The details: PEN America, Penguin, and five authors of banned books filed a federal lawsuit against the Escambia County School District and School Board, claiming they violated the First Amendment by banning 10 books from its school libraries. The suit also alleges the groups violated the constitutional equal protection clause because most of the books targeted included themes of race, sexuality, or gender.

A number of books including George M. Johnsonâ€™s All Boys Arenâ€™t Blue, Toni Morrisonâ€™s The Bluest Eye, and Judy Blumeâ€™s Foreverâ€¦ were challenged by one single language arts teacher, according to the suit. Escambia County School District has declined to comment.

Whatâ€™s so special about Escambia Countyâ€™s book bans? PEN America said this specific school district has attempted to ban or restrict almost 200 books.

Montana bans TikTok. Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte signed a law that makes Montana the first US state <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> to comprehensively ban the Chinese-owned app. While other states have banned TikTok on government-issued devices over national security concerns, Montanaâ€™s law blocks the app from operating inside its borders and penalizes app stores from making TikTok available for download in Montana. The ban goes into effect on Jan. 1, but you can bet opponents (like TikTok and free speech advocates) will take Montana to court over this major escalation.

Things are about to get heated. The World Meteorological Organization estimates <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> that thereâ€™s a 66% chance the world will experience warming of 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, at least temporarily, by 2027. The number has long been considered a breaking point for keeping climate change in check. The group expects that the extra heat from the natural El NiÃ±o weather phenomenon coupled with human-caused warming will likely make the next five years the hottest on record.

Uber to let teens ride. To expand its user base, Uber is preparing to take on one of the most thankless parenting tasks: ferrying teens around. The dominant ride-hailing company will now permit unaccompanied teens <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> aged 13+ to use the service, though initially only in certain cities. Theyâ€™ll have to use new teen accounts attached to family profiles that will summon only â€œexperienced and highly rated driversâ€ and will allow their parents to track rides in real time, Uber says.

FOOD TECH

CRISPR lettuce for your summer salad <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> Scientists at Pairwise have gene-edited mustard greens to be less bitter <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> Hannah Minn
Genetically edited mustard greens are coming for the salad base throne thanks to scientists who have figured out how to remove the trait that makes the nutritious vegetable taste so bitter.

The new and improved milder mustard greens from agriculture startup Pairwise will be the first food on the US market to have been tweaked using the revolutionary gene-editing tool CRISPR. The modified greens are already being served in a few restaurants and will begin hitting grocery stores this summer.

But you probably wonâ€™t know theyâ€™re anything special from the packaging. Unlike GMO foods that bend the laws of nature by incorporating genes from other species, gene-edited foods contain modified versions of their own genes, so the USDA doesnâ€™t require the â€œbioengineeredâ€ label it slaps on GMOs.

The logic is that gene-editing merely speeds up a process that can occur naturally: Rather than using the centuries-old crossbreeding methods that can take a decade to alter traits, scientists used CRISPR to directly edit the mustard greens DNA for debittered lettuce in just four years, according to Wired <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ne?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>.

New priorities: Until recently, gene editing and genetic modification had been used mainly to boost crop yields. Mustard greens 2.0 is all about getting consumers to substitute iceberg and other nutrient-lacking lettuce for a more nutritional vegetable.â€”ML

TECH

AI is in its regulation era <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Sam Altman at Senate hearing <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Win McNamee/Getty Images
Typically when a tech CEO goes in front of a Senate committee, they end up explaining how to use email. Not so yesterday, when Sam Altman, CEO of ChatGPT-maker OpenAI, testified <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> on Capitol Hill on the future of AI and how the field should be regulated.

What happened at the hearing? Setting an ominous tone for what was to come, Sen. Richard Blumenthal, the chair of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, read opening remarks that he later revealed were created by AI. The hearing continued with a discussion of the dangers presented by an unpredictable, evolving technology that can create and spread misleading information without us even realizing it (looking at you, drippy pope).

Lawmakers acknowledged past failures to implement timely regulation for advances in technology. Sen. Blumenthal said, â€œCongress failed to meet the moment on social media,â€ and hinted at wanting to avoid the same mistake again.

Regulating AI is like herding kittens on rollerskates Experts donâ€™t agree on what regulation <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> should look like for AI because itâ€™s evolving much faster than other technologies. And moving quickly (or at all) isnâ€™t exactly Congressâ€™s strong suit, so itâ€™s unclear whether traditional lawmaking can keep up with the regulation of a technology that is constantly changing.

But theyâ€™ll try. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer is working alongside experts to create a framework that focuses on transparency within AI models. It would require that models disclose who trained them and their data sources, but the proposal will likely face resistance from AI companies.

Altman, who warned â€œif this technology goes wrong, it can go quite wrong,â€ is also in favor of regulationâ€”but came with his own ideas. He advocated for the creation of a new government agency with the power to license large AI models, create and monitor safety standards, and conduct independent audits. But he did not mention requiring transparency around model training or source data.

Looking aheadâ€¦expect the regulation talk to heat up as both Congress and tech leaders try to figure out how to manage the existential risk posed by AI.â€”CC

Taco Bell wants to free T*co T*esday <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FS?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Taco out of open cage <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FS?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Francis Scialabba
Normally the villain of your insides, Taco Bell is trying to be a hero by freeing the name â€œTaco Tuesdayâ€ from its IP prison. The fast-food chain filed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> a petition yesterday to cancel the trademark of the phrase owned by a smaller taco chain, Taco Johnâ€™s.

Taco Johnâ€™s, maker of the also-trademarked Potato OlÃ©s, has owned the trademark on Taco Tuesday in 49 states since 1989 and has not been shy about sending cease-and-desist letters to anyone who tries to use it to promote tacosâ€¦on Tuesday.

In the one state where Taco Johnâ€™s doesnâ€™t have the trademarkâ€”New Jerseyâ€”a restaurant and bar called Gregoryâ€™s owns it. Taco Bell filed to Baja blast away Gregoryâ€™s trademark as well.

The creators of the Crunchwrap Supreme (also trademarked) said in a press release that the phrase â€œshould belong to all who make, sell, eat and celebrate tacosâ€â€”so it wonâ€™t be seeking damages or future trademarking of the phrase on its own. In response, Taco Johnâ€™s announcedâ€¦a Taco Tuesday deal.

Could Taco Bell win this thing? In 2019, LeBron James tried to trademark Taco Tuesday, and the US Patent and Trademark Office rejected his app, saying that the phrase was just too common (thereby kind of admitting no company should hold a trademark on it). Taco Bell might be hoping this precedent will work in its favor, but it will likely be a couple years until the beef is resolved.â€”MM

Stat: In the 1980s and 1990s, almost one-third of job seekers in the US would pack up and move for a new role. Now, virtually nobody is doing that <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>. According to a new survey from Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the share of American job seekers who relocated for a new position dropped to a record low of 1.6% in Q1 of 2023. The ability to work remotely, combined with the fact that finding a new house right now is the absolute worst <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>, is responsible for the seismic change.

ECONOMY

Ballooning consumer debt isnâ€™t deflating <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Credit card that is being blown up with a bike pump <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Hannah Minn
If youâ€™ve been dropping plastic a lot and hoping itâ€™ll take care of itself later, join the club. Yesterday, the New York Fed released its Q1 report on household debt: Findings include a record-high debt level of $17 trillion, persistent credit card debt, and rising delinquency rates.

A typical first quarter sees credit card balances decline as people pay off what they spent over the holidays while trying to out-gift their in-laws. But, for the first time in 20 years, that isnâ€™t the case, according to Bloomberg. Balances remained flat over Q1, suggesting that people arenâ€™t cutting back and are probably using credit cards to finance daily spending due to the rising cost ofâ€¦pretty much everything.

Itâ€™s not just that credit card balances are flat. Delinquency is rising, as is its intimidating older brother, serious delinquency, which is when a debt is 90+ days past due. The Fedâ€™s report showed that 4.57% of credit card debt transitioned to serious delinquency last quarter, up from 3.04% in Q1 of 2022. And for credit card holders aged 18â€“29, 8.3% of balances were in serious delinquency.

Plastic isnâ€™t the only thing to blame In addition to causing lots of folks to check their credit card balance real quick, the report had a few key takeaways:

Auto loan delinquencies are higher than they were before the pandemic for those under 40. The average monthly car payment is $729.

Mortgage debt increased by $121 billion in the first quarter, reaching a $12.04 trillion balance, likely as a result of the Fedâ€™s rate increase extravaganza.

Student debt saw a slight decrease in the rate of serious delinquency, which went down to less than 1%â€”but thatâ€™s probably because repayment is paused for now.

Zoom out: Debt balances are almost $3 trillion higher than pre-pandemic, but Fed analysts see an upside; many households are still more financially stable than they were before thanks to the mortgage refi boom <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BU?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> of 2020â€“2021 when rates were at their lowest.â€”CC

Tour de headlines Illustration of a Call of Duty skeleton with Microsoft logo in his eyes Illustration: Dianna â€œMickâ€ McDougall, Photo: Call of Duty/Activision
At least the EU likes Microsoftâ€™s $69b deal to buy Activision. In a win Microsoft needed to keep its deal with Activision alive, EU antitrust regulators gave its efforts to acquire the Call of Duty-maker the green light <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> yesterday. But Microsoft still has an uphill battle to get the deal through antitrust watchdogs in the UK and the US. UK regulators rejected the deal last month, and yesterday criticized the fixes accepted by its EU counterpart. And in the States, the FTC has sued to block it.

FBI comes under fire for Trump-Russia probe. Trump-appointed Special Counsel John Durham has finally released <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> his report on the agencyâ€™s probe into allegations linking former President Donald Trumpâ€™s 2016 campaign to Russia, and he concluded that the investigation should never have happened. The 306-page report states that the agency rushed into the investigation based on â€œraw, unanalyzed, and uncorroborated intelligence,â€ while being much more cautious regarding claims against Hillary Clinton. The report is unlikely to end partisan fighting over the issue, especially since Durhamâ€™s four years of work yielded few court victories.

Vice Media filed for bankruptcy. The company, which was valued at $5.7 billion in 2017, filed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Co?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday and plans to sell itself to a group of creditors for $225 million. Itâ€™s the latest in a string of digital media companies to stumble recently after advertising revenue became harder to come by. Viceâ€™s filing was also one of seven large companies to head to bankruptcy court in a 48 hour periodâ€”marking the largest number of filings during a two-day period since 2008, according to Bloomberg.

Heâ€™s about to secure <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6B_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> a $100 million funding round for an eye scan-enabled global cryptocurrency, worldcoin, according to the Financial Times.

Itâ€™s not totally unrelated to his signature project: Worldcoinâ€™s goal is to verify whether users are human by scanning their irises to disburse universal basic income...to workers displaced by AI.

Finding investors for a crypto startup during crypto winter is just one of Altmanâ€™s side projects. The venture capitalistâ€™s resume increasingly looks like a cyberpunk manga.

The Altman-backed nuclear fission startup, Helion Energy, recently notched a deal to supply electricity to Microsoft in 2028, even though most experts say that timeline for making the tech work is a long shot.

But so is expanding the average human lifespan by 10 years, a research effort by Retro Biosciences, which the serial entrepreneur plugged with $180 million.

Zoom out: This may all sound like the beginning of a dystopian sci-fi scenario, but Altman claims heâ€™s aware of the potential dangers of his ventures and is concerned with more than just profit. Still, some worry that he wonâ€™t be able to build technology at a breakneck pace without unleashing chaos.â€”SK

TECH

Trade offer: You get a free TV, Telly gets your eyeballs <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Trade offer: You get a free TV, Telly gets your eyeballs <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Telly
Whoever has been making sacrifices to the free television gods just got their prayers answered. The hardware startup Telly is giving away 500,000 55-inch 4K flat-screens at no cost to your wallet.

But, like most free things, the TV comes with a catch <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>: constant advertisements and data collection.

A never-ending ad stream will live on the dual-screen TVâ€™s lower â€œSmart Screen,â€ a nine-inch addendum that can also show weather, stocks, and other widgets. The main screen might also display ads when youâ€™re not using it.

Youâ€™ll also have to answer some demographic and psychographic questions when you sign up to make the ads more targeted: â€œIf Toyota wants to run an ad to people that currently own a Honda whose lease expires within the next 12 months, we pick and choose those individual TVs,â€ Telly co-founder Ilya Pozin, who also co-founded Pluto TV, told <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> the Hollywood Reporter.

If youâ€™re okay with all that, you can reserve a free TV on Tellyâ€™s website <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>. Theyâ€™re expected to ship this summer.

Zoom out: Marketers say it was only a matter of time before a free TV emerged, since prices for devices like Roku and smart TV sets have been coming down as ad sales have grown. Ad spending for internet-connected TVs rose from about $6 billion in 2019 to more than $21 billion in 2022, according to Statista.â€”ML

Key performance indicators An image from the Netflix show Queen Cleopatra Queen Cleopatra/Netflix

Quote: â€œThe thing that I miss the most about being on the surface is literally the sun.â€

University of South Florida Joseph Dituri, who also goes by Dr. Deep Sea, recently beat the world record <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Cb?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> for time spent living underwater without depressurization by spending 74 days 30 feet deep in a Key Largo lagoon inside the Julesâ€™ Undersea Lodge. And heâ€™s not about to surface any time soonâ€”he plans to spend 100 days there to complete his research. But despite ascribing to the philosophy that itâ€™s better down where itâ€™s wetter, Dituri admitted he misses seeing the sun rise. He doesnâ€™t miss class, thoughâ€”heâ€™s still teaching online.

Markets: Despite the risk of the US defaulting on its debts next month, equity investors have kept calm and carried on <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ww?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>, sending the Nasdaq to a weekly gain last week. But over in the bond market, investors are sweating. The cost of credit-default swaps, which act as insurance over a default, is higher in the US than in emerging markets like Mexico and Brazil.

Stock spotlight: This is just a wild stat about the stock marketâ€™s concentrationâ€¦Appleâ€™s market cap is now greater <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wx?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> than the value of every company in the Russell 2000 small-cap index combined.

GEOGRAPHY

The suburbs are buzzing <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> Suburban mall in Virginia <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> Robert Knopes/Education Images/Universal Images Group via Getty Images
Have a few morning meetings, hit a Sweetgreen for lunch, finish up work, then go see your favorite band play a showâ€”sounds like a day you could only pull off in a city.

Not anymore. As Axios reported, the rise of remote work has breathed new life <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wz?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> into Americaâ€™s suburbs, drowning out the roar of leaf blowers with commercial growth, an influx of new residents, and increased cultural opportunities, like legitimately good restaurants <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>.

Retailers show the way

Youâ€™ve read headlines about major retailers closing stores in downtowns. But the reverse is happening in the suburbs, where retailers are opening new locations <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> to meet customers where they live and, increasingly, work. The availability of urban retail topped suburban availability in the second half of last year for the first time since at least 2013, the WSJ reported citing CBRE data.

Case study: Sweetgreen.

In 2019, 35% of Sweetgreenâ€™s real estate footprint was in the suburbs.

As of last summer, half of its locations are rockinâ€™ the suburbs.

Even suburban malls, which have been given their last rites for decades, appear to be recuperating. Shopping center landlords are setting leasing and occupancy records this year, according to the WSJ.

A trickle into a flood

The US suburban population had been increasing before the pandemic, growing 10.5% between 2010 and 2020, according to the Census. But lawns and patios became even more attractive during Covid, and the desire to live your best North Caldwell life has stuck around post-pandemic. Nearly half of millennials surveyed in a recent Bank of America report <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> (43%â€“45%) said they expected to buy a house in the suburbs.

And as the suburbs have ballooned, they look a lot less like Leave It to Beaver. The populations of big American suburbs are now more diverse <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> than the broader US population, according to Brookings.

Bottom line: The WFH-enabled rise of the suburbs may serve as a wake-up call <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> to cities, where, in the case of NYC, 26 Empire State Buildingsâ€™-worth of office space now sits empty. According to Stanfordâ€™s Nicholas Bloom, the typical office worker is spending $2,000â€“$4,600 less annually in city centers.

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wG?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wH?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> 

TOGETHER WITH FACET

The first step to facing your financial fears <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uV?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=title> Facet <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uV?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=image>
What do we do when weâ€™re stressed out? We procrastinate, of course. Because nothing solves a problem like avoiding it!

Jokes aside, *90% of Americans are anxious about money <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uW?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=text1> (yowza ). â€‹â€‹ Turkish election is headed for a runoff. Ja Morant suspended again. The Memphis Grizzlies star has been suspended <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wK?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> from all team activities after he appeared to be holding a gun on an Instagram livestream this weekend. After the first incident, in March, Morant was suspended for eight games and lost out on $668,000 of his salary. SPORTS

5 sports betting stats on its 5th birthday <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wL?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> a roulette wheel inside a baseball diamond <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wL?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> Francis Scialabba
Five years ago yesterday, the Supreme Court lifted <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wM?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> a federal ban on sports gambling in the US, spawning a multibillion-dollar industry thatâ€™s transformed how Americans watch, talk about, and experience sports.

We plucked five numbers from the sports betting world to highlight five years of legalization.

$95 billion: Thatâ€™s how much Americans bet on sports in legal jurisdictions with consumer protections last year, Sportico reported. Itâ€™s more money <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wN?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> than the amount spent on ride sharing, coffee, and streaming.

71%: Two sports betting companies, DraftKings and FanDuel, control more than 70% <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wO?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> of the US market, per gambling analytics firm Eilers & Krejcik. But despite taking in ~10% of wagers, these companies have struggled to turn a profit. FanDuel recorded its first quarterly profit last year, and DraftKings has yet to report a profitable quarter.

33: Thatâ€™s the number of states, not including Washington, DC, that currently have legal sports betting. Another four states have legalized sports wagering, but donâ€™t have any sportsbooks operating yet.

3: The three most-populous US statesâ€”California, Texas, and Floridaâ€”have not legalized sports gambling. They account for 26% of all teams in the major North American pro leagues, according to Axios.

45%: The number of women joining sportsbook apps jumped 45% last year, marking the third straight year that new women users exceeded men. Plus, the amount bet on womenâ€™s sports in 2022 increased 61% annually on DraftKings.

OSCAR WINNER HIRING BABYSITTER: At age 79, Robert De Niro revealed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ul?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> that he had fathered his seventh child (his oldest child is now 51). De Niro is excited to have the opportunity to force one more generation to watch Goodfellas in his lifetime.

MUSIC LIQUIDATOR: Spotify purged <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6um?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> thousands of AI-generated songs uploaded by the music startup Boomy. The streamer said it flagged the tunes it thought were being listened to by bots, which inflated listener numbers. But maybe it was just bots making music for other bots 
Â  SNAPSHOT

Â  Photo of the week Brienz, Switzerland I, Parpan05, Brienz-Brinzauls Dorf, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/legalcode> Take a good look at the Swiss village of Brienzâ€¦because it may be the last time you see it intact. Residents of the picturesque town had to evacuate <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uu?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> their homes last week after officials warned that 70 million cubic feet of rock could break off the nearby mountain and come crashing down on Brienz in the coming days or weeks.

Â  SCIENCE

Â  Dept. of Progress Dexter from Dexter's lab saying Dexterâ€™s Laboratory/Warner Bros. Domestic Television via Giphy Here are some illuminating scientific discoveries from the week to help you live better and maybe even win over your neighborâ€™s cat.

The financial dangers of looking on the sunny side. Spring is here, the sun is shiningâ€”and new research shows thatâ€™s likely to affect the stock market. A study <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uv?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> that examined the weatherâ€™s impact on Chinese investorsâ€™ behavior in auction-style secondary equity offerings found that on days investors needed sunglasses, they were more optimistic and less risk-averse, driving bidding up and discounts down. Even one standard deviation in either sunshine intensity or duration made a noticeable difference. This adds to previous studies that found sunlight is associated with higher market returns and that fall and winter IPOs get priced lower.

Learn how to catcall more effectively. Cats are notoriously fickle, but French scientists have determined the best way to call <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uw?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> an unfamiliar cat to you and actually get it to come is by using a combination of audio and visual cues (rather than just one or the other). If you have to pick just one, a purely visual summoning gets a quicker feline response than a solely vocal one. The researchers discovered all this by testing out techniques on kitties from a cat cafe.

Get ready for Smell-O-Vision. One quick way to tell whether youâ€™re in a VR simulation or the real world is to ask yourself whether things have scents. But that might change now that scientists have developed more efficient systems for integrating smell <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ux?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> into the virtual world. Previous efforts involved messy aerosols and bulked-up headsets, but the new scent delivery method works by heating wax, so the user needs just a small under-nose patch or soft mask. The researchers have made 30 smells so far, including stinky durian fruit, and testers identifying them had a 93% success rate.â€”AR

Improving internal morale: When Valimail Chief People Officer Elaine Mak saw employee engagement was down, she partnered with CFO Ryan McQueeney <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5pF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781&lp=text1> to align their talent needs and financial goals with the larger organizational strategy. Â  NEWS ANALYSIS

Â  How tech CEOs learned to hate remote work <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> Zuckerberg over zoom with office window in background <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>Michael M. Santiago/New York Times Staff/Getty Images Can you guess what â€œone of the tech industryâ€™s worst mistakes <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6u_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>â€ is, according to OpenAI CEO Sam Altman?

Itâ€™s not Quibi. Itâ€™s buying into the idea that 100% remote work wouldnâ€™t cost startups creativity, as he recently said at an event organized by payment company Stripe.

The OpenAI CEO is the latest tech exec to argue that an 8:57am wake-up call and leisurely cold brew in bed might not be the optimal Tuesday morning routine for tech workers, despite many leaders having once hailed WFH as the way of the future.

Then vs. now

When the pandemic shut down the world, many tech leaders were quick to proclaim a permanent WFH revolution. But now, one after another, Silicon Valley bosses are trading remote work evangelism for remote work frustration, citing productivity concerns.

Here are a few examples.

Meta: In May 2020, Mark Zuckerberg told The Verge <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6v0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> he wanted to mold Facebook into â€œthe most forward-leaning company on remote work at our scale.â€ In the first months of the pandemic, he said employees could apply to make their job permanently remote and predicted that half of the company could work off-site in 5â€“10 years.

Fast forward to 2023: Zuck is saying that in-person engineers â€œget more doneâ€ and that Meta is reevaluating its distributed team approach.

Salesforce: In 2021, Salesforceâ€™s CEO Marc Benioff was seemingly at peace with the idea of never again seeing his companyâ€™s glitzy SF skyscraper bustling with workers. â€œTheyâ€™re mostly at home, and thatâ€™s fine,â€ he said then.

Now, it might not be fine after all: Late last year, he wondered in an internal Slack if the â€œmuch lower productivityâ€ of employees hired during the pandemic is â€œa reflection of our office policy,â€ according to CNBC.

What changed?

The US is experiencing the biggest decline in worker productivity since 1948, according to research from EY-Parthenon, and many executives have been quick to single out remote work as the main culprit.

This is what they cite to prove their point.

* A study <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> published in Nature Human Behaviour found that working remotely made Microsoftâ€™s remote workers miss important learning opportunities by not rubbing elbows with coworkers who arenâ€™t part of their immediate team.

* More recent research <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> showed that interacting through a screen can make workers less likely to generate ideas. Thatâ€™s a problem for tech companies needing to out-innovate the competition.

For many industry leaders, accessing a wider talent pool outside of traditional tech hubs isnâ€™t enough to make up for those drawbacks. And as widespread labor shortages subside and layoffs sweep through Silicon Valley, companies are no longer in a perk war to recruit and retain the brightest minds.

Zoom out: The Big Tech office push mirrors broader white-collar labor market dynamics. In December, 13% of LinkedIn postings were for remote jobs, compared to 20% nine months prior.â€”SK

Â  DESTINATIONS

Â  Place to be: Milwaukeeâ€™s haunted hotel Pfister Hotel on September 20, 2014 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin Raymond Boyd/Getty Images Itâ€™s a big universe out there. In this section, weâ€™ll teleport you to an interesting locationâ€”and hopefully give you travel ideas in the process.

Los Angeles Dodgers star outfielder Mookie Betts isnâ€™t spooked by a 100 mph fastballâ€¦but he sure as heck is scared of ghosts.

When his team traveled to Milwaukee last week to play the Brewers, Betts declined <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uO?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> to stay at the downtown Pfister Hotel with the rest of the Dodgers and opted to shack up with some friends at an Airbnb instead.

Why? Because the 130-year-old Pfister Hotel is allegedly haunted by the apparition of its founder, Charles Pfister. And, while itâ€™s unclear whether Pfisterâ€™s ghost is on the Brewers payroll (designated specter?), heâ€™s relished the opportunity to disturb visiting baseball players whoâ€™ve stayed there.

* In 2001, visiting player AdriÃ¡n BeltrÃ© said his TV inexplicably kept turning off and on, and he heard unexplained knocking on his door, according to Sports Illustrated. He ended up getting just two hours of sleep in three nights.

* Eight MLB players, including Bryce Harper and Giancarlo Stanton, reported spooky experiences <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uP?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> when staying at the Pfister. â€œFrom the minute I walk in there, Iâ€™m freaked out,â€ Justin Upton told ESPN.

When its founder isnâ€™t conducting psychological warfare against baseball players, the Pfister Hotel is considered one of the nicest hotels in Milwaukee and a historic landmark <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uQ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>. Every US president since William McKinley has stayed at the Pfister, and Elvis Presley checked in just four months before he died, according to WUWM.â€”NF

Who is Yaccarino? Sheâ€™s a heavyweight in the advertising industry, nicknamed â€œthe velvet hammerâ€ for her negotiating tactics. Yaccarino brings something Twitter has desperately lacked since Musk took over: credibility with advertisers. When Musk took over the platform, ad sales brought in more than 90% of Twitterâ€™s revenue, but after a shaky takeover, advertisers bounced.

Monthly ad revenue from Twitterâ€™s top 1,000 advertisers dropped from roughly $127 million in October 2022 (the month Musk bought the company) to $48 million in January 2023, according to digital marketing analysis firm Pathmatics by Sensor Tower.

Musk tried to replace some of those lost dollars by making people pay for their blue check marks with Twitter Blue, but that flopped. GAMING

Zelda is back and bigger than ever Scene from Zelda Nintendo
If your gamer friends go MIA this weekend, theyâ€™re probably answering the call to take up arms as the Hero of Hyrule in the most anticipated <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rf?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> video game release of the year: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom, out today.

Itâ€™s a sequel to The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild (2017), the flagship Nintendo Switch game that gave a jolt to the slumping video game console market. Nintendo said Breath of the Wild sold almost 30 million copiesâ€”more than all <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rg?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> of the previous 3D installments in the franchiseâ€™s four-decade history combined, Wired reports.

It looks like Tears of the Kingdom could surpass its predecessor. The game is about two gigabytes bigger than Breath of the Wild and $10 more expensive in its digital edition, making it the Switchâ€™s largest and priciest Nintendo game, per GameSpot.

Whatâ€™s all the hype?

The Zelda hive is BIG. The Reddit group devoted to the world of Zelda has 2.1 million members compared to just 147,000 in r/Mario, and it far outstrips r/CallOfDuty and r/gtaonline, two powerhouse video game franchises.

With such a rabid fanbase, Zelda has pushed beyond the borders of its land, Hyrule, and into broader pop culture.

Its characters have been referenced in mainstream media like The Simpsons, How I Met Your Mother, My Little Pony, and Scott Pilgrim vs. the World.

ASAP Mob, Rejjie Snow, and Chance the Rapper have all sampled sound effects specific to the Zelda games in songs.

Fun fact: Zelda was Robin Williamsâ€™s favorite video game franchise, so much so that he named his only daughter Zelda.

Big picture: While The Legend of Zelda has been adored by gamers since the original 8-bit Link slashed moblins on the Nintendo Entertainment System in 1986, Breath of the Wild revolutionized open-world gaming and invited a wave of new and younger players to join the die-hards.

Tears of the Kingdom is expected to capitalize on the last installmentâ€™s momentum by picking up where its predecessor left off, but with a bigger map, more creative gameplay, and a brand-new campaign to beat.â€”ML

Tour de headlines In an aerial view, immigrants seeking asylum in the United States wait in line near the border fence to be processed by U.S. Border Patrol agents Mario Tama/Getty Images
All eyes in the southern border as Title 42 ends. The Covid-era policy that allowed US authorities to quickly deport migrants expired <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ri?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> at 11:59pm last night, and itâ€™s expected to result in a spike in border crossings that the US is likely not prepared to handle. 60,000 people were waiting near the border to enter the US yesterday, though Border Patrol is already far beyond capacity with 25,000 migrants in custody, the BBC reported. The Biden administration has replaced Title 42 with other policies intended to stem illegal crossings.

Peloton recalls 2.2 million of its bikes. If you bought a Peloton bike in the US between January 2018 and May 2023, you should stop using it and contact Peloton for a free repair, the company said yesterday. Peloton found that the bikeâ€™s seat post can break <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rj?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> while youâ€™re riding, which can lead to injury. This recall is the fourth Peloton has issued for its exercise products in the past several years and weighed down its already beat-down stock. Shares sank to their lowest level since Pelotonâ€™s 2019 IPO.

WORK

Surprise: People like their jobs <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rl?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> Graph showing share of people who are satisfied in their jobs from 1987-2023 <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rl?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254>
The Conference Board released new data <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rm?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> showing that 62.3% of US workers are satisfied with their job, the highest share since the business research organization started the survey in 1987.

Whatâ€™s behind the newfound satisfaction? Itâ€™s not kombucha on tap, a yoga wellness retreat, or because next Friday is Hawaiian shirt day. Rather, resurgent employee happiness is mostly attributed to hybrid work arrangements, job flexibility, and the pandemic-induced tight labor market that has allowed people to leave jobs they hate for jobs they like (or at least hate less).

Note: The survey was conducted last November, before tech companies started mass layoffs.

But even worker satisfaction has a gender gap. Women were less satisfied <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rn?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> overall than men in each of the 26 categories surveyed, including leave policies, promotions, and culture. The biggest gap was in job security: 68.7% of men felt satisfied with their level of job security, compared to 61.8% of women.

Itâ€™s unclear how the potential economic downturn would affect worker satisfaction. If the labor market cools off significantly, employees will be less able to ditch jobs theyâ€™re unhappy with as companies lamp down on hiring.â€”CC

Key performance indicators dozens of Empire State Buildings Francis Scialabba
Stat: How much empty office space does New York City have right now? Enough to fill more than 26 Empire State Buildings <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6rx?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31457418.2802254> (about 74.6 million square feet, if you want to be specific). Researchers Edward Glaeser and Carlo Ratti made the comparison to emphasize how NYC and other large American cities need to make drastic changes to their zoning laws to adapt to the WFH era. The ultimate goal: become a â€œPlayground Cityâ€ where people live, work, and play all in the same neighborhood.

Friday puzzle

Think of a one-word fruit that is spelled with 11-letters. Remove the last two letters of its name. When you anagram the remaining nine letters, you can find the name of two other fruits: one with four letters the other with five. What are the three fruits?

IMMIGRATION

US braces for border chaos as Title 42 expires <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6n_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> People standing at the US-Mexico border <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6n_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> Patrick T. Fallon/Getty Images
Today marks the end of the US Public Health Emergency for Covid-19. And when it expires tonight, so does the controversial immigration policy Title 42.

What is Title 42? A public health policy that went into effect in March 2020 that allowed US Border Patrol to turn away migrants seeking asylum to prevent the further spread of Covid. Title 42 received criticism from the ACLU and other advocacy organizations for using public health as a pretext for keeping immigrants out of the country. Border regulations will now revert to pre-pandemic rules permitting asylum-seekers to stay in the US while their cases are processed.

Why is it expiring? Title 42 was only legal because of the national public health emergency. Now that the Biden administration is ending the emergency, Title 42 has no legal basis.

Authorities anticipate an immigration surge

Officials expect those who attempted to make it into the US during Title 42 could try again, knowing that they canâ€™t be turned away so easily. The following places have already declared a state of emergency:

Brownsville, El Paso, and Laredo, Texas. In El Paso, an estimated 2,300 people are living on the streets because shelters are at maximum capacity.

Chicago. The self-proclaimed â€œsanctuary cityâ€ saw more than 8,000 migrants arrive in the past year.

Two New York counties. The counties each declared a separate state of emergency after NYC Mayor Eric Adams said he wanted to send migrants to hotels in the suburbs.

Looking aheadâ€¦1,500 additional troops sent by the Biden administration have started to arrive at the border. The president is also expanding legal avenues into the US for migrants. But whether or not the federal government has an adequate plan to handle the increase in migrants at the border remains to be seen.â€”CC

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o2?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853>

Itâ€™s not just super powerful, itâ€™s also lighter and cheaper to produce.

They did it through relentless R&D, $30m in funding from the US Department of Defense (plus a fresh $9m contract with the Army), 82 patents, and the support of everyday investors just like you.

LiquidPiston isnâ€™t stopping at disrupting a $40b market, either. Theyâ€™re aiding our armed forces with everything from helping drones fly farther to making generators smallerâ€”but they need your support to do it.

WORLD

Tour de headlines Birth control pills Lou Benoist/Getty Images
FDA panel backs OTC birth control approval. A panel of outside experts voted unanimously <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> yesterday that the agency should allow over-the-counter sales of Opill, a hormonal birth control pill that has been available with a prescription for half a century, despite concerns raised by FDA staff about whether people would properly follow the drugâ€™s instructions. If drugmaker Perrigo scores this approval for Opill, it would be the first nonprescription oral contraceptive sold in the US. The FDA is expected to make a final decision this summer.

Disney trims its streaming losses. The company reported that price increases helped significantly reduce the losses <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> incurred by its streaming services last quarter, even though Disney+ lost 4 million subscribers. Additional price hikes are coming, but more people may soon be able to watch Disney+ content anyway since some of it will come to Hulu, CEO Bob Iger said. Traditional TV is still lagging, but Disney saw a boost in revenue from its theme parks.

Donald Trump says GOP should let the US default. Speaking at a town hall event with mostly Republican voters on CNN, the former president and 2024 hopeful said Republicans should allow the country to default <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ow?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> on its debt unless Biden agrees to â€œmassive cuts.â€ He also doubled down on his claims that the 2020 election was â€œrigged <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6oy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853>â€ and wouldnâ€™t say whether he would sign a federal abortion ban or whether he wanted Russia or Ukraine to win the war.

George Santos charged with crimes of dishonesty <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6nr?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> George Santos appeared in federal court on Wednesday. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6nr?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> Tom Williams / Getty Images
After being dragged in the court of public opinion for deceiving voters about his qualifications and personal connection to 9/11, Rep. George Santosâ€™s alleged aversion to the truth got him indicted on 13 financial crimes yesterday. The congressman pleaded not guilty.

If convicted, the New York lawmaker could get more than 20 years in prison <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ns?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> for wire fraud alone, in addition to the sentences potentially carried by money laundering, theft of public funds, andâ€”perhaps least surprisinglyâ€”lying to the House of Representatives.

According to federal prosecutors, Santos allegedly:

Solicited campaign donations that ended up in his pocket, including tens of thousands of dollars used to pay off debts, give money to associates, and foot the bill for designer clothes (trÃ¨s chic).

Falsely claimed unemployment in the summer of 2020 to get $24,000 in pandemic-era benefits. He was reportedly employed at the time at Florida-based investment firm Harbor City Capitalâ€¦which the SEC shut down in 2021 for being a â€œclassic Ponzi scheme.â€

Failed to mention those unemployment benefits or earnings from Harbor City on congressional financial disclosure forms.

Where does this leave Congress? Santos says he wonâ€™t resign and has even pledged to run for reelection. House Speaker Kevin McCarthy said he would not support the reelection bid, but heâ€™s not calling for Santos to resignâ€”yet. He said he would do so if the House Ethics Committee finds Santos broke the law.â€”ML

Google introduces AI search and a foldable phone <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> Google tablet and foldable phones with google logo. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> Morning Brew/Images: Google

And it may be the future <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> of search: Instead of gathering up a bunch of links (sponsored and just plain popular), answers to queries will be written by Googleâ€™s AI and will appear at the top of the page for some searches, the company said.

The update will roll out to just a few users at first but could signal a radical change <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6o7?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31442606.2893853> for publishers.

Fruit Roll-Ups have become so popular in Israel that people are willing to pay $6 each.

MEDIA

Americans don't agree on what news to trust <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gc?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> Turning on TV gif <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gc?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> Francis Scialabba, Photos: Getty Images
â€œIn the media we only sometimes trustâ€ could be Americaâ€™s motto, according to the results of a YouGov poll <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> released yesterday. The April survey shows extreme polarization in how much folks trust 45 different news outlets.

CNN and MSNBC are the most divisive media orgs: A much larger share of Democrats than Republicans think theyâ€™re in the business of telling the truth. Winning over Democrats may be the easier task: The survey shows they're more likely to trust the media in generalâ€”theyâ€™re even more likely than Republicans to have faith in the conservative-leaning New York Post.

And, in some good news for the brave souls who report from the eye of the storm, the most trusted news source overall is The Weather Channel, followed by PBS and the BBC. Meanwhile, only a handful of ultra-distrusted publications, including Breitbart News, The Daily Caller and InfoWars, have more skeptics than believers, per the survey.

What this means for TV

The lack of trust likely isnâ€™t helping cable news ratings. CNN and Fox News, enjoying the trust of just 40% and 38% of the public, respectively, are struggling to convince viewers to tune in.

CNN had a 61% drop in prime-time viewership in March compared with a year earlier, as it attempts to reinvent itself under new management.

Fox lost 29.6% of its prime-time audience in the week after it dismissed its most popular on-air personality, Tucker Carlson, in the wake of a defamation scandal with a $787.5 million legal settlement.

But at least the two TV behemoths have less of a credibility problem to worry about than TikTok, which ranked as the most distrusted social media platform in the surveyâ€”even among younger adults. Meanwhile, LinkedIn is the only social media site with a greater share of folks trusting it than not.

Looking aheadâ€¦the situation might be improving: Media skepticism overall has declined in recent months compared to a similar YouGov survey from last year.â€”SK

TOGETHER WITH MONOGRAM

These robots are planning for the Nasdaq <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6cO?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933&lp=title> Monogram <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6cO?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933&lp=image>

Monogram aims to launch the first active-cutting robotic surgical assistant on the market to install their personalized, 3D-printed joint implants. Perfect timing, since 50% of joint replacement surgeries will involve robotics by 2030. They showed off their robotâ€™s potential with a live surgery on a cadaver for a 5k-person digital audience this year.

In a world with 100k failed joint surgeries every year, this industry kneeds a solution. Invest in Monogram before their intended Nasdaq listingâ€”and be on the lookout for ticker MGRM.

WORLD

Tour de headlines House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Joe Biden Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images
The debt ceiling dance is on. President Biden is scheduled to meet <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gh?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> today with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other congressional leaders to negotiate over raising the debt limit (and thereby avert economic catastrophe). The two sides are coming into the negotiations far apart: Biden says it should be raised with no conditions, while Republicans have vowed only to raise it in exchange for steep spending cuts. The clock is ticking as the US is expected to run out of money to pay all its bills as of June, but todayâ€™s meeting is not expected to produce a final result.

Meat prices are coming down. Itâ€™s good news for anyone whose regular pizza order is the meat lovers, but bad news for Tyson Foods, which reported a surprise $97 million quarterly loss <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gi?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> yesterday (sending its stock down 16%). The company said that itâ€™s still facing higher prices for feed and livestock, but canâ€™t pass the extra costs to consumers because of waning demand. Its average sale price dropped 10.3% for pork and 5.4% for beef last quarter.

The Army terminated Texas mall shooter after three months. As authorities continued to investigate the motives and white supremacist views of the shooter who killed eight people at a Texas outlet mall over the weekend, military officials told news outlets yesterday that he had been discharged <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gj?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> from the US Army in 2008 due to a mental health issue after just three months and did not complete training. The shooter, who was killed by police during the attack, purchased the guns he used through legal private sales that did not require background checks, but this type of discharge would not come up in checks.

TRAVEL

Biden wants airlines to pay you back for travel headaches <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> New rules would give customers cash back for flight cancellations. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> Hannah Minn
Good news for weary travelers: The Biden administration is writing new rules that would require cash compensation for flyers when airlines are responsible for a cancellation or lengthy delay.

This will be a first for US-based airlines: Refunds for canceled flights are federally required, but no major carrier offers extra cash for the inconvenience. Only JetBlue and Alaska Airlines guarantee compensation beyond a refund of any kindâ€”and itâ€™s in the form of frequent flyer miles or vouchers.

Air travel complaints have quadrupled in recent years, with the majority coming from travelers trying to get refunds. And for good reason: Transportation Department figures attribute almost 80% of cancellations from the first half of 2022 to airline mismanagement like crew shortages, craft maintenance, or late-arriving planes. Those kinds of situations would warrant compensation in addition to a refund under the Biden administrationâ€™s planned rules <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gl?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933>.

Airlines would also be required to cover meals, transportation, and hotels during flight disruptions, which most (except Frontier) started doing voluntarily after last summerâ€™s nightmare travel season. Experts predict this summer could be even worse, but the new rules could take months or even years to implement.

Until thenâ€¦travelers can use the Transportation Departmentâ€™s newly expanded customer service dashboard <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gm?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> to see what each airline offers for delays or cancellations.â€”ML

TOGETHER WITH EXPRESS EMPLOYMENT PROFESSIONALS

FASHION

â€˜Quiet luxuryâ€™ is fashionâ€™s biggest trend <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gq?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> Kendall, Shiv, and Roman Roy in a scene from "Succession" <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gq?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> Claudette Barius/HBO
Succession has taken over the internet with its memes, crafty Machiavellian insults, and Kendall Roy obsessives. And now itâ€™s taking over your closet with â€œquiet luxury.â€

Thanks in part to the showâ€™s cashmere baseball caps <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gr?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933>, quiet luxury is surging: The term surpassed 35 billion views on TikTok.

What is it? Many in the fashion industry are defining quiet luxury much like the Supreme Court defined obscenity in 1964: You know it when you see it. Itâ€™s well-tailored clothing made from expensive fabrics in neutral colors and logo-freeâ€”think bespoke.

Why now? Seeing Succession characters as fashion inspo is part of it, but so is the looming possibility of a recession: Quiet luxury last had a resurgence in 2008. While the economy grapples with banking turmoil, Big Tech layoffs, and interest rate hikes, flashy stylesâ€”like a neon Balenciaga bodysuitâ€”are just not it. Instead, quiet luxury <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gs?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> insists on quality. According to brand research firm Edited, â€œQuiet luxury provides investment pieces with a year-round appeal that offers consumers a good cost-per-wear return.â€

Style trickles down: This Spring/Summer seasonâ€™s lines saw the use of premium materials, like pima cotton and merino wool, up 32% year over year, according to Edited, proving the impact of quiet luxury on the mass market. Expect to see more accessible retailers turn to elevated basics.â€”CC

Key performance indicators Spaghetti in the shape of a dollar sign Illustration: Francis Scialabba, Photo: Teine/Getty Images
Stat: While some people have so much pasta they just dump it in the woods of New Jersey, over in Italy, surging pasta prices are interfering with la dolce vita. The Italian government has scheduled crisis talks <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6gw?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31417769.2886933> for this Thursday to address the soaring cost of noodles, which jumped 17.5% year over year in March even as wheat prices fell. Inflation is high in Italy, but not that high: Overall consumer prices rose by 8.1% in the same month.

ENTERTAINMENT

Hollywood braces for writersâ€™ strike <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5V5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31331890.3294310> Snowy mountains fill the landscape behind the Hollywood sign. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5V5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31331890.3294310> Patrick T. Fallon / Getty Images
If production companies and unionized writers donâ€™t reach a new contract by midnight tonight, the scribes will put down their No. 2 pencils and strike <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5V6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31331890.3294310> for the first time in 15 years.

The stalemate reflects how streaming has upended TV and film, with writers feeling like they arenâ€™t seeing any of the plusses from the emergence of all the plusses.

Depending on how long the strike lasts (if it does happen), it could send Hollywood into a deep freeze: Series might go off the air, productions might get delayed, more reality shows would flood the airwaves, and the California economy could lose billions.

What are the writersâ€™ gripes?

They argue that Hollywoodâ€™s pivot to streaming worsened their working conditions and made it hard to earn a middle-class income as a writer. Hereâ€™s whyâ€¦

Shorter series: In the previous TV era, shows like How I Met Your Mother reliably churned out seasons with 20+ episodes. Now, streamers are prioritizing seasons with eight-to-12 episodes.

Residuals: Historically, if you had a writing credit on a TV show and that show was aired as a rerun, youâ€™d earn a royalty payment known as a residual. Streaming has disrupted that income stream.

Mini rooms: In the streaming age, writers often work in â€œmini roomsâ€ where they crank out scripts at low wages for shows that may or may not be made.

So, thereâ€™s a lot of frustration. Last month, 97.85% of eligible members of the Writers Guild of America, which represents most of the working writers in Hollywood, voted to authorize a strike <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5V7?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31331890.3294310> if an agreement with major studios wasnâ€™t reached. Thatâ€™s the most support for a work stoppage in the unionâ€™s history.

What happens if they strike? Studios have been stockpiling scripts ahead of the May 1 deadline, so scripted TV shows would continue for awhile. But late-night shows and other topical programs like SNL could be impacted almost immediately.

During the last strike, which lasted 100 days from 2007â€“2008, Conan Oâ€™Brien filled the airtime by seeing how long he could spin his wedding ring. More importantly, it cost the LA economy over $2 billion, according to the Milken Institute.

BANKING

The big get bigger: JPMorgan to acquire First Republic <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5VA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31331890.3294310> The big get bigger: JPMorgan to acquire First Republic <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5VA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31331890.3294310> The Washington Post/Getty Images
US financial regulators just executed the banking version of a house flip. Authorities seized <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5VB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31331890.3294310> First Republic Bank this morning and sold most of its assets to JPMorgan, the countryâ€™s largest bank.

First Republic Bankâ€™s collapse marks the second-biggest banking failure in US history, topping Silicon Valley Bankâ€™s collapse in March. Like SVB, First Republic is a midsized California-based lender with a specific client baseâ€”in this case, wealthy individualsâ€”that made it particularly exposed to the shockwaves of the recent banking turmoil.

First Republic tried to weather the storm itself, but after customers withdrew more than $100 billion in deposits in Q1 and its share price plunged nearly 75% last week alone, the government had to hang the â€œclosedâ€ sign on the door.

But by quickly finding a buyer over the weekend, the government avoided what it had to do for SVB: Protect deposits over the federally insured cap of $250,000. JPMorgan said it will assume First Republicâ€™s $92 billion in deposits, which is a welcome outcome since making SVB depositors whole cost the FDICâ€™s Deposit Insurance Fund about $20 billion.

Big picture: This government-brokered acquisition is just the latest in a series of bigger banks swallowing failing, smaller banks at a discount this spring. First Citizens collected the scraps of SVB, New York Community Bank snatched up assets of Signature Bank, and UBS absorbed crosstown rival Credit Suisse.

Â  SCIENCE

Â  Dept. of Progress Dexter from Dexter's lab saying Dexterâ€™s Laboratory/Warner Bros. Domestic Television via Giphy Here are some illuminating scientific discoveries from the week to help you live better and maybe even make your parrot feel less alone.

Polly wanna FaceTime? Parrots, for one species, donâ€™t think Zoom happy hours are cringe. A new study had parrot owners in the US teach their feathered pets to use tablets to make video calls. And just like humans in the early days of lockdown, the birds felt less lonely <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Sl?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362> when they could virtually hang out with one another. The parrots could choose who they wanted to ring, and the popular birds turned out to be the ones who initiated the most calls.

Hot off the press: stick-on vaccines. Researchers at MIT have created a new type of tabletop printer that spits out vaccine doses on demand in the form of thumbnail-size microneedle patches <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Sm?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362>. Once scaled, this mobile technology could produce hundreds of doses per day, revolutionizing pandemic response. And in a boon for warmer or more remote parts of the world, the vaccine patches can be stored at room temperature for months before theyâ€™re slapped onâ€”no refrigeration or professional administering required.

Itâ€™s official: AI will make you more productive at work. The first real-world study of AI in the workplace just concluded after more than a year, and it confirmed what tech enthusiasts already believed: Using AI tools can significantly boost <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Sn?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362> employee productivity and save managers dozens of hours each week. Customer service agents at a Fortune 500 software company got their work done 14% faster with the help of generative AI tools, and new hires who used AI rivaled workers with more than six months of experience.â€”ML

Â  NEWS ANALYSIS

Â  The hottest esport is...chess <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5So?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362> Man playing chess online <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5So?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362>goc/Getty Images What are the youths into these days? A centuries-old board game. Chess is the talk of recess but now, just like everything else, itâ€™s happening online.

At the center of the frenzy is Chess.com, a site where folks can face off against each other or play against a bot (like the insolent cat <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Sp?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362> Mittens). Itâ€™s seen an influx of players since 2020 when many turned to the game of kings as a way to avoid pandemic lockdown boredom.

The gameâ€™s popularity during Covid was helped along by the Netflix miniseries The Queenâ€™s Gambit, whose barrier-smashing, chess prodigy heroine inspired millions to play. But the latest chess boom is fueled not by Beth Harmon, but by influencers helping young people realize online chess can be just as fun as Minecraft and Fortnite.

Keeping chess in check at school

Schools nationwide are dealing with an epidemic of distracted kids sneakily playing matches <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5SY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362> on their phones during classes, according to the Washington Post. While some teachers have been confiscating phones, at least one teacher on Reddit said they are happy itâ€™s chess the kids are into and not Andrew Tate.

Maxim Dlugy, who runs a Manhattan chess school, told us his student body has increased more than threefold, from about 200 to 700 since the start of the pandemic.

And Chess.comâ€™s traffic has soared: The siteâ€™s servers crashed multiple times as its daily user count doubled from November 2022 to December 2022, and reached 12 million <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5SZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362> this month, according to Polygon.

The sport was likely helped along last year by a perfect hype storm created by Magnus Carlsen, the worldâ€™s No. 1 chess player, accusing an opponent of cheating in an in-person game, as well as a Louis Vuitton campaign in which Messi and Ronaldo faced off across a chess board. But the biggest boost came from a cadre of influencers working to win over teens.

* The top chess streamers on Twitch have over a million followers each who are eager to see them play and break down their moves.

* TikTok videos with #chess have been viewed 11.6 billion times.

Unlike in the chess heydays of the last century, one need not be a Bobby Fischer-level genius to achieve chess stardom now. Though some chess influencers are among the best players on the planet, many are merely decent and make up for their lack of big-league skill with charisma.

One of the most popular chess YouTubers, Levy Rozman, is a pro, but he lacks the grandmaster designation of top-tier players. That doesnâ€™t bother the 3.6 million followers who tune into his strategy tutorials and his breakdowns of the epic moments in famous chess matches played by others.

Embracing the esport

With the online game becoming dominant, the esport versions of rapid and blitz chess are increasingly getting professional buy-in. Carlsen said heâ€™s taking a break from in-person matches until at least 2024 and will be focusing on online chess tournaments. He recently sold a chess app to Chess.com and announced this week that heâ€™s starting a Fantasy Chess game (Carlsen is an elite fantasy soccer manager).

And the Champions Chess Tour, a series of online tournaments now hosted by Chess.com, features some of the biggest names in the sport, including Carlsen. The matches are time-limited to just a few minutes, similar to the ones amateurs play on Chess.com and influencers stream on Twitch.

The company hopes that the Champions Chess Tour will become the flagship event â€œfor all of chessâ€ in the future, a spokesperson for Chess.com told Morning Brew.

Looking aheadâ€¦some players like Carlsen and US champion Fabiano Caruana predict that hourslong IRL matches will get phased out as pro chess moves online and shorter games dominate.â€”SK

Â  DESTINATIONS

Â  Place to be: Westminster Abbey Westminster Abbey, London Tim Graham/Getty Images Itâ€™s a big world out there. In this section, weâ€™ll teleport you to an interesting locationâ€”and hopefully give you travel ideas in the process.

On Saturday, King Charles III, like every British monarch since 1066, will be coronated at Westminster Abbey in London.

What is this place? Itâ€™s undoubtedly the most important church <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5SC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362> for the British monarchy, having hosted dozens of royal coronations, weddings, funerals, and other important ceremonies over its nearly 1,000-year history. Westminster Abbey hasnâ€™t been the site of a coronation since Queen Elizabeth IIâ€™s in 1953, but it was the location of her funeral last year, Princess Dianaâ€™s funeral in 1997, and the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton in 2011.Â 

In addition to hosting royal pomp and circumstance, Westminster Abbey has a number of, er, permanent installations, such as the interred bodies of some of the most notable figures in British history. Legendary artists such as writer Geoffrey Chaucer and composer George Frideric Handel are buried in a section known as Poetsâ€™ Corner. Charles Dickens was buried there, too, though he didnâ€™t want to be <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5SD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362>.

If you do want to be there, youâ€™re probably into history, because Westminster Abbey is a great place to visit if you enjoy looking at really old things. Thereâ€™s an old chair <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5SE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362>, an old door <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5SF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362>, and, currently en route from Scotland, an old stone <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5SG?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31317641.3274362>. Westminster Abbey is typically open to the public, but itâ€™s closed April 25â€“May 8 for reasons.â€”NF

BUSINESS

Pour one out for First Republic <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5US?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> A First Republic bank branch <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5US?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> View Press/Getty Images
First Republic might be breathing its last breaths. Regulators are gearing up <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5UT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> to take over the beleaguered regional lender, just like they did the two banks that failed last month, Reuters reported yesterday.

Officials spent the past few days huddling with financial institutions to come up with an action plan to prevent First Republic from becoming the latest bank meltdown headline. But there appear to be no private banks willing to help it raise more cash.

Howâ€™d we get here?

The bank panic that led to the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank left First Republicâ€™s depositors worried about whether it could stay afloat. Like many regional banks, it invested depositor cash in assets that were devalued over the past year by rising interest rates.

First Republic got hit extra hard by the crisis because it successfully pursued wealthy clients in order to grow. But those same clients understood that, if the banking sectorâ€™s troubles seeped into First Republic, they wouldnâ€™t be made whole by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, as two-thirds of accounts at the bank had balances above the $250k insurance threshold.

Clients pulled more than $100 billion from their accounts in the first quarter of 2023, leaving First Republic with a 40% reduction in deposits.

Things calmed down after big banks including JPMorgan and Bank of America deposited $30 billion in the bank last month. Although this reassured customers, First Republic began to rack up interest fees on government rescue loans. And it reported dismal quarterly results this week.

Its stock has plummeted more than 70% since Monday, putting it at a 97% loss compared to the start of the year.

Looking aheadâ€¦if the bank fails, regulators will have some busy days ahead of them deciding whether to make First Republic depositors whole and assuring the public that the banking sector isnâ€™t in trouble.â€”SK

The Fed says itâ€™s time for new bank rules. Just in time for a new looming bank failure, the Federal Reserve issued a 102-page report dissecting the corpse of Silicon Valley Bank. The Fed pointed the finger at both its own inadequate supervision and the bankâ€™s management. And in an accompanying letter, Michael Barr, the Fedâ€™s vice chair for supervision, called for <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5UQ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> stricter rules to be applied to more financial institutions, as well as for more tools to be given to regulators to bring firms with poor capital planning and risk management into line.

North Carolina plays the reverse card on gerrymandering. The newly installed Republican majority on North Carolinaâ€™s Supreme Court took a look at the courtâ€™s recent precedents on voting rights and decided theyâ€™d rather go in a different direction <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5UR?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763>. In two separate decisions yesterday, the court tossed out an earlier ruling that rejected Republican-drawn election maps and reinstated a voter ID law that the prior court had nixed as racially biased. A third ruling denied voting rights to people with some felony convictions.

Can Jack Dorsey make Twitter 2.0? So far, none of the social media platforms hyped as the big thing for those looking to replace Elon Muskâ€™s Twitter have gained real traction, but the latest one, Bluesky, might have a bit of an edgeâ€”and not just because Chrissy Teigen has already joined. New stores will soon replace the Beyond <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Uq?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> Shopper peering into closed Bed Bath and Beyond <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Uq?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
In the wake of the companyâ€™s bankruptcy filing, Bed Bath & Beyond is closing all 360 of its locations (and all of its Buybuy Baby stores). But those giant, fluorescently lit buildings will be filled <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Ur?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> soon enough, as retail landlords are swimming in potential tenants.

Thereâ€™s a big-box space shortage: Vacancy rates for existing retail space hit 4.9% at the end of last year, which is at the lowest since 2005, when commercial real estate firm CBRE started tracking it. This and the meager new construction since 2008 means thereâ€™s simply not enough space for companies like HomeGoods to chaotically display ceramic dog statues and gaudy throw pillows.

With large retail spaces in short supply, discount outlets like TJ Maxx, Nordstrom Rack, Five Below, and even budget gym Planet Fitness are plotting to snatch up old BB&B locations, some even before the last toaster is sold.

Bottom line: The BB&B closures are a welcome influx of space. According to Coresight,Â  retailers opened more stores than they closed in 2022 for the first time since 2016.â€”MM
