ENVIRONMENT

No Shave November in Mayâ€¦but for lawns <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Uv?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> Homeowners participating in No Mow May let their grass grow all month. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Uv?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> Francis Scialabba
To mow or not to mow? That is the question homeowners are debating as more cities and towns embrace No Mow May, a movement started in 2019 to revitalize backyard wildlife by refraining from lawn care for an entire month.

And it works, sort of.

In past years, participants have watched their lawns transform from an â€œecological dead zoneâ€â€”as one professor calls the average American yardâ€”into a tall-grassed ecosystem rife with bumblebees, songbirds, chipmunks, and other forest friends...or foes. Last year, some Minnesotans called the police on snakes they spotted.

But some environmentalists say No Mow May <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Uw?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31321781.2899763> isnâ€™t the right way to bring biodiversity back to residential areas because it â€œteasesâ€ insects and other pollinators. Their newfound habitat goes away when homeowners bust out the lawnmowers on June 1.

Instead, experts encourage supporting local wildlife by seeding native plants and other pollinator-attracting greenery. The Guelph Turfgrass Institute suggests channeling the benefits of No Mow May during the other 11 months by sectioning off a part of the yard as a permanent â€œwildflower zone.â€â€”ML

Jerry Springer, â€˜ringmaster of civilizationâ€™s end,â€™ dies <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5OX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> Jerry Springer sitting at a desk <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5OX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> Roy Rochlin/Getty Images
Jerry Springer, the talk show host, politician, and king of mess who pushed the boundaries of television with his eponymous daytime talk show, died yesterday at 79. He leaves behind a legacy of norm-defying, provocative storytelling about people on the fringes of society that laid the foundation for the current reality TV landscape.

The Jerry Springer Show, which ran from 1991 to 2018, peaked in popularity in 1998, drawing 12 million viewers and surpassing Oprahâ€™s talk show in the ratings. That year, while Oprah was chatting with celebs like Madonna, Brad Pitt, and Tyra Banks, Springer interviewed three people in interspecies marriages.

Just how weird was The Jerry Springer Show? If you thought Dr. Philâ€™s â€œCash Me Outsideâ€ <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5OY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> episode was strangeâ€¦youâ€™d better sit down. Examples of guests Springer hosted include members of the KKK <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5OZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427>, adult babies <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5O-?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427>, a self-described kung fu hillbilly <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5O_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427>, and a number of folks who came clean about extramarital affairs while on the show.

Springer said <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5P0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> he only ever interviewed â€œregular folks, of no fame, little if any wealth, and very little influence,â€ and he faced many critics who said that in doing so, he profited off the exploitation of low-income people.

But Springer defended his approach. When asked in a 2014 BBC interview if he was ashamed of his show, he said, â€œYou could decide only to put well-scrubbed, wealthy people who speak the Queenâ€™s English on television and just do that, but that wouldnâ€™t reflect the whole society.â€

Springer was a busy guy

When he wasnâ€™t breaking up fights on daytime TV, Springer also:

Started as a politician. He was an advisor to Robert F. Kennedy, served as the mayor of Cincinnati from 1977â€“1978,Â and ran for Ohio governor in 1982. Luckily, he lost and pivoted to TV.

Inspired a musical. Jerry Springer: The Opera has been running on and off since 2001.

Appeared in a number of other productions, including The Rocky Horror Show on Broadway, Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5P1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427>, and most recently, The Masked Singer as a contestant.

Of course, for â€™90s kids, Springerâ€™s greatest role of all was keeping us company on sick days.â€”CC

Tour de headlines Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell Samuel Corum/Getty Images
Powell got punkâ€™d. In January, Fed Chair Jerome Powell had a phone call with a person he thought was Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyâ€¦but it was just a prank <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5P5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> by Russian tricksters, according to footage from Russian state television. Powell isnâ€™t the only victim of these pranksters; they also bamboozled their way to speak with former German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Prince Harry.

Cigarette smoking hits a record low in the US. Just 1 in 9 Americans smoked cigarettes last year, a record low <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5P6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427>, according to the CDC. Compared to the 1960s, when 42% of US adults smoked cigarettes, itâ€™s a dramatic drop that reflects greater awareness of the health risks of smoking, and economic hurdles like cigarette taxes. But Americans havenâ€™t given up their nicotine addiction entirely. Vaping rose to almost 6% last year, and 14% of teens reported using e-cigarettes in another CDC study.

QBs go No. 1 and No. 2 at the NFL draft. On the first night of the NFL draft, the Carolina Panthers selected <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5P7?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> Alabama quarterback Bryce Young as the first pick, and with the second pick, the Houston Texans drafted Ohio State signal-caller C.J. PHARMA

A new challenger emerges in the weight-loss drug race <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5P9?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> Eli Lilly manufactures Mounjaro and Trulicity, two antidiabetics with weight loss benefits. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5P9?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> Cristina Arias/Getty Images
Say buongiorno to Mounjaro.

The antidiabetic drug made by Eli Lilly that helps patients shed pounds could dethrone Wegovy (the weight-loss version of Ozempic) as the favorite among celebrities and wealthy people on a diet, according to new clinical trials.

The results reinforced previous findings that Mounjaro (generic name tirzepatide) can help diabetic and nondiabetic patients lose more weight than people did in past studies of Wegovy. But Mounjaro is currently only approved for diabetes, and prescribed patients could lose steady access to the drug.

Eli Lilly has already struggled through shortages of Mounjaro after a social-media-fueled demand for Ozempic seeped into the rest of the sector. And judging by how quickly Wegovy went to backorder after being officially approved for non-diabetes purposes, Mounjaro will likely also face a frenzy of weight-loss prescriptions that causes more shortages.

Once greenlighted for weight loss, Mounjaro is projected to become one of the highest-grossing drugs of all time with $50 billion in annual sales, driving the weight-loss/diabetes medication industry to what some estimate could be $150 billion per year. Wegovy and Ozempic raked in $10 billion last year for manufacturer Novo Nordisk.

The timeline: Eli Lilly expects the FDA to approve Mounjaro for weight loss <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Pa?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> soonâ€”perhaps by the end of the year. And the company is so confident in its potential â€œblockbusterâ€ drug that itâ€™s beginning an almost two-year trial this week to directly compare it against Novo Nordiskâ€™s Wegovy.â€”ML

The novel, published in 1970, remains the beloved authorâ€™s best-selling book, but even today,Â itâ€™s commonly banned around the country.

The story follows Margaret, an 11-year-old girl, as she navigates religion, periods, and toxic friendships in the New Jersey suburbs. Due to its frank discussion of menstruation and puberty, the book (and Blumeâ€™s other works) became a substitute of sorts for the sex ed many tweens never had in their classrooms.

Thatâ€™s also why the novel received pushback

Are You There God and some of Blumeâ€™s other 32 titles were challenged during the first significant wave of banning books from schools in the â€™80s. Sheâ€™s spoken out against book bans, but her work is still being pulled from libraries for its discussion of teen sexuality and other taboo topics.

Most recentlyâ€¦Blumeâ€™s book Forever was included on a list of 80 books from celebrated authors like Toni Morrison and James Patterson banned <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Pg?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31308756.3300427> last month by a Florida school district. Still, women are significantly underrepresented in the corner office: They account for 8% of S&P 500 CEO positions, compared to their 50.5% share of the US population.

The feud hinges on control of the special district where Disney World sits. Disney filed its suit almost immediately after the board, hand-picked by DeSantis to govern the district, voted to nullify land use agreements made by the previous Disney-controlled board.

From a spoonful of sugar to a 74-page lawsuit

The lawsuit also claims that the continued attacks on Disney by DeSantis and other Florida lawmakers are a direct result of the companyâ€™s expressed opinion on state legislation.

Historically, Florida has been known for being business-friendlyâ€”and Disney, which powers the stateâ€™s tourism economy, has benefited from that. Since 1967, the theme park has existed harmoniously with the greater Orlando area as a special tax district, allowing it to essentially act as its own county. But thatâ€™s precisely what DeSantis claims is the root of his conflict with the company, saying it has â€œgotten away with special deals from the State of Florida for way too long.â€

No one was counting on the Atlanta Hawks getting booted from the playoffs more than the folks who run the teamâ€™s stadiumâ€”and maybe Janet Jackson.

LAâ€™s Crypto.com Arena managed a 90-minute turnaround between Clippers and Lakers games last Saturdayâ€”sandwiched in the middle of the Kings NHL playoff games on Friday and Sunday. HOUSING

Why rent prices are so dang sticky <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5LZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31294555.2885093> Apartment buildings that look like graph going up to show rents rising <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5LZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31294555.2885093> Francis Scialabba
While egg prices have fallen dramatically and even Chipotle has paused price hikes on burrito bowls, one sector of the economy remains stubbornly expensive: rents.

In the latest consumer price index report, the shelter category (aka rents) was the largest contributor by far to overall inflation.

And despite moderating in recent months, rent growth remains 17% higher than 2021 levels.

So, why arenâ€™t rent prices falling like most other things in the economy? And what factors pushed rents so high in the first place?

We did some digging to find out. Learn whatâ€™s going on with rent prices here <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5LZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31294555.2885093>.

Markets: Even as many companies turned in bright earnings reports, stocks couldnâ€™t escape the shadow <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Im?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> cast by First Republic Bank. TECH

Generative AI joins the 2024 presidential race <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Io?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> Snowy mountains fill the landscape behind the Hollywood sign. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Io?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> Patrick T. Fallon / Getty Images
After President Biden announced his reelection bid yesterday morning, the Republican National Committee swiftly responded with an attack ad <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Ip?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>. The video asked the question â€œWhat if the weakest president weâ€™ve ever had were re-elected?â€ and thenâ€¦imagined the answer.

It had some help from artificial intelligence. The 30-second video used generative AI tools to create images and video of The Last of Us-looking scenes, including one where the army is occupying San Francisco because the city had supposedly been overtaken by crime and fentanyl. The RNC told Axios that itâ€™s the first video the organization has ever created completely using AI.

Get used to it

The video is likely just the start of a 2024 presidential race influenced by AI. While political campaigns have used AI tools to help canvass voters for years, recent breakthroughs in generative AI (like ChatGPT, Midjourney, and other programs) have taken the tech to a whole new level of realism.

And, if the past few months are any indication, powerful figures are among the most popular targets of AI-generated shenanigans.

Fake photos (fauxtos, if you will) of the pope swagged out in a giant white puffer coat and former President Trump being carried away by cops went viral due to their shocking realism.

Itâ€™s not just images: Fake audio <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Iq?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> of Biden and Trump slinging insults at each other while they play a video game made the rounds on TikTok and Instagram. Those two men could very well square off in the general election.

Not only has generative AI technology dramatically improved since the last election, but so has access to these programs. ChatGPT, for instance, became the fastest-growing consumer app in history after racking up 100 million users in just two months.

Experts say that since anyone with a computer and a wild imagination can use AI programs, misinformation could be churned out at rapid speed during this electionâ€”especially since social media companies have loose policies to keep AI-generated political content in check.

Counterpoint: Misinformation is already doing just fine without AI. Chris Meserole, a Brookings Institution fellow, told Fortune that â€œrecent presidential elections have already witnessed such high levels of human-written misinformationâ€ and expects the next election to look pretty similar to those of 2020 and 2016.

Plus, concerned citizens raised alarms during the 2020 presidential election that deepfakes would sow chaos and confuse voters. But thatâ€¦didnâ€™t end up happening <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Ir?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>.â€”MM

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Is?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5It?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Iu?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>

WORLD

Tour de headlines Spotlight on Microsoft and Google Francis Scialabba
Alphabet and Microsoft kept calm and carried on. The two tech giants posted earnings that showed theyâ€™re both on solid footing <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Iv?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>, despite investorsâ€™ concerns that growth would slow to a trickle. For Alphabet, Google Search advertising revenue grew again after a quarter in the red. And Microsoftâ€™s all-important cloud division posted better-than-expected sales. Both companies discussed how AI could impact for their businesses, but they differed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Iw?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> in their predictions: Microsoft characterized AI as a much more disruptive force than Google did.

Nate Silver will leave ABC News. The statistician and founder of FiveThirtyEight said that Disneyâ€™s recent layoffs had â€œsubstantially impacted <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Ix?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>â€ his website to the point where he expects to leave the company when his contract expires this summer. Silver became the data nerd du jour with his prescient forecasts for the 2008 and 2012 elections, and his statistics-focused site was acquired by ABC News in 2018. Silver becomes the latest media leader to seek new pastures this week.

RIP Harry Belafonte. The groundbreaking performer-turned-activist died <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Iy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> at his Manhattan home yesterday at 96. You probably know Belafonte best for his catchy-as-all-heck take on the Jamaican folk song, â€œDay-O (The Banana Boat Song)â€ released in 1956. But after achieving unprecedented commercial success for any musician at the time, especially a Black artist, Belafonte turned his attention to political activism and the fight for civil rights. Belafonte even put up bail for MLK and other civil rights activists to get them out of jail.

CONSUMER

Shoppers pay up for pricey Big Macs and burritos <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Iz?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> shut up and take my money! Futurama meme <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Iz?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> Disney/Futurama
Charge more, see what happens. Thatâ€™s exactly what many consumer-facing corporations including Chipotle and McDonaldâ€™s did in response to historic inflationâ€¦and itâ€™s worked out pretty great for them <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>, according to their earnings reports this week.

Chipotle increased prices and store traffic also increased <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>, the company said.

PepsiCo products were 16% pricier last quarter, but it sold only 2% less of them, resulting in a 10.2% sales bump.

Consumer giants Kimberly-Clark, NestlÃ©, and P&G raked in more revenue last quarter after they all jacked up prices by about 10%.

Higher sticker prices helped GM add almost $1,800 to its per-car profit in North America and grow its revenue.

But the good times wonâ€™t last. After more than a year of getting hammered by inflation, consumers are starting to resist paying farmers market prices at the grocery store. Pepsiâ€™s CFO said its customers have already been opting for cheaper products <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>, and the CEO of McDonaldâ€™s told the Financial Times that customers were starting to push back on the companyâ€™s beefier price tags.

Looking aheadâ€¦execs at companies like Coca-Cola say itâ€™s only a matter of time before theyâ€™ll have to stop increasing prices, or else risk losing customers. Chipotle already beat Coke to it, saying it had paused price hikes.â€”SK

HEALTH

Sleep gummies give you more Zzzs than you asked for <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> Sleep gummies give you more Zzzs than you asked for <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> Hannah Minn
Apparently, counting melatonin isnâ€™t as easy as counting sheep. A study released yesterday <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IG?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> showed that the labels on sleepy-time gummies frequently misrepresent the amount of melatonin they contain.

The study, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, found that 22 out of the 25 melatonin products tested by researchers had inaccurate labels that most often lowballed the amount of melatonin they contained. One product even had 347% of the stated amount of melatonin.

For an adult, extra melatonin usually just makes you feel like you had too many Vodka Red Bulls the night before. But for kids, higher levels of melatonin can cause health problems.

Between 2012 and 2021, the number of pediatric melatonin ingestions reported to poison control surged 530%, according to a CDC report <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IH?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385> last year. Of the 260,000+ incidents reported over that time, over 4,000 kids were hospitalized, five required mechanical ventilation, and two died.

Pediatricians warn that since melatonin is a hormone, even normal consumption on a regular basis can affect a childâ€™s development in puberty.

Big picture: Industry reps and the FDA agree that the dietary supplement marketplace needs a regulatory overhaul. Current US regulations do not require supplement-makers to conduct any clinical trials or obtain FDA approval before putting their products on the shelf. Meanwhile, in the EU, the UK, Canada, and others, melatonin requires a prescription.â€”CC

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5II?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IJ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5IK?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31283300.2878385>

MEDIA

A tale of 2 prime-time stars flaming out <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5EC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31269320.2886699> Tucker Carlson and Don Lemon <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5EC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31269320.2886699> Photo Illustration: Hannah Minn/ Photo: Getty Images
Yesterday was a big day for shake-ups in the cable news world: Fox News broke up with Tucker Carlson, and shortly after, CNN announced that they ousted Don Lemon. Both stars were major personalities for their networks.

Whatâ€™s behind all the moves? For Carlson, itâ€™s likely more about whatâ€™s been happening in the courtroom than on your TV.

Dominionâ€™s defamation lawsuit against Fox, which the network settled less than a week ago for $787.5 million, made Carlsonâ€™s private text messages publicâ€”including some that criticized Foxâ€™s senior leadership. Those messages played a role in his departure from Fox, per the Washington Post.

Plus, former Fox News producer Abby Grossberg filed a lawsuit last month accusing Carlson and his executive producer, Justin Wells, among others, of sexism and harassment. Wells was let go along with Carlson, and, according to the LA Times, Grossbergâ€™s lawsuit was the main factor in the decision, handed down by Rupert Murdoch, to fire Carlson.

Meanwhile, Lemon made headlines in February for saying that â€œa woman is considered to be in her prime in her 20s and 30s and maybe 40s,â€ and more recently had combative interviews with some guests. According to the New York Times, Lemonâ€™s future at CNN â€œhad become untenable.â€

The bottom line for networks

It appears that Carlson was worth over $500 millionâ€”thatâ€™s how much the Fox Corp.â€™s market value dropped after his ousting made news. Itâ€™s not entirely surprising: Tucker Carlson Tonight was as synonymous with Fox as Law & Order is to NBC. It has been one of the top shows on cable news and regularly drew more than 3 million nightly viewers.

For CNN, firing Lemon, who had been at the network for 17 years, is one of many recent moves in programming as the network tries to catch up with its competitors. As cable news viewership continues to decrease, all the major networks are launching new shows and overhauling programming to try to recapture the ratings glory days of 2015.â€”CC

TOGETHER WITH MONOGRAM

Tour de headlines Aaron Rodgers
Aaron Rodgers traded to the NY Jets, ESPN reports. After 18 seasons with the Green Bay Packers, the four-time MVP quarterback is headed to NYC <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Eg?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31269320.2886699> in a long-anticipated trade. Rodgersâ€™s move from Green Bay to New York near the end of his career is reminiscient of Brett Favreâ€™s trade to the Jets 15 years ago, which allowed a young Rodgers to take the reins at Lambeau Field.

First Republic Bank lost $102 billion in deposits last month. Thatâ€™s not good. The regional lender that got swept up in Marchâ€™s bank turmoil said that deposits plunged nearly 41% <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Eh?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31269320.2886699> last quarter, and they would have fallen by more than 50% if 11 large banks hadnâ€™t plugged it with $30 billion to shore up confidence. The bankâ€™s stock, already down 87% this year, dropped by another ~18% after it released its results.

Apple triumphs in Epic app store dispute, again. An appeals court upheld <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5Ei?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31269320.2886699> Appleâ€™s victory in Fortnite-maker Epic Gamesâ€™s antitrust lawsuit over Appleâ€™s App Store fees.   TOGETHER WITH

Masterworks <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5us?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550&lp=logo>  
Good morning. What do very happy people in common? The Wall Street Journal called up the 12% of respondents in a WSJ-NORC survey <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> who called themselves â€œvery happyâ€Â  and asked them what they were all about. Here are the traits they share.

Companionship: 67% of the happiest people said that marriage was very important to them, compared to 43% of overall respondents.

Religion: Two-thirds of very happy people characterized themselves as moderately or very religious. The overall share: less than half.

Closer to death: People 60 and over accounted for 44% of the happiest group, but represented 30% of total survey respondents.

Gym rats: Fitness was a common interest among very happy people.

What doesnâ€™t seem to matter to being very happy? Political party affiliation or avoiding following politics.

â€”Neal Freyman

RETAIL

Bed Bath & Bankrupt <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5ze?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> Store closing sale announcement at a Bed Bath & Beyond indoor mall in northern Idaho <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5ze?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> Don & Melinda Crawford/UCG/Universal Images Group via Getty Images
You have two days left to remember where you hoarded your 20%-off Bed Bath & Beyond coupons and redeem them. After limping along in poor financial health for years, the retailer filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zf?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> on Sunday and said it would stop accepting its famous coupons on Wednesday.

Bed Bath & Beyond coupons are getting scrapped, and so are the stores that accept them. As part of its bankruptcy and liquidation, the company said it plans to close all of its 360 BB&B locations and its 120 Buybuy Baby stores by June 30â€”if a last-minute buyer doesnâ€™t rescue it from going out of business.

A bad bet on private labels

You canâ€™t blame this business failure on â€œeconomic uncertainty.â€ Numerous bad decisions by Bed Bath & Beyond management led to the chainâ€™s demise, but the worst own-goal of all was its pivot to private-label products, or items that were made exclusively for Bed Bath & Beyond.

This effort was led by Mark Tritton, a former Target exec who was installed by activist investors in 2019. Tritton worked private-label magic at Target, releasing dozens of highly profitable Target-only lines that offered a promising roadmap <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zg?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> for other retailers to follow.

But when Tritton tried to replicate his Target success at Bed Bath & Beyond, that strategy broke down like a cheap blender. In certain categories like kitchen appliances, brands matter, and shoppers stopped showing up to Bed Bath & Beyond after it swapped out KitchenAid mixers and OXO garlic mincers for its own stuff.

What happens next? A massive going-out-of-business sale <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zh?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> matched only by Toys R Us and Circuit City in the last 15 years, Axios notes.

Plus, if youâ€™re one of the many individual investors who piled into Bed Bath & Beyond when it was a trendy meme stock last year, youâ€™ll need to take your medicine and move on. In bankruptcy proceedings, debtholders get prioritized over shareholders, so meme-stock traders will be left holding the bag.

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zi?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zj?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550>  

TOGETHER WITH MASTERWORKS

Investors earn 325% annualized return here (really) <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5us?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550&lp=title> Masterworks <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5us?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550&lp=image>
While the ultra-rich have been banking off this under-the-radar asset for centuries, a group of everyday investors just used it to rake in a whopping 325% annualized gain.

Sounds totally ridiculous? It definitely does. But itâ€™s also 100% true.

The asset was a sculpture offered by the fractional art investment platform Masterworks. After just 36 days, investors profited a 15.4% net gainâ€”a triple-digit return on an annualized basis.

While itâ€™s not common for Masterworks to get a profitable exit that fast, every one of their 13 exits has returned a profit to investors, totaling more than $35 million in payouts.

Foreign governments evacuate diplomats from Sudan. The US, the UK, and other countries airlifted diplomats <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zl?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> and other citizens out of Sudan over the weekend as fighting continued to rage between two rival generals over control of the African country. The situation is getting dire <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zm?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> for Sudanese people caught in the crossfire: More than 420 people have been killed; food, water, and electricity are getting scarce; and internet and phone service suffered a â€œnear-total collapseâ€ yesterday, according to NetBlocks, a monitoring service.

NBC boss gets the boot. Jeff Shell, CEO of NBCUniversal, is leaving the company <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zn?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> for â€œinappropriate conduct,â€ parent company Comcast said. In a joint statement, Shell acknowledged â€œan inappropriate relationship with a woman in the company, which I deeply regret.â€ Shell was one of the most powerful figures in media, overseeing everything from Universal theme parks to NBC News and Bravo. He joins a list of other media execs, including CNNâ€™s Jeff Zucker, who have stepped down over inappropriate relationships at work.

Dead celebrities get blue checkmarks on Twitter. Prominent people who are deceased, such as Chadwick Boseman, Barbara Walters, and Anthony Bourdain, have received a verification badge <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zo?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> on Twitter thatâ€™s now reserved for accounts that pay $8/month for a subscription to Twitter Blue. A note from the company on their pages states that these celebs have paid for the subscription, even though they areâ€¦not alive. Twitter has also restored blue check marks <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zp?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> to many other living celebrities who arenâ€™t paying for Twitter Blue, either. So, what this all amounts to, seemingly, is that CEO Elon Musk is partially recreating the verification system he made a big deal of destroying.

MARKETING

Bud Light makes changes after calls for boycott <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zq?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> @dylanmulvaney Instagram, a sponsored post for Bud Light <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zq?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> @dylanmulvaney/Instagram
Bud Lightâ€™s VP of marketing, Alissa Heinerscheid, and her boss, Daniel Blake, were placed on leave <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zr?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> following conservative backlash to a recent campaign with transgender influencer Dylan Mulvaney.

Since she became the first woman ever to lead Bud Lightâ€™s marketing last June, Heinerscheid set out to revive the declining brand by appealing to women and younger people. Those efforts included a partnership <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5zs?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31257551.3215550> with Dylan Mulvaney, a transgender influencer who promoted Bud Lightâ€™s March Madness giveaway on April 1 with a personalized can sheâ€™d been sent by the company.

This partnership did not sit well with many conservatives, who attacked Bud Light for being another corporation that went â€œwokeâ€ by prioritizing inclusivity. Kid Rock filmed himself shooting 12-packs of Bud Light, and other conservatives used social media to urge a boycott of the brand.

Whatâ€™s Bud Lightâ€™s response been? Last week, the CEO of parent Anheuser-Busch released a non-statement statement, writing, â€œWe never intended to be part of a discussion that divides people.â€ And yesterdayâ€™s shake-up shows itâ€™s not happy with how the Mulvaney campaign went down. Along with sidelining the two execs, itâ€™s changing its marketing departmentâ€™s structure so that senior employees have more visibility â€‹â€‹into all decisions.

The boycott appears to be having some effect on business. According to Beer Business Daily, Bud Light sales fell 10.7% the weekend ended April 8, while rival Molson Coors appears to have gotten at least a short-term lift.

Spark <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5vE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751&lp=logo> 
Good morning and Happy Earth Day. A lot had to go right for us to be living here.

First: location, location, location. Earth is located in a remote corner of the Milky Way. And while that means we have to Uber everywhere, it also means fewer threats like a huge star devouring us with its gravity. The star we do have nearby, the sun, is pretty stable and the perfect distance away to sustain liquid water (important!). And when the sun sends deadly flares our way, weâ€™re safe because the Earthâ€™s core produces a magnetic field that deflects radiation.

The Earth also contains critical elements like oxygen and carbon, its atmosphere traps heat (but not too much), its neighbor/protector Jupiter deflects asteroids and comets from smashing into it, its moon stabilizes the climate, and its active plate tectonic system produces volcanoes, whose eruptions may have led to the first instances of life.

Plus, itâ€™s the only planet in the galaxy where you can get a good gyro.

â€”Abby Rubenstein, Molly Liebergall, Matty Merritt, Cassandra Cassidy, Neal Freyman

HEALTH

SCOTUS upholds access to abortion pillsâ€¦for now <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> Image of mifepristone <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images
In its first major ruling on abortion since overturning Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court handed down a 7â€“2 decision <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> yesterday allowing mifepristone to remain widely available while the legal battle over the FDAâ€™s two-decade-old approval of the abortion medication rages.

And itâ€™s going to rage: The matter reached the Supreme Court after a federal judge in Texas yanked the FDAâ€™s approval of the drug. That ruling would have blocked nationwide access to the medication, spooking pharmaceutical companies <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> by raising the possibility that any drug approval could be nixed later. The government quickly appealed to the conservative-leaning 5th US Circuit Court of Appeals, which rejected parts of the judgeâ€™s decision but still imposed restrictions on the medicineâ€™s availability.

Meanwhile, the same day the Texas ruling came out, a Washington federal judge ordered the FDA not to restrict access to the pill in 17 states.

Plus, a generic drugmaker subsequently sued to keep its version of the pill on the market regardless of the Texas ruling.

The Supreme Courtâ€™s decision means the status quo will be maintained while that all gets sorted out.

But with the case all but guaranteed to end up back at the high court for a final say eventually, what it doesnâ€™t do is tell us much about what the justices will ultimately decide when it gets there.

Why not? Because the brief, unsigned order came in response to an emergency petition, making it part of the courtâ€™s so-called shadow docket, where decisions get made quickly and without the benefit of oral arguments. Also, itâ€™s pretty standard to block changes from taking place while appeals wind their way through the courts.

But there were a few hints: Both Justice Alito and Justice Thomas dissented from the order, saying they would have permitted the restrictions on the drug to take effect.

What comes next? The case is scheduled to pick back up with oral arguments at the 5th Circuit on May 17.â€”AR

Tour de headlines Tweets by an imposter NYC government Twitter
Chaos on the bird app. Impostor accounts sprang up <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yz?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> on Twitter yesterday following the removal of legacy blue checks for brands and public, media, and government figures not willing to pay for a subscription. In one example, a fake account with a paid-for blue check posing as a Sudanese paramilitary sent a tweet that got millions of views, which falsely said that its leader had been killed in the conflict there. Elsewhere on Twitter: All labels calling accounts â€œgovernment-funded mediaâ€ were removed (not just the recent controversial ones).

NFLâ€™s biggest gambling crackdown. Itâ€™s not just the ponies getting people in trouble these days: The NFL suspended <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> five players, four of whom play for the Detroit Lions, for violating the leagueâ€™s sports betting policy. Players are not allowed to bet on any NFL-related games or events, but can bet on non-NFL games as long as they arenâ€™t on NFL turf. Three of the players, Quintez Cephus and C.J. Moore of the Lions and Shaka Toney of the Washington Commanders, were suspended indefinitely (through 2023 at least). Jameson Williams and Stanley Berryhill got shorter, six-game suspensions.

Alphabetâ€™s CEO is getting paid. Amid layoffs and reports of cutbacks on perks that include even scaling back the number of employee staplers, not everyone at Googleâ€™s parent companyÂ  will have to tighten their belt: CEO Sundar Pichaiâ€™s pay <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z9?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> rose $226 million last year. HOUSING

Gen Z is winning the housing market race <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> Hand wearing "slay" bracelet holding house. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> Francis Scialabba
Parents will have to go back to criticizing their kids for excessive screen time or killing golf, because not owning a home is no longer an accurate roast. A new report from Redfin found that 30% of Gen Zers age 19â€“25 owned <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> their own homes as of last yearâ€”which is higher than the 27% of Gen Xers and 28% of millennials that did at the same age.

Before all you 30-something renters freak out, most young homebuyers bought in cheap areas and jumped on low interest rates.

Gen Zâ€™s favorite place to buy a house? Virginia Beach, VA, where they accounted for 9% of all home purchases last year. The median house sale price for a Gen Z buyer in the area was $255,000 in 2022â€¦$199,525 less than theÂ  average median sale price in the US last year, according to the St. Louis Fed.

It also comes down to timing. Gen Zers entered a tight labor market with high wages, while millennials had to wade through the fallout of the 2008 recession before they were able to establish themselves financially.

Looking aheadâ€¦with interest rate hikes pushing mortgage rates past 6% this year and supply tightening, Gen Zers may not keep up their homebuying pace.â€”MM

CLIMATE

After the big chill, California braces for a big melt <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> Snowy mountains fill the landscape behind the Hollywood sign. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> Patrick T. Fallon / Getty Images
Californiaâ€™s historic snowfall this year helped pull the state out of a drought and blessed our feeds with photos of snowy palm trees...but now itâ€™s starting to melt, setting up a summer of flooding.

Officials warn that warmer temperatures will cause the massive snowpack <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> atop the Sierra Nevadas to overflow reservoirs, spilling into lakes and valleys that are already buckling under last monthâ€™s storms. To give you an idea of just how much melted snow thereâ€™ll be, itâ€™s enough to submerge 30 million football fields under a foot of water.

Whereâ€™s all that water going?

The biggest threat is to downstream communities to the west of the Sierra Nevadas, and in some valleys to the east.

Californiaâ€™s San Joaquin Valley stands to suffer most from impending floods, which could last through the year.

The mountainside counties of Fresno, Kings, and Tulareâ€“which has a recently revived lake <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5y-?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> thatâ€™s already damaged hundreds of buildingsâ€“are under a flood warning until further notice.

It wonâ€™t happen all at once: Temps these next few days are forecast to hit the 80s, causing some melt, but the true danger will be 90-degree June days.

Big picture: With an estimated 98% of the snowpack still up there, Central Californians are bracing for a very wet year <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5y_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> that could cost billions in infrastructure and agricultural damages.â€”ML

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751>Â Â  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5z2?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751>

GRAB BAG

Key performance indicators A soda can with a dollar sign for the tab Hannah Minn
Stat: Even a penny can make a big difference. After Oakland, California, slapped sugary drinks with a one-cent-per-ounce tax in 2017, local sales of sweetened beverages, including soda, fruit and sports drinks, and sweetened teas, dropped <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5yG?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31247888.2901751> nearly 27%, research released this week shows. Public health experts behind the study say that it proves even a little tax pain might help you kick your daily Mountain Dew habit.

Quote: â€œOf course, we respect local restrictions around the word â€˜champagne,â€™ but we remain proud of Miller High Life, its nickname and its Milwaukee, Wisconsin, provenance.â€

Itâ€™s only champagne if it comes from the Champagne region of France; otherwise itâ€™s just sparkling wineâ€”or in this case lager. Making awkward eye contact with coworkers in the bathroom mirror is back, because more companies are asking employees to return to the office. But with many businesses trying to accommodate a hybrid workforce, companies are getting creative with their offices to avoid wasting money.

One increasingly popular solution: Get some corporate roommates by subleasing part or all of their office space to other companies.

ETHICS

Clarence Thomasâ€™s free vacations could be costly <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UUQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D5271d567> Clarence Thomas in front of a vacation background <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UUQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E5271d567> Illustration: Hannah Minn/Photo: Getty
When your billionaire friend invites you on their yacht for an island-hopping adventure, you reply, â€œomw.â€

Well, unless youâ€™re a Supreme Court justiceâ€”then you might want to think twice.

Clarence Thomas apparently didnâ€™t get the memo because, according to a bombshell ProPublica report <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UUU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C9b343d70> published yesterday, the conservative Supreme Court justice has been whisked around on luxury vacations for 20+ years by the Dallas-based real estate mogul and GOP megadonor Harlan Crow. These gifted vacations, which Thomas didnâ€™t disclose, have alarmed ethics watchdogs and spurred calls by senators to create a binding ethics code for Supreme Court justices.

Currently, the SCOTUS justices are the only federal judges <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UUY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7353fdf1> who arenâ€™t officially tied to a code of conduct, according to Bloomberg. However, they are required to report when they travel on a private jet (which Thomas did with Crow) and stay at commercial properties like resorts. Since Thomas didnâ€™t disclose these gifts, ethics experts told ProPublica that he appears to have violated the law.

Got my toes in the waterâ€¦

What were these luxury vacations Thomas took on Crowâ€™s dime? Some includeâ€¦

Nine days on a megayacht in Indonesia, a trip that would have cost Thomas and his wife $500,000+ had they paid for it themselves, ProPublica wrote.

Summer stays at Crowâ€™s estate in the Adirondacks, Camp Topridge, where Thomas reportedly came into contact with execs at Verizon and PwC, as well as big GOP donors.

In a statement to ProPublica, Crow said that Thomas never asked to be taken on vacations, and his invites were â€œno different from the hospitality we have extended to our many other dear friends.â€

But a SCOTUS justice is not like Crowâ€™s other friends, in that they are expected to avoid any appearance of outside influence in order to maintain public trust in the institution. The revelation that Thomas accepted secret gifts from the ultrawealthy shows that he â€œseems to have completely disregarded his higher ethical obligations,â€ former government ethics lawyer Virginia Canter told ProPublica.â€”NF

WORK

McDonaldâ€™s remote layoffs might be the future <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UUs_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dcfeb80c2> McDonald's sign <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UUs_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ecfeb80c2> Celal Gunes/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
When McDonaldâ€™s cut hundreds of corporate jobs this week, it utilized a pandemic trend thatâ€™s still going strong: remote layoffs. The fast-food giant closed <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UUw_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C0ee558cb> corporate offices Mondayâ€“Wednesday to remotely lay off a slice of its 45,000 US (and some international) white-collar workers.

Telling an employee their position has been eliminated in front of a blurred Zoom background has gotten a lot more common since waves of corporate workers ditched their offices at the onset of the pandemic. But in turning to remote layoffs, some companies have made an awful situation even awful-er:

When Twitter closed its offices to cut nearly 3,700 staffers in November, some employees reported losing access to work emails and Slack in the middle of the night prior to receiving an emailed pink slip.

Googleâ€™s parent company, Alphabet, chaotically laid off <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31092873.2913513/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80UU0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA5Mjg3My4yOTEzNTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb791de66> 6% of its staff in January via email.

Better.comâ€™s CEO infamously laid off 900 employees in a virtual town hall in December 2021.

HR experts have mixed feelings. Some argue that finding out the bad news in the comfort of your home is a better alternative to packing up your office plants while catching coworker side-eyes. Plus, why drag someone into the office only to send them back home? But others say email and Zoom are impersonal and relieve managers of taking responsibility for layoffs.

Friday puzzle

There is only one number that, when spelled out, has its letters in alphabetical order.

Can you name it?

MEDIA

Twitter labels NPR â€˜state-affiliated mediaâ€™ <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TWo_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dd5cf748b> NPR building <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TWo_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ed5cf748b> Saul Loeb/Getty Images
NPR, which usually plays the role of soft-spoken sidekick, was the main character of yesterdayâ€™s Twitter drama. The social media platform put a â€œUS state-affiliated media <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TWs_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Caf2f04c8>â€ tag on NPRâ€™s account, a loaded label that suggests itâ€™s an accessory to the US government.

Some background: Twitter started using the label in the pre-Elon Musk days of 2020 for transparency, defining state-affiliated media as â€œoutlets where the state exercises control over editorial content.â€ Up until Tuesday night, its policy explicitly said that state-funded media operating with editorial independence, like the BBC andâ€¦NPR did not fall into the category. But, like a newly dumped ex cleansing their grid, Twitter seems to have deleted all mentions of NPR from the policy.

Why now? Twitter, which has no PR department, hasnâ€™t said why it started lumping NPR in with news sites notorious for spreading government propaganda, like China Daily and Russia Today. But Musk tweeted, â€œSeems accurateâ€ in response to a tweet about the new label.

Whatever Twitterâ€™s reasons, NPRâ€™s chief communications officer told <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TWw_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7877b21f> the NYT that less than 1% of the orgâ€™s yearly operating budget comes from government-funded grants. Most of the organizationâ€™s funding comes from individual and business donations. Other media orgs that receive substantial government funding, like Voice of America and the US military newspaper Stars and Stripes, donâ€™t have the label, the Washington Post noted.

The labelâ€™s addition not only suggests to the NPR accountâ€™s 8.8 million Twitter followers (and anyone who views it) that its reporting is less than credible, but it also means NPR will not be amplified via Twitterâ€™s recommendation algorithm.

This is part of a pattern for Muskâ€™s Twitter: The site recently took away the main New York Times accountâ€™s verification badge while leaving them on for other news outlets after the Times said it wouldnâ€™t pay for the blue check. And several reporters who criticized Musk had their accounts suspended last year.â€”MM

â€œOperation Cookie Monsterâ€ is less fun than it sounds. Itâ€™s the code name for a coordinated, international law enforcement effort in which the FBI and other authorities seized <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TUs_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1210b346> Genesis Market, a notorious online marketplace for stolen login credentials. FOOD & BEV

The burrito bowl battle is on <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TXE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Da2a7e480> Sweetgreen's Chipotle Burrito Bowl <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TXE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ea2a7e480> Business Wire
When it comes to burrito bowls named after a smoke-dried jalapeno pepper, fast-casual chain Chipotle believes Highlander-style there can only be one. Just in time for todayâ€™s National Burrito Day promotion, the Mexican grill slapped its rival for lunchtime supremacy, Sweetgreen, with a trademark lawsuit <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TXI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C5a4d8ad6> over the salad spotâ€™s new â€œChipotle Chicken Burrito Bowl.â€

The suit, filed in California federal court Tuesday, claims Sweetgreen is trying to take advantage of customer goodwill toward the Chipotle brand. It further maintains that Sweetgreen has advertised the new bowl using the word â€œChipotleâ€ in the font and style used for Chipotleâ€™s logo and deployed an ad background color similar to the brandâ€™s trademarked Adobo Red hue.

In a press release introducing the new menu item last week, Sweetgreen said it was named for the â€œthoughtfully-sourced chipotle powder that provides the perfect slightly spicy, smokey bite.â€ But Chipotleâ€™s legal complaint asserts that industry publicationsâ€”and even Sweetgreenâ€™s own social media commentsâ€”have noted the similarity to Chipotleâ€™s offerings.

Big picture: News of the lawsuit sent Sweetgreenâ€™s stock plunging yesterday. It ended the day down 6.26%â€”another setback for the salad-maker, whose shares are down ~20% in 2023 so far as it struggles to turn a profit. Chipotle, meanwhile, has seen its stock surge 24% this year thanks to strong sales.â€”AR

TECH

Harry Potter, but use AI to make it Balenciaga <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TXY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Df95cbff6> Harry Potter Balenciaga characters <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TXY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ef95cbff6> Illustration: Francis Scialabba, Source: demonflyingfox/Youtube
Artificial intelligence is being used to create Balenciaga-fied versions of movies and TV showsâ€”a lucky hit of positive publicity for the high-fashion brand that was wrapped up in scandals last year.

A timeline for those of you out touching grass:

YouTube channel demonflyingfox posted â€œHarry Potter by Balenciaga <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80bkQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2B830bae07>â€ three weeks ago (it now has over four million views), and itâ€”along with a similar channel called Abandoned Films <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80TXc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2B04067436> that started posting content at the same time â€”has since continued posting Balenciaga crossovers, including for Star Wars and Lord of the Rings.

And about two weeks ago, an AI-generated photo of Pope Francis <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31079355.2922000/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Qlk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA3OTM1NS4yOTIyMDAw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cafae9623> in a Balenciaga coat went mega-viral on Twitter after first being posted on Reddit and Facebook.

How do they do it? By using AI image generators such as Midjourney and AI voice generators like Eleven Labsâ€”which Abandoned Films tagged in the LOTR video where a snatched Boromir says, â€œOne does not simply walk into a Balenciaga fashion show.â€

Trump pleads not guilty to 34 felony counts <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SUw_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D89306940> Trump in court <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SUw_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E89306940> Pool/Getty Images
In a historic day for the US, a former president appeared as a criminal defendant in a courtroom.

Donald Trump was charged <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SU0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3f5ade81> with 34 felony counts of falsifying business records at his arraignment at the Manhattan Criminal Court. He pleaded not guilty to each of them.

Breaking down the criminal case against Trump

We knew that Trump was indicted but not the specific charges against him, which were kept under sealâ€¦until yesterday. Hereâ€™s what we learned from the 16-page indictment:

The case is extremely complex. But at its core, Trump is accused of falsely labeling business records in order to get around campaign finance laws. And both those points are key, because for the charges to rise from a misdemeanor to a felony, prosecutors have to show that the defendant falsified business records with the intent of committing or concealing a separate crime.

So, what was Trump trying to conceal? According to prosecutors, reimbursement for a $130,000 payment Trumpâ€™s former lawyer, Michael Cohen, sent to adult film actress Stormy Daniels in exchange for silence about her alleged affair with Trump. The payment took place in the final days of his 2016 presidential bid, and Trumpâ€™s company falsely classified the series of transactions used to reimburse Cohen as legal expenses.

Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg, the architect of the case, has gotten heat from Republicans and (more quietly) some Democrats for bringing a case that possibly relies on an untested legal theory. In response, Bragg emphasized the importance of prosecuting the alleged business fraud due to New Yorkâ€™s status as a global center of commerce.

Next steps

Trumpâ€™s lightning-quick NYC trip concluded without taking in a Broadway show or $0.99 pizza slice: He was back in Florida by the evening to give a speech at his Mar-a-Lago estate, where he accused Democrats of using law enforcement to intefere with elections. Trump, portraying himself as a victim of a liberal â€œwitch hunt,â€ has already used his arraignment as a fundraising opportunity for his presidential campaign by selling â€œnot-guiltyâ€ T-shirts <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SU4_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Caaaf0e7c> that feature a fake mug shot (no mug shot was taken today).

Looking ahead...Trumpâ€™s legal team will use various tactics <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SU8_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cea9ff62c> to get this case thrown out before it even goes to trial. If it does goes to trial, thatâ€™s months away at the earliest.â€”SK, NF

Tour de headlines Illustration of Wisconsin court house Francis Scialabba
Wisconsinâ€™s Supreme Court turns blue after pricey election. Liberal Judge Janet Protasiewicz defeated <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SVM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C09e75a4b> her conservative opponent in the most expensive judicial election in US history (more than $40 million was spent on the contest). Why so much attention? The stateâ€™s Supreme Court, now 4â€“3 in favor of progressives, will likely overturn Wisconsinâ€™s abortion ban and strike down GOP-drawn legislative maps that Protasiewicz has called â€œrigged.â€ In the other big Midwestern election yesterday, Chicago residents chose Brandon Johnson <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SVQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cbc8893f5> as their next mayor.

Johnson & Johnson proposes monster $8.9 billion talc settlement. The healthcare giant offered $8.9 billion <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31068001.3360432/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80SVU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA2ODAwMS4zMzYwNDMy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3ac67a38> to settle lawsuits from tens of thousands of people who claim that its talc-based powders and other products gave them cancer. GOVERNMENT

Trump heads to the courthouse <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rnk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D347e4c84> Donald Trump <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rnk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E347e4c84> Eva Marie Uzcategui/Getty Images
In a first for presidential history, Donald Trump will be charged with a crime today. The former president flew into his hometown, New York City, yesterday and is set to appear <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rno_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb955e543> at the criminal courthouse in lower Manhattan to plead â€œnot guiltyâ€ this afternoon.

What will go down today

Todayâ€™s courthouse visit is expected to be a short one: Trump will likely be released without bail soon after heâ€™s arraigned.

The charges against him, which are currently in a sealed indictment, will be read at the arraignmentâ€”but we already know the prosecutor was investigating hush money paid to adult film actress Stormy Daniels in the final days of Trumpâ€™s 2016 presidential run. Then heâ€™ll enter a â€œnot guiltyâ€ plea, according to his attorney.

Before the arraignment, the former president will be fingerprinted and possibly photographed for a mug shot, per the usual protocol. Mug shots arenâ€™t released publicly in New York, and itâ€™s unlikely that Trump will be handcuffed and perp-walked in front of the media, to the disappointment of NYC photojournalists.

But he wonâ€™t hide from the cameras: Trump plans to hold a press conference in the evening after he returns to his Florida estate, Mar-a-Lago.

Some media outlets asked for permission to bring cameras into the courtroom, an exception to the rules that Trumpâ€™s lawyers say would create a â€œcircus-like atmosphereâ€ if granted.

Exactly the atmosphere the Big Apple is gearing up for

Authorities barricaded the courthouse and Trump Tower (where the ex-POTUS crashed for the night) in anticipation of Trump supporter protests and his criticsâ€™ counterprotests.

The Artemis II flight test, scheduled for 2024, will ferry its four-person crew to the moon, make a pass close to its surface, and bring them back to Earth over the span of about ten days. Itâ€™s part two of a three-part mission to land astronauts on the moonâ€™s surface in 2025â€”the first time since Neil Armstrongâ€™s day. Part one was a success last year, when an unmanned spacecraft orbited the moon.

So, whoâ€™s going to space?

The four lucky Sailor Moons are: Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Hammock Koch, and Jeremy Hansen. The crew includes the first woman, the first person of color, and the first Canadian to ever go on a lunar mission.

Why one Canadian? Hansenâ€™s spot on the Artemis II mission cost the Canadian Space Agency an arm and aâ€”well, actually just an arm. In 2020, the CSA sealed the deal <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rkg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1960a672> by agreeing to give NASA a robotic arm the agency needed for its small, moon-orbiting space station.

MUSIC

Apple joins the Wolf Gang <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rk0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Da85a0aac> Mozart in Amadeus movie <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rk0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ea85a0aac> Amadeus/Orion Pictures
In its latest push into audio, Apple launched a dedicated app for classical music last week. And classical music snobsâ€¦actually like it <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rk4_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C368ac499>.

Hereâ€™s why: The app, called Apple Music Classical, lets you find the classical music you want to listen to. While that doesnâ€™t sound earth-shattering, it is a huge deal, because searching for classical music on services like Spotify was worse than using Bing pre-ChatGPT.

The issue is classical musicâ€™s metadataâ€”how itâ€™s labeled and categorized.

Streaming apps are optimized for pop songs that have limited metadata (song/artist/album, typically).

But a piece of classical music has a lot more metadata linked to it, including the composer, the orchestra, the conductor, the movement, the nickname, and the key.

So, it gets messy. Imagine sifting through more than 490 covers of a Dua Lipa track for your favorite rendition. Thatâ€™s how many recordings of Beethovenâ€™s Piano Concerto No. 5 are on Apple <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Rk8_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ceb9f8e5f>, CNET notes.

To help it fix the metadata problem, Apple bought Primephonic, a Dutch startup that had built the back-end data infrastructure needed to surface the most useful search results.

Tack on human editors curating their favorite recordings, and Appleâ€™s hoping its new app will attract both the Lydia TÃ¡r types and newbies looking to see what all the Mozart fuss is about.â€”NF

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80RlA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb58bbf21>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80RlE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C815d28e5>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31052283.103981/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80RlI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA1MjI4My4xMDM5ODE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3b9dda0d>Â Â

Markets: Investors have to feel pretty good heading into the first trading day of the second quarter. After all, last month saw the biggest banking failures since the financial crisis, and the S&P still closed up 3.5%. You can thank two companies <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Qno_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7f6f4104> for that: Microsoft and Apple. These tech giants accounted for about half of the S&Pâ€™s gain in March.

Energy: Oil prices jumped <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QkE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ccdeb0d6b> as much as 8% last night after OPEC and its allies made the surprising decision to cut output. The White House canâ€™t be happy with the Saudis, since the production cut could be inflationary and lead to higher gas prices for Americans.

MEDIA

UFC and WWE could be the ultimate tag team <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QkI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Da2627352> Vince McMahon <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QkI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ea2627352> Ethan Miller/Getty Images
Endeavor Group, the parent company of UFC, is nearing a blockbuster deal to buy WWE <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QkM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ceb25ed19>and could announce an agreement imminently, CNBC reported yesterday, which coincidentally(?) was the second day of WrestleMania, WWEâ€™s biggest event.

A deal would mean that three huge personalities in mediaâ€”Endeavor CEO Ari Emanuel, UFC President Dana White, and WWE Executive Chairman Vince McMahonâ€”will be working at the same company. Not even Erik Spoelstra could manage all that ego in one office.

A deal would also spawn a combat sports entertainment behemoth. WWE would have an enterprise value of $9.3 billion in the acquisition, CNBC reported, a significant premium over its current market value of $6.79 billion. And UFC, the largest global mixed martial arts organization, would be valued at more than $12 billion.

So, how would this all shake out?

The plan is to combine WWE and UFC into one publicly traded firm.

Emanuel, a Hollywood power broker, would remain CEO of Endeavor and also lead the new company.

Dana White would stay president of UFC and WWE CEO Nick Khan will become president of the wrestling unit.

But itâ€™s McMahon who comes out of this impending deal looking like a Logan Roy-level mastermind. With Endeavor scooping up 51% of the new company, heâ€™ll cash out on the humble wrestling promotion he bought from his dad <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QkQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ceb6f98de> in 1982 for $1 million and built into an entertainment juggernaut. McMahon had been shopping around WWE for months, and raised eyebrows when he asked $9 billion for his company. But Endeavor came in from the top rope to give him what he was looking for...and more.

There is controversy surrounding these big personalities

McMahon had temporarily retired in July following a scandal over hush money payments sent to women who accused him of sexual harassment and misconduct. White, meanwhile, was filmed slapping his wife on New Yearâ€™s Eve 2022 during an argument (he apologized for his behavior).

Bottom line: Many corporate mergers come labeled with imagined â€œsynergies,â€ but a UFCâ€“WWE tie-up might truly be a 1+1=3 scenario. WWE could piggyback off of UFCâ€™s success in bringing in sponsorship revenue, and itâ€™s also exploring legalizing betting on its matches in several states.

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QkU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce60e8911>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QkY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C9dd8e00d>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80Qkc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1388bbb2>Â Â

Top editors at 38 news outlets (including the Wall Street Journal, where Gershkovich works) called for Gershkovich to be immediately released <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31041265.2944781/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QlA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTA0MTI2NS4yOTQ0Nzgx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C4c5de2e0> and accused Russia of â€œsending the message that journalism within your borders is criminalized.â€ The WSJ vehemently denies the allegations against its reporter.

Time value of money (TVM) is calculated by assessing the present value of a future amount, the corresponding number of years and interest rate, and multiplying the resulting factor and the future value.

FINANCE

If you invested in tech stocks last quarter, congrats <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31029240.2950477/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QU8_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTAyOTI0MC4yOTUwNDc3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dd74746ff> Stock lines on a chart banking and tech going different directions <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31029240.2950477/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QU8_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTAyOTI0MC4yOTUwNDc3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ed74746ff> Francis Scialabba
With the first quarter of 2023 behind us, we now know that if youâ€™d visited a good Tarot card reader on New Yearâ€™s Day, they wouldâ€™ve told you to park your cash in tech stocks and avoid bank shares.

Despite wild fluctuation due to continuous rate hikes from the Fed and an unexpected bank panic, stocks and bonds managed <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/31029240.2950477/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy80QVA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMTAyOTI0MC4yOTUwNDc3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce8ee8bbe> to turn in a pretty, pretty, pretty good performance for the quarter. The S&P 500 gained 7% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4%.

But tech is indisputably the honors students.

Top of the class

Wall Street rewarded tech companiesâ€™ layoffs and other cost cutting measures, giving tech stocks a resurgence. And as ChatGPT becomes a household name, investors clearly have their money on generative AI being the next big bet.

The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite index rose a whopping 18% since January 1, its largest quarterly gain in two years.

Stocks of the tech giants leading the charge in AI-powered search, Microsoft and Alphabet, are up 20% and 16%, respectively.

And in an I-told-you-so triumph for your crypto-obsessed cousin, Bitcoin has surged 72%.

Meanwhile, the second- and third-largest bank collapses in US history happening within 48 hours hurt *drumroll please*â€¦banks.

The remedial bunch

Bank stocks were a delight for short sellers, who made $2 billion betting against the sector in the past three months.

Smaller institutions were most badly injured by the bank panic: The SPRD S&P Regional Banking ETF, which consists of non-behemoth banks, had more than a quarter of its value wiped out in Q1.

Large banks are feeling the pinch of rising interest rates: Global merger and acquisition deals suffered the biggest first-quarter decline since 2001, according to the Financial Times and Refinitiv.

Looking ahead: While Q1 proved just about anything can happen, itâ€™s safe to bet that the marketâ€™s future performance largely hinges on what Jerome Powell and his central bankers decide what to do next.â€”SK

TOGETHER WITH WHOOP
