Â  SCIENCE

Â  Dept. of Progress Hey Arnold saying Hey Arnold!/Paramount Global Here are some illuminating scientific discoveries from the week to help you live better and maybe even justify all those six-dollar cold brews.

Two men and a baby. For the first time ever, scientists have successfully created baby mice with two biologically male parents <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C5148be2d> by turning male stem cells into female ones. After using the cells to make eggs, they were able to fertilize them, implant them in females, and see some healthy babies be born and grow into fertile adults. The breakthrough raises the possibility of using the same techniques for human babies, but scientists cautioned thatâ€™s still a long way away.

Your morning brew may be good for you. Drinking three cups of coffee a day might make you type really fast and really loud, but a new study found it could also improve your health. The research <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cfc0b2581> linked high levels of caffeine in your blood with lower body fat and a reduced risk of Type 2 diabetes. But before you zoom off to Latte Larryâ€™s, know that the study had some limitationsâ€”it mostly involved people with European ancestry and didnâ€™t actually test whether drinking caffeinated beverages causes the health benefits.

Can a newsletter writerâ€™s vacation move markets? Weâ€™re asking for a friendâ€¦specifically, Bloomberg Opinionâ€™s Matt Levine, whose PTO has been interrupted by financial news bombshells so many times that people started joking his scheduled vacations presaged market volatility. Ivy League grad students investigated <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cff69c358> whether this was trueâ€”and found it wasnâ€™t. Turns out Matt can knock back drinks served in coconuts without putting the financial system at risk: His time off (usually taken during popular vacation times) actually corresponds to calmer moments for the market.â€”AR

Â  NEWS ANALYSIS

Â  The easy-money era may be over for startups <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D3c12a66d> Jared in Silicon Valley looking out of a window <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E3c12a66d>Silicon Valley/HBO via Giphy Silicon Valley Bankâ€™s collapse is dragging down <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1d8f92f0> startupsâ€™ futures with it, like the Scar to their Mufasa. And when the founders of young companies catch their breath from the initial chaos, theyâ€™ll be confronted with a harsh reality: The days of easily securing bank loans while looking out over the Pride Lands are over.

The gist: The version of Silicon Valley Bank that now exists after regulators stepped in can give startups their money back, but not the services theyâ€™ve come to rely on.

SVB was rooted deep into the startup ecosystem

SVB was relatively smallâ€”it had 40,000 customers compared to JPMorgan Chaseâ€™s 66 millionâ€”but it claimed to bank nearly half of all US tech and life sciences startups last year, including household names like Etsy, Roblox, and Roku. The cultural cachet of having a relationship with SVB as a venture-backed startup was like sporting a New Yorker tote at Whole Foods.

But the reason its loss will leave such a gaping hole in the startup community isnâ€™t that it was cool to name-drop at a networking event. Because the bank was created in 1983 specifically to cater to venture-backed startups, it helped them in ways that most banks canâ€™tâ€”or wonâ€™t.

SVB was known for super-chill loans: SVB would offer loans to startups more readily <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C6f2b5327> than large banks, basing the loans on a companyâ€™s ability to raise venture capital funds, not to turn a profit. SVB was also known for being flexibleâ€”even if startups breached their loan terms.

â€œThey were the easiest money for an unprofitable, early stage to midstage tech company,â€ Irving Investors founder Jeremy Abelson told The Information.

Plus, it had a personalized touch: Even small startups received hand-holding services, such as guidance on how to set up their financial infrastructure. Its bankers personally called startups when they secured their first rounds of funding, according to The Information.

Now, startups might have to deal with big league banks

Several founders who previously banked with SVB told Bloomberg that theyâ€™re moving their money <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc422b329> to Chase and Bank of America, banks considered â€œtoo big to fail.â€

Startupsâ€™ experience at big banks wonâ€™t be like their time at SVB. Not only is Jamie Dimon unlikely to call a startup to congratulate them on their Series A, but big banks are also expected to be more tight-fisted with their loans. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, a regulator that oversees large US banks, disapproves <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUjk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C51087269> of loans to companies that are further out than one year from profitability, according to Crunchbase.

The loss of SVB is therefore expected to have a chilling effect on loans to venture-backed startups, aka â€œventure debt,â€ which SVB handed out more of than any other bank.

Zoom out: While on the surface, less money flowing to startups = bad, some think SVBâ€™s collapse could be a net-positive reckoning for the startup community. Loans from SVB may have been too easy to procure, leading to reckless spending. â€œI think we all would be better off burning a lot less cash,â€ Chris Herndon, founder of SVB-banked startup The Guild, told The Information.â€”JW

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUmE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ca0caeff9>Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUmI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ca5449239>Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUmM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cfed01816>Â

Â  DESTINATIONS

Â  Place to be: the Washington, DC, Cherry Blossom Festival Cherry blossoms in D.C. Getty Images Itâ€™s a big world out there. In this section, weâ€™ll teleport you to an interesting locationâ€”and hopefully give you travel ideas in the process.

Weâ€™re nearing the end of March, and other than on your couch watching college basketball, the only other â€œplace to beâ€ is in Washington, DC, for the Cherry Blossom Festival <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30873753.3348347/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zUm0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg3Mzc1My4zMzQ4MzQ3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cfa6925af>.

The festivities began yesterday, a few days earlier than intended. DC is coming off of a historically warm winter, and the blossoms will be their fluffiest selves (aka â€œpeak bloomâ€) March 22â€“25.

How did DC get cherry blossoms?

We have Eliza Ruhamah Scidmore to thank. In 1885, the American travel writer returned from a visit to Japan, where she had become infatuated with the countryâ€™s flowering cherry trees, known as â€œSakura.â€ For the next 24 years, she lobbied the US government to bring Japanese cherry trees to the nationâ€™s capital. Ignored time and time again, she finally found a powerful ally in Dept. of Agriculture official David Fairchild, who was also an admirer of Japanese cherry trees.

The two convinced the first lady at the time, Helen Herron Taft, to join their crusade, and after a few more hiccups along the way, a donation of more 3,000 trees arrived in DC as a gesture of goodwill from the mayor of Tokyo.

You can see the blossoming of Scidmoreâ€™s dream along the Tidal Basin over the next five weekends.â€”NF

The stateâ€™s high court unanimously ruled that towns cannot require residents to act civilly in public meetings.

Politeness vs. freedom of assembly

The main plaintiff in the case was 71-year-old Louise Barron, of Southborough, MA. Barron sued after her brash behavior got her threatened with removal from a town meeting under rules requiring civility. She was uncivil: In a heated argument, Barron accused the townâ€™s Select Board of spending taxpayer funds â€œlike drunken sailorsâ€ and told one member â€œto stop being a Hitler.â€

The court opined that local governments should encourage polite discourse but deemed Southboroughâ€™s public meeting civility rules a violation of citizensâ€™ contitutional right to criticize public servants.

Mixed opinions: While some critics worry itâ€™ll embolden cantankerous constituents, freedom of speech advocates welcomed the decision. Bellicose exchanges in town meetings are as much a Massachusetts tradition as sipping on a Dunks medium iced while plowing snow after a mighty norâ€™easter.

INTERNATIONAL

France in a frenzy over retirement age bump <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zTzQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Da7a1d51e> A protester climbs on a traffic light during a demonstration on Place de la Concorde, as the Eiffel tower is seen in the background, after the French government pushed a pensions reform through parliament without a vote <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zTzQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ea7a1d51e> Alain Jocard/AFP/AFP via Getty Images
Emily may have to keep posting about luxury products in her fancy Paris office for longer than she anticipated. French President Emmanuel Macron and his supporters used executive power to bypass Parliament and raise <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zTzU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7766f54b> Franceâ€™s official retirement age from 62 to 64 yesterday, despite massive pushback from much of the country.

Macron, whoâ€™s 10 months into his second five-year term, campaigned on the promise of raising the official retirement age to help keep Franceâ€™s shrinking pension fund flush with cash. He and his supporters have noted that French people are living on average three years longer compared to a few decades ago, and the retirement age needs to reflect that.

This is about as popular as your sisterâ€™s new boyfriend

About three-quarters of the French public is against raising the retirement age. Over the last few months, trade unions have launched eight coordinated protests across the country, and millions of citizens have marched in the streets, stymying public services.

Workersâ€™ strikes have disrupted transportation services, including trains and planes.

More than 7,000 tons of garbage have piled up in Paris after sanitation workers walked off the job in protest.

What comes next? French lawmakers who oppose the change are preparing a no-confidence vote that if successful would essentially gut Macronâ€™s ability to do anything going forward and reverse the retirement age bump. The likelihood of that passing? Not high. So far during Macronâ€™s tenure, several previous no-confidence votes have failed. But unions have vowed to continue protests and â€œtake things up a gear <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zTzY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb4651530>â€ following Macronâ€™s move.

Big picture: France isnâ€™t the only country that wants to make citizens send emails for more of their lives. The UK and China have both floated the idea of raising retirement ages as their elderly populations eclipse working-age citizens. In the US, the idea of bumping the retirement age has also been proposed as a fix for Social Security reserves expected to run dry in 2034.â€”MM

Wall Street to the rescue. The largest banks in the US gave a $30 billion infusion <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2E_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C59e89773> to First Republic Bank, the struggling regional lender that found itself in the blast radius of SVB. JPMorgan, Bank of America, and other financial giants each poured in at least $2.5 billion to shore up confidence in the US banking system during this precarious time. If you needed more proof these are precarious times: US banks borrowed $152.85 billion from a Fed lending program in the past week, topping the previous weekly high from the 2008 financial crisis.

Inflation hits YouTube TV: Google raised the price <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2I_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ca861bc20> of its YouTube TV subscription from $65 per month to $73â€”a 12% bump. The service, intended as a cable replacement, hasnâ€™t experienced a price hike since June 2020. But, according to Google, â€œcontent costs have risenâ€ since then. It didnâ€™t specify what content costs more now, but YouTube TV did recently pony up a reported $2 billion for the rights to the NFLâ€™s Sunday Ticket package. Other streaming services from Apple, Disney, and HBO have raised prices recently.

SCIENCE

Worldâ€™s 1st octopus farm proposal sparks outcry <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2Y_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2De878cb1c> Octopus <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2Y_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ee878cb1c> Nikos Stavrinidis/Getty Images
A proposal to kill farmed octopuses with extremely cold water has landed a Spanish company in hot water with animal welfare advocates. Seafood producer Nueva Pescanova aims to open an octopus farm <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2c_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc5fd3a52> in the Canary Islands, the worldâ€™s first, where it reportedly would slaughter the mollusks for food by placing them in -3 degree Celsius slush, according to leaked documents obtained by Eurogroup for Animals.

Scientists point to studies on fish to argue that the slaughter method would distress the highly intelligent animals and cause them to die slowly. Animal rights supporters note that the plan to house the octopuses in lit-up communal tanks doesnâ€™t adequately replicate their natural habitatâ€”the animals are territorial and thrive in darkness.

Nueva Pescanova rejects accusations of animal cruelty.

Why are humans rallying around octopuses?

Though wild-caught octopuses are a delicacy in global coastal cuisines (and one award-winning thriller <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2g_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C5fbb14fa>), their cognitive prowess makes them a more ethically contentious culinary delight than most other seafood.

One Dartmouth University cognitive neuroscientist believes theyâ€™re â€œas intelligent as cats,â€ and UK law recently recognized them as sentient beings since they can feel pain and pleasure.

A brain in each of the eight arms (and one in the head) allow octopuses to use tools, recognize humans, and even open jars <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2k_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1c8185ac>.

In the USâ€¦lawmakers in Washington state are weighing a ban on the nascent octopus farming industry, inspired in part by the Netflix documentary <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30864054.101657/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zT2o_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg2NDA1NC4xMDE2NTc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb9ce9b0c> My Octopus Teacher.â€”SK

Markets: Anyone hoping the storm had passed for the markets was disappointed yesterday after Credit Suisse got investors fearing for the health of the financial sector all over again (more on that in a sec). Bank stocks in Europe and the US took a hit <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30848879.2966880/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zSkM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg0ODg3OS4yOTY2ODgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1a9ae220>, including First Republic which reportedly began to mull selling itself to a larger institution after two ratings firms cut its credit rating to "junk."

FINANCE

Global banking system on edgeâ€¦again <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30848879.2966880/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zSnI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg0ODg3OS4yOTY2ODgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D14b17e97> A dog saying <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30848879.2966880/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zSnI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg0ODg3OS4yOTY2ODgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E14b17e97> Gunshow/Giphy
Just when we thought we could put up our feet and enjoy a stress-free day of watching college basketball, another banking mess emerged.

Yesterdayâ€™s mayhem stems not from California, but from Zurich. The Swiss banking giant Credit Suisse cratered <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30848879.2966880/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zSnM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg0ODg3OS4yOTY2ODgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C667c22a8> to a record low yesterday after its largest shareholder, the Saudi National Bank, said it couldnâ€™t provide Credit Suisse with any more financial support due to regulations. Investors already rattled by two major bank failures in the US sent bank stocks tumbling, and concerns grew that the fragile financial sector could fracture.

To shore up liquidity, Credit Suisse said last night it will borrow <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30848879.2966880/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zSzY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg0ODg3OS4yOTY2ODgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cda621474> up to $54 billion from the Swiss National Bank.

Are Credit Suisseâ€™s problems related to SVB?

No. Credit Suisse has been in the Bad Place for years due to mismanagement and scandals. When many clients yanked their money out of the bank last year, Credit Suisse posted its biggest annual loss since the financial crisis.

And, unlike SVB, which catered to a niche client base of startups, 167-year-old Credit Suisse is a much more influential player <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30848879.2966880/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zSnU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDg0ODg3OS4yOTY2ODgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ca835c25d> with deep ties to financial markets all over the globe. It is considered a â€œsystemically important financial institutionâ€ under international banking regulations.

But if youâ€™re a bank, nowâ€™s not a time to show any weakness

Though SVBâ€™s implosion did not lead to Credit Suisseâ€™s current crisis, it did expose how banks everywhere are under pressure from rising interest rates. When rates were near zero, banks scooped up safe but low- or even negative-yielding bonds. Now that rates are much higher, the value of those bonds fell, and banks are sitting on loads of unrealized losses.

In other words, SVBâ€™s collapse woke up the mama bear, then Credit Suisse went and poked it.

Zoom out: Some finance leaders think a â€œslow rolling crisisâ€ is coming for banks. BlackRock CEO Larry Fink, in his widely read annual letter, wrote that rapid rate increases have â€œexposed cracks in the financial system,â€ and he predicted â€œmore seizures and shutdowns coming.â€â€”NF

Good morning. The Ides of March (today) is infamous for being the date Julius Caesar was killed. But before that happened, it was mostly known as the deadline by which the ancient Romans had to settle their debts. That means today is the only day you can click â€œRemindâ€ on Venmo without being considered passive-aggressive.

Weâ€™re beginning to learn what Metaâ€™s â€œyear of efficiencyâ€ means in practice: fewer employees.

Yesterday, CEO Mark Zuckerberg said Meta plans to lay off 10,000 employees, <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zR2o_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1089e959> just four months after it laid off 11,000 staff members. That round of layoffs, impacting 13% of Metaâ€™s workforce, represented the biggest job cuts in the companyâ€™s history.

Not only is Meta laying off 10k employees, but itâ€™s also closing 5,000 open roles. This is not a company that wants to onboard many people right now.

Why is that?

Meta is looking to reduce costs as part of what Mark Zuckerberg calls the â€œyear of efficiency.â€ Last year was â€œa humbling wake-up call,â€ Zuck said, citing economic uncertainty and increased competition (aka TikTok) for denting the companyâ€™s ad revenue.

But Meta made plenty of unforced errors, too. And by dubbing 2023 â€œthe year of efficiency,â€ itâ€™s acknowledging that previously, things were not very efficient.

That starts with hiring. Meta has been criticized for growing its headcount so rapidly that many employees had nothing to do.

In a viral TikTok video <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zR2s_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ceb5f87dc>, one former Meta employee said, â€œwe were just sitting thereâ€ and â€œyou had to fight to find work.â€

A report <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zR2w_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3e81cee5> in Wired argues that Metaâ€™s headcount got bloated due to â€œghosts in the machineâ€â€”employees who were brought on to launch new products and stayed on the payroll even when those products failed.

Putting the recent layoffs in context: Even after shedding 21,000 jobs, Meta will still have a higher headcount than it did before the pandemic. In the boom times of 2020 and 2021, it hired <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zR20_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C36da6fa6> more than 27,000 employees.

Zoom out: While the US labor market remains strong, layoffs have spiked in 2023. Companies announced 180,713 job cuts <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zR24_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C447f6b54> in January and Februaryâ€”the most to start any year since 2009, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. â€‹â€‹ChatGPT is old news. OpenAI released its much-hyped GPT-4 AI language model <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zSGQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2954d576> yesterday, representing an advancement over the tech that powers ChatGPT. Plus, it crushes its predecessor GPT-3.5 on academic assessments: On a simulated bar exam, GPT-4 scored around the top 10% of test takers, while GPT-3.5 scored around the bottom 10%.

EPA moves to get â€œforever chemicalsâ€ out of drinking water. The EPA proposed regulations yesterday to limit <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zR3M_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C03d1daeb> the amount of six types of industrial chemicals allowed in drinking water. PFAS, as they are known, cause health problems including cancer. Though many companies have begun phasing out the chemicals, a 2020 study found that 200 million Americans are exposed to PFAS in tap water.

Weâ€™ve written at George R. R. Martin-length about the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the second-largest banking collapse in US history. The deets are juicy.

On Sunday, regulators seized the assets of NY-based Signature Bank and gave senior management the boot, but they assured its depositors that they could access all of their money. Signature was deemed a threat to the US financial system after panicked customers reportedly withdrew 20% of its total deposits.

But leaders inside the bank say authorities overreacted, led by none other than Barney Frank, the former US representative on Signatureâ€™s board. If that name sounds familiar, itâ€™s because Frank crafted key banking regulations in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis (the Dodd-Frank Act).

Frank argues that Singature was singled out because of its ties to cryptoâ€”it was one of the go-to banks for crypto companies. Frank told Bloomberg <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30836836.2966161/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zR3U_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgzNjgzNi4yOTY2MTYx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce481dcf9> that he believes Signature wasnâ€™t on the verge of collapse, and regulators only shut it down â€œto send a message to get people away from crypto.â€

Authorities have pushed back on the pushback. The New York State Department of Financial Services, which initiated the closure, claims that Signature executives were elusive in sharing data with regulators during the bank panic, causing a â€œcrisis of confidence.â€â€”SK

In the early 2000s, boneless wings gained popularity when the price of chicken breastâ€”which is what boneless wings are usually made ofâ€”cratered, while wings remained expensive.  TOGETHER WITH

Cytonics <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeng_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUzJmxwPWxvZ28/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd9594294> 
Good morning. At an event outside Tokyo in 2006, Akira Haraguchi set an unofficial world record for reciting the most digits of pi: 100,000+ over more than 16 hours. So, howâ€™d he do it? In his mind, he linked each digit with a syllable and created a collection of epic stories from the words those syllables formed.

For Haraguchi, pi is more than just a numberâ€”itâ€™s a spiritual calling <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQnc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2f8820d5>. He told The Guardian: â€œAll things in this world, including ourselves, are aggregate sums of atoms, which are made up of rotating electrons. The ultimate history of mankind is moving toward a happy ending for people of all races. The Earth, the galaxy, and the universe all rotate. In other words, I think rotation is the absolute truth. So as long as Iâ€™m thinking about pi, I think I can live a life according to truth.â€

Happy Pi Day.

â€”Sam Klebanov, Jamie Wilde, Neal Freyman, Abby Rubenstein

Some stocks were actually buoyed by the notion that the Fed might stop raising interest rates due to the potential for a banking crisis. But bank stocks, especially regional ones, took a big hit, even though several regional banks told news outlets that they werenâ€™t experiencing the big deposit pullouts investors feared.

FINANCE

Did the government hand SVB and Signature Bank a bailout? <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQnk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dbde10095> Government extinguishing an SVB cash fire <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQnk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ebde10095> Hannah Minn
You may have heard that the second- and third-largest bank implosions in US history occurred in the past four days. And since financial regulators know that bank runs can be as contagious as measles, they moved fast to keep cash flowing in order to prevent a system-wide epidemic.

Officials announced Sunday that clients of Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) and Signature Bank will get their full deposits back, with the money coming from the Deposit Insurance Fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC). The decision prompted comparisons to when Uncle Sam bailed out banking behemoths back in 2008, angering many taxpayers who footed the bill to rescue bank shareholders and executives.

But is it a bailout?

Hereâ€™s why it sure looks like a bailout to some: The FDIC guarantees bank deposits only up to $250,000, but most SVB and Signature clients were businesses rather than individuals, with account balances surpassing that mark. The government threw out the $250k compensation limit for the banksâ€™ clients. And the Federal Reserve said itâ€™s got cash ready to loan other banks that might be in trouble.

But officials are adamant that thereâ€™s no need to use the b-word <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQzc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ca6f82ae9>, pointing out that only the banksâ€™ clients are getting their money back.

So, whatâ€™s different this time around?

Unlike in 2008, SVB and Signature investors are taking a loss, and executives at the banks will be fired. â€œThatâ€™s how capitalism works,â€ President Biden said, referring to the fact that shareholders wonâ€™t get a free pass for their financial flops (sorry if you took Jim Cramerâ€™s advice <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cac7a8618>).

The Treasury Department is also stressing that this time the recovery money is not from taxpayers but from an FDIC fund that banks pay into.

However, thereâ€™s no free lunch for taxpayersâ€¦banks may have to shell out extra cash to the FDIC to make SVB and Signature clients whole, which could ultimately come out of their customersâ€™ pockets.â€”SK

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C4477ccae>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQzg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce3366a66>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C58998105>Â Â  

TOGETHER WITH CYTONICS

600 million cases, 1 unsolvable problemâ€¦ <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeng_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUzJmxwPXRpdGxl/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C6d45c91c> Cytonics <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeng_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUzJmxwPWltYWdl/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C5f278c86>
Osteoarthritis.

Despite being the most common joint disease in the worldâ€”affecting over 600m peopleâ€”the only available treatments are â€œband-aidsâ€ that offer temporary relief (e.g., painkillers and corticosteroids).

Thatâ€™s a big issue, and one that Cytonics is about to solve <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeng_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUzJmxwPXRleHQx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc6f6e354>.

Founded by an orthopedic surgeon, Cytonics has identified the root cause of osteoarthritis and is developing a biologic agent to attack it. With 22 issued US and international patents, $25m in funding already raised, and 8,000 patients successfully treated <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeng_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUzJmxwPXRleHQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C9fe7e650>, Cytonics is well on their way to dominating the $240 billion osteoarthritis treatment market.

The best part? Theyâ€™re still accepting investments.

Uber drivers are contractors, California court says. A state appeals court upheld <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQzU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C9d539806> Proposition 22, a California ballot measure that classifies Uber and Lyft drivers as independent contractors rather than employees. The decision overturned a lower courtâ€™s ruling voiding the law. But the legal battle over the status of hundreds of thousands of gig workers is likely far from over: The Service Employees International Union is expected to appeal the decision to the stateâ€™s highest court.

Australia is getting nuclear-powered submarines. The US, UK, and Australia struck a deal yesterday to help the country Down Under go further down under. Australia will buy <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cae1ed42a> submarines from the US to modernize its aging naval fleet in what Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese called â€œthe biggest single investment in Australiaâ€™s defense capability in all of our history.â€ The agreement is the product of a nuclear partnership among the three nations that kicked off in 2021.

Pfizer bets $43 billion on cancer drugs. Pfizer is shelling out that cash to purchase <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C82facb9f> Seagen, a biotech company specializing in innovative cancer treatments known as antibody-drug conjugates that can attack cancer while leaving healthy cells intact. The purchase could get attention from antitrust regulators as the government has started looking closely at healthcare deals. However, although Pfizerâ€™s oncology division raked in $12 billion in revenue last year, it doesnâ€™t have the kind of treatments it will get from Seagen.

ECONOMY

The Fed rethinks its playbook <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D8ab1e00a> a meme about the Fed reversing direction <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E8ab1e00a> Imgflip/Neal Freyman
Fed Chair Jerome Powell had a plan: He was going to continue hiking interest rates until inflation returned to typical 2% levels. But then Silicon Valley Bank collapsed, and that plan became almost as outdated as Mason jar decor.

Given the current fragility of the banking sector, some economists predict that Powell will change his strategy to put the health of banks above all other considerations.

Goldman Sachs, which previously projected a rate increase of 25 basis points at the Fedâ€™s meeting next week, now expects no rate increase <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C73280627>, citing â€œstress in the banking system.â€

The Japanese bank Nomura made an even bolder prediction yesterday: a rate cut at next weekâ€™s Fed meeting.

Another rate hike next week is still the most popular betâ€”as of yesterday, traders were pricing in a 70% chance <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQkk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2B09240512> of a 25 basis-point increase, according to the CME FedWatch Tool. But the fact that weâ€™re even talking about the Fed potentially pausing rate hikes shows how dramatically the conversation has shifted since last Friday, when the probability of a meaty, 50 basis-point hike was 40% (now itâ€™s 0%).

Zoom out: The Fed already had a tough job trying to bring down historic inflation. But thanks to SVBâ€™s implosion, it now needs to balance its fight against inflation with preventing even more banking chaos.

Controversial oil drilling project in Alaska gets the green light <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQk0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Bea848391> Wild birds in Alaska <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQk0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cea848391> The Washington Post/Getty Images
President Biden approved <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQk4_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C73a1b06a> the controversial Willow oil project for the Alaskan Arctic yesterday. That means oil company ConocoPhillips can drill on some of the USâ€™s last unspoiled wilderness, where itâ€™ll extract an estimated 576 million barrels of oil over the next 30 years.

Environmentalists oppose the drilling, calling the approval a severe setback for Bidenâ€™s goal of cutting CO2 emissions in half by 2030. And theyâ€™ve got support: More than 1 million protest letters have been sent to the White House, a Change.org petition has 3.2 million signatures, and the #StopWillow hashtag on TikTok has over 180 million views.

But Alaska lawmakers, oil industry groups, and some Native groups welcome <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30823808.2976653/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zQk8_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgyMzgwOC4yOTc2NjUz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd5d53942> the Willow oil project for the revenue and jobs it could create.

Biden *tried* to please everyone

The final project scales back ConocoPhillipsâ€™s original proposal by about 68,000 acres, only allowing three out of five requested drilling â€œpads,â€ or sites where a rig is set up.

Biden also threw in some environmental consolation gifts: He banned all drilling in the Arctic Ocean and added protections for 13 million acres of the National Petroleum Reserve in Alaska. But Jamal Raad, co-founder of the climate group Evergreen Action, called these measures â€œlipstick on a pig.â€

 TOGETHER WITH

Facet <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30813774.3386742/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zcko_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgxMzc3NC4zMzg2NzQyJmxwPWxvZ28/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3e9b42ea>

Somehow weâ€™ve managed to squeeze it into one newsletter: the scramble to prevent a banking crisis, an Oscars recap, turmoil at the BBC, and a lot more. You might want to grab your coffee before diving in.

Markets: Investors probably feel like a 5,000-pound weight has been lifted off their shoulders since US regulators announced a plan to make Silicon Valley Bank depositors whole. But danger still lurks: An important inflation report is on tap this week, and the banking sector remains skittish following SVBâ€™s shocking collapse. After another weekly loss last week, the S&P is now barely in the green for the year.

BANKING

OK, you can breathe now <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30813774.3386742/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeHM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgxMzc3NC4zMzg2NzQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Db4a96105> Silicon Valley Bank branch <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30813774.3386742/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeHM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgxMzc3NC4zMzg2NzQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Eb4a96105> Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
At the end of an extremely stressful weekend, depositors of collapsed Silicon Valley Bank were told they could have everything everywhere, at all once.

Yesterday evening, the US government informed anxious SVB depositors that theyâ€™d have access <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30813774.3386742/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeHQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgxMzc3NC4zMzg2NzQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C423fedd9> to all the money they stashed with the lender today, even if the amount exceeded the $250,000 limit insured by the FDIC. In addition to backstopping depositors, the Fed is offering additional funding to some banks to limit the contagion from spreading across the banking sector.

The Fedâ€™s aggressive actions, the scale of which we havenâ€™t seen since early Covid, show how the implosion of Silicon Valley Bank on Friday could have quickly turned into a full-blown banking crisis when markets opened this morning.

Banking is a confidence game, and if people and businesses felt their uninsured deposits were at risk, they could start pulling money from other banks in a catastrophic bank run.

The government had a hard deadline of 9:30am ET this morning to restore confidence in the banking system, and it beat it. Heck, it even got it done before the Oscars.

However, in their announcement, regulators also noted the closure of a second bank, New York-based Signature Bank, over â€œsystemic risk.â€ All of Signatureâ€™s depositors will be made whole, they said.

What it all means

The governmentâ€™s propping up of SVBâ€™s depositors means the US startup ecosystem will avoid an â€œextinction-level event <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30813774.3386742/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeHU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgxMzc3NC4zMzg2NzQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C59b1f0a2>,â€ as some startup leaders had warned. More than half of US tech and life sciences startups banked with SVB, and many were concerned they wouldnâ€™t have enough money to pay employees this week or keep their companies running.

What will happen to SVB? Its assets will be sold to the highest bidder. The FDIC, which now controls SVB, began an auction for the bankâ€™s assets Saturday night. The cleanest outcome would be a single buyer, but there are only a few banks big enough to realistically scoop it all up, such as JPMorgan, Citigroup, or Bank of America. As of last night, no deal had been reached.

Bottom line: While it appears that we wonâ€™t be reliving 2008, expect SVB to remain in the headlines for days and weeks to come. Politically charged debates over the Fedâ€™s decision to backstop depositors, the meaning(lessness) of FDIC insurance, regulation of mid-sized banks, and how to prevent another SVB-like collapse have already begun and will only grow louder.

A scandal has erupted in Britain at the intersection of TV, sports, and politics.

This weekend, the BBC was forced to pull <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30813774.3386742/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeEM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgxMzc3NC4zMzg2NzQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C4813464a> much of its sports coverage following a boycott by anchors and commentators in solidarity with Gary Lineker.

Lineker, a former star soccer player and now a hugely popular TV presenter, was suspended <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30813774.3386742/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zeEQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgxMzc3NC4zMzg2NzQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cceaaae03> by the BBC on Friday for a tweet that criticized the UK governmentâ€™s immigration proposal to stop asylum-seekers from coming into the country via boats.

The BBC said that Linekerâ€™s tweet violated its impartiality guidelines and suspended him from his hosting duties at Match of the Day, a beloved soccer program thatâ€™s been around since the â€™60s (imagine the glory days of NFL PrimeTime, but with 100x the cultural cache).

Chaos ensued. To support Lineker, other BBC on-air talent didnâ€™t show up for work this weekend, causing the network to scramble to fill in programming. It even aired a prerecorded podcast on the radio instead of live soccer coverage.

The political fallout: Linekerâ€™s suspension sparked a debate over the BBCâ€™s independence from the government, with critics accusing it of caving to pressure from conservative lawmakers. Even Prime Minister Rishi Sunak weighed in, defending the governmentâ€™s immigration proposal and expressing hope that Lineker and the BBC would work things out.

Prime trivia

Set a timer for five minutes. Then, without looking them up, write down the 10 prime numbers between 50 and 100. Or at least see how many you can get.

Personal

Â  Photo of the week Skijoring competition in Leadville, Colorado Jason Connolly/AFP via Getty Images What exactly is going on in this picture? Thanks for asking. It shows competitors in the annual Leadville Ski Joring event <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cec65a2ae>. Every winter since 1949, this Colorado town has hosted a skijoring tournament wherein a skier is towed by a horse and rider down historic Harrison Avenue. Itâ€™s not exactly for pizza-style skiersâ€”these daredevils must hit jumps, collect rings on their batons, and squeeze between gates while hurtling toward the finish line.

Fun fact: At 10,200 feet above sea level, Leadville is the highest incorporated city in North America.

Â  SCIENCE

Â  Dept. of Progress Dexter from Dexter's lab saying Dexterâ€™s Laboratory/Warner Bros. Domestic Television via Giphy Here are some illuminating scientific discoveries from the week to help you live better but maybe also kill your buzz.

Sobering science. Researchers at UT Southwestern may have found a way to sober you up <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf6afda74> fast. At the very least, theyâ€™ve figured out what to do with mice that might be slugging IPAs while living in your walls. They found that injecting the liver-produced hormone FGF21 into mice that were passed out from booze brought the critters back to consciousness in half the time it otherwise takes to sleep it off. If it works for humans, the research could lead to lifesaving treatments for alcohol poisoning.

Super superconductor news. Scientists reported a breakthrough in the journal Nature that could improve any technology that uses electric power, from car batteries to maglev trains to fusion reactors. The researchers claim to have discovered a superconducting material <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C19bb07d7> that, unlike the ones weâ€™ve got now, can work at around room temperature and low enough pressure levels to be commercially viable. One caveat: The team behind the new superconductor had a similar paper retracted by the same journal in 2020, leaving some experts skeptical of their work this time around.

What causes coulrophobia? That SAT word means fear of clowns, and scientists recently set out to determine why weâ€™re all so freaked out <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C772ff737> by Bozos: Unsurprisingly, itâ€™s the way they look. Though negative pop culture portrayals play a role, the researchers concluded that most people get spooked around clowns because weâ€™re uncomfortable that we canâ€™t suss out their true facial expressions behind their makeup. Of the 53.5% of people surveyed who admitted to being afraid of the circus workers, very few reported having actually had a close encounter with a Pennywise type.â€”AR

Â  HEALTH

Â  Covid lab leak theory reignites debate over research safety <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D811f8d50> Person working with hazardous lab materials <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E811f8d50>Sebastian Condrea/Getty Images The one thing we know about where Covid-19 came from isâ€¦that we just donâ€™t know.

With little hard evidence to draw from, some experts believe that the virus leaked from a lab, specifically the Wuhan Institute of Virology (WIV), while others maintain it transferred from animals to humans. US government agencies are divided, and a congressional subcommittee has embarked on a quest this week to get closer to the truth by holding the first hearing on Covidâ€™s origins. But many experts arenâ€™t waiting for a definitive verdict on the lab leak theory <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1ad912e1> to jump into a heated discussion about whether the current safety regulations around the globe for research involving high-risk viruses are sufficient.

Even the idea that a virus that killed almost 7 million people may have started from a sleep-deprived intern had us wondering just how many other labs like WIV are out there and what theyâ€™re up toâ€”so letâ€™s dive in.Â 

What kind of labs are these?

Labs like WIV are designated Biosafety Level 4 by the CDC, which means they work with dangerous and highly transmissible diseases for which there are no vaccines or treatments. A pair of gloves and a lab coat wonâ€™t cut it at Level 4 facilities: Theyâ€™re usually housed in buildings with controlled airflow and state-of-the-art equipment, where staff are often swagged out in PPE on steroids <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdXo_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3c162d19>.

The number of Level 4 labs has grown in recent years.

* There are 52 of them operating around the world, including four in the US. And 17 more are due to open in the future.

* Locations range from Boston, MA, to Minsk, Belarus. A group of researchers conveniently created a map <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdUE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cfb9b8b41> so you can find the one nearest to you.

Though most Level 4 labs are operated by governments, some are privately run. The international standards meant to govern safety are difficult to enforce, and many experts argue that the regulations that are in place are too laxâ€”even in the US.

So, whatâ€™s up with US labs?

Every member of the National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity agrees that there needs to be a serious overhaul of how the US government handles oversight of dangerous pathogens. The board recommended that officials direct more scrutiny at research funded with private money and lower the threshold for what is considered a high-risk pathogen.

Biosecurity experts Gregory D. Koblentz and Rocco Casagrande say <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdUI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C9cda4b5e> that the US â€œhas taken a reactive and haphazard approach to preventing lab accidents.â€ They think there should be an independent government agency to regulate the research.

Meanwhile, former CDC Director Dr. Robert Redfield has called for an outright ban on research that involves engineering viruses to make them stronger. An early proponent of the lab leak hypothesis, Redfield says such research is too risky to be worth it. But infectious disease expert Dr. Paul Auwaerter disagrees: He warns that halting the research in the US wonâ€™t stop it from happening elsewhere.

Viruses donâ€™t recognize bordersâ€¦which is why many experts are calling for international cooperation in crafting research standards that will hopefully prevent the next pandemic, or at least preclude the need to argue about where it came from.â€”SK

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdUM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc4a182f2>Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdUQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7ae0c549>Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdUU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C45c1c943>Â

Â  DESTINATIONS

Â  Place to be: Nagi, Japan A child gets white powder on their face in Nagi Japan Nagi Town on YouTube <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cueW91dHViZS5jb20vd2F0Y2g_dj0ya0dfLXNFZ2JmTQ/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce4e231fc> Itâ€™s a big world out there. In this section, weâ€™ll teleport you to an interesting locationâ€”and hopefully give you travel ideas in the process.

Thereâ€™s something remarkable happening in the small, remote Japanese town of Nagi: It has a lot of babies <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdU8_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D7c2e8982>.

Why is that remarkable? Because Japanâ€™s population is shrinking fast, and an advisor to the prime minister recently warned <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdVA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc5a7b2e7> that â€œthe country will disappearâ€ if Japan doesnâ€™t turn things around in the stork-delivery department. About 2x as many people died as were born in Japan last year.

But Nagi is an exception to the rule <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30798758.3368811/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zdU8_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc5ODc1OC4zMzY4ODEx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E7c2e8982>, the WSJ reported. Women on average there have more than two children, compared to the national average of closer to one. Experts credit the townâ€™s financial support for childcare as a factor encouraging more birthsâ€” daycare costs a maximum of $420/month for a parentâ€™s first child and the cost goes down to $0 for the third.

Previously, Nagi was only known for inspiring a village of ninjas in the manga series Naruto. But now, thanks to its fecundity (big word alert), itâ€™s become somewhat of a travel destinationâ€”â€œbaby tourism,â€ weâ€™ll call it. Delegations from other parts of Japan and even South Korea have been visiting to understand its baby-making sauce.â€”NF

Â  COMMUNITY

Â  Crowd work Last week we asked you: What lore in your town should be turned into a Hollywood movie?

Here are some of our favorite responses:

* â€œIn Salt Lake City, there is a grave for Lilly E. Gray, which prominently reads: â€˜Victim of the Beast 666.â€™ Quite mysterious and great horror movie fodder.â€â€”Kate from Utah

* â€œMy hometown of Cut and Shoot, TX, supposedly got its name because in the early 1900s a preacher with a radical doctrine wanted to use the new town hall to preach a sermon. Half the town was vehemently against this. So those in favor nearly fought a battle against the pro faction. After that, it was known as where all the cutting and shooting [almost] happened.â€â€”Jason from Cut and Shoot, Texas

* â€œThe mall in Fredericksburg, VA, had a wig shop that stayed there for 30 years. The storefront never changed and the inventory was never updated, but somehow it survived. The wig store was the one constant among an ever-rotating cast of Chess Kings and Spencerâ€™s. Was it the little engine that could, or a mob front? I need a movie about this place!â€â€”Tom from Fredericksburg, Virginia

But major banks JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup all ended the day higher.

FINANCE

So long, Silicon Valley Bank <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30802367.2974113/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zd1E_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgwMjM2Ny4yOTc0MTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D7b2303b8> Brinks truck in front of Silicon Valley Bank <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30802367.2974113/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zd1E_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDgwMjM2Ny4yOTc0MTEz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E7b2303b8> Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
Silicon Valley Bank is no more. The tech industryâ€™s go-to lender imploded in the second largest bank failure in US history. After investor concerns about Silicon Valley Bankâ€™s (SVB) solvency prompted a bank run, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) took control of customersâ€™ deposits yesterday.

The collapse happened fast:

SVB said Wednesday that it sold some of its assets at an almost $2 billion loss, sending investors and depositors into full freak out mode.

Its stock tanked over 60% the next day and several prominent VC funds advised their portfolio companies to pull their deposits.

By Friday, the 40-year-old bank was toast.

Why did things go south?

SVB counted nearly half of all venture-backed US companies among its customers. That client list was a blessing when interest rates were low so startups were swimming in cash from VCs. Its deposits more than tripled between 2018 and 2021.

But when interest rates began to climb last year, deposits shrank and so did the value of the bonds it bought with depositorsâ€™ cash. Short sellers have been sounding alarm bells about risks to smaller banks for some time now. But SVB was particularly vulnerable as it parked an unusually high share of customersâ€™ funds in bonds and mortgage-backed securities.

What this means for SVB depositors

So when, if ever, will all those startups see their $175 billion in deposits? Each customer is guaranteed to receive up to $250,000 per account from the FDIC, but theyâ€™ll have to wait for the sale of SVBâ€™s remaining assets to see if they can get any more money back (and most will have to make payroll before then).

Some are getting creative: The toy store Camp is offering a 40% discount with promo code â€œbankrunâ€ to help it stay afloat as it waits for its cash to be returned.

Zoom out: SVBâ€™s downfall sent shockwaves through the banking sector. But banksâ€™ finances are in better shape now than they were in 2008, leaving experts optimistic that a full system meltdown is not on the horizon.â€”SK

President Biden laid out his ideal 2024 budget plan yesterday. Maybe we should say ideal-istic, because itâ€™s the White Houseâ€™s version of asking that no one gift wine at a white elephant. While the proposals are unlikely to be approved <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30788859.3375890/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zc0M_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc4ODg1OS4zMzc1ODkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C03cfc2b8> by the split Congress, they give a sneak peek of Bidenâ€™s policy priorities heading into the next election cycle.

The proposed budget rings in at $6.9 trillion (nice). Here are a few key items in the planâ€¦

Healthcare: The proposal would cap the price of insulin at $35 per month and empower Medicare to negotiate more drug prices. It would also make tax credits for health insurance premiums permanent.

Childcare: The child tax credit would increase from $2,000 to $3,600 per child and families could receive it even if they donâ€™t owe taxes.

Going to the moon: NASAâ€™s moon-bound Artemis program would get a budgetary boost <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30788859.3375890/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zc0Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc4ODg1OS4zMzc1ODkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C22efa435> of $500 million.

His other big goal? Reducing deficit spending by $3 trillion in the next decade to rein in the national debt.

Whoâ€™s paying for this?

Biden hopes to raise $4.7 trillion over 10 years by hiking taxes on the kind of folks whose couches arenâ€™t against a wall.

Higher taxes for the wealthy: The budget request would reverse Trump-era tax cuts on Americans making more than $400,000 and add a new 25% minimum tax on billionaires. For people making at least $1 million, the proposal would also double the tax rate on capital gains, or the profit made by selling assets like stocks, houses, and PokÃ©mon cards.

Higher taxes for corporations: Under the new plan, the corporate tax rate would jump to 28%, multinationalsâ€™ earnings abroad would be taxed at double the current rate, and the tax on stock buybacks would quadruple from its existing 1% rate.

Looking aheadâ€¦the GOP likes tax hikes as much as New Yorkers like a Los Angeles bagel, and the Republican-led House is already planning to reject Bidenâ€™s budget as proposed. But consider the budget an icebreakerâ€”or more like throwing the ice into an infernoâ€”to get conversations going.â€”JW

Visa, Mastercard, others pause plan to track gun shop purchases. Major payment networks halted their plan <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30788859.3375890/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zc0s_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc4ODg1OS4zMzc1ODkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C58b022bb> to implement a new merchant category code for sales at gun stores, citing legal uncertainty. Gun control advocates had hoped that by categorizing gun store purchases, payment giants would help authorities spot suspicious activity. But GOP lawmakers pushed back, arguing it would infringe on consumer protections. And several bills have been introduced in state legislatures that would ban this type of tracking if passed.

Allbirds stepped in some doo-doo. When you open Spotify today to blast Miley Cyrusâ€™s new album of breakup bops and future karaoke picks, the app might look a little different. The audio streamer has redesigned <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30788859.3375890/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zc1I_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc4ODg1OS4zMzc1ODkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce71cc422> its mobile app andâ€”surpriseâ€”it kind of looks like TikTok.

The most drastic changes include vertical, TikTok-like discovery feeds for music, podcasts, and audiobooks that let you scroll through previews of each type of content.

Spotify also introduced a â€œSmart Shuffleâ€ mode for premium subscribers that enables its algorithm to recommend putting new songs in your queue if you are listening to a playlist.

Once you finish a podcast episode, similar podcasts will autoplay.

Spotify's TikTokification joins the ranks of Reddit, Netflix, Instagram, and YouTube which have all doubled down on peopleâ€™s desire to only see shortened versions of everything while using their phones. Some of the new features started rolling out Wednesday, and the company announced more will come online soon.

RETAIL

How would you get rid of $1.3b worth of sneakers? <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30775253.2964846/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zblY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc3NTI1My4yOTY0ODQ2/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Da8798a47> Very ugly red Yeezys. <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30775253.2964846/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zblY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc3NTI1My4yOTY0ODQ2/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ea8798a47> Jeremy Moeller/Getty Images
Like everyone with a Deathly Hallows tattoo, Adidas is stuck <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30775253.2964846/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zblc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc3NTI1My4yOTY0ODQ2/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce4234f5d> with a very expensive reminder that a lot has changed in the last few years. The athletic brand is sitting on roughly $1.3 billion worth of Yeezy gear after cutting ties with Ye, formerly known as Kanye West, for his antisemitic comments. But the brand is not sure how to get rid of it.

Not everything ages like fine wine

During an earnings call yesterday, the new Adidas CEO BjÃ¸rn Gulden made it clear that ditching its unwanted Yeezy stock is a top priority. But the company is sort of stuck between a rock and an antisemitic sneaker:

Burning or trashing the gear would be unsustainable.

Donating the shoes could create a boom in the resale market.

Even if Adidas rebrands the items and sells them, Ye is still promised a cut of the profits.

The most likely option? Sell the kicks and donate the proceeds to charity. Gulden vaguely upvoted this solution in yesterdayâ€™s call saying, â€œIf we sell it, I promise that the people who have been hurt by this will also get something good out of this.â€

Big picture: Figuring out how to offload warehouses full of taboo merch isnâ€™t the only headache Gulden is dealing with following the companyâ€™s breakup with Ye. Adidas reported roughly $630 million in lost sales in Q4 of 2022 thanks to the split. Gulden cautioned investors not to have high hopes for 2023, calling it a â€œtransition year.â€ The company is also cutting dividends as it figures out a way to replace its $1.5 billion Ye collab.

Even bigger picture: The company is expecting an operating loss of over $730 million this year. The last time Adidas reported an annual loss, George H. W. Bush was president and Wayne'â€™s World was still a â€œnew movieâ€ (31 years ago).â€”MM

ECONOMY

The bond market is flashing a recession warning light <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30775253.2964846/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbzA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc3NTI1My4yOTY0ODQ2/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dbbbe5299> A dashboard with a check economy light flashing <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30775253.2964846/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbzA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc3NTI1My4yOTY0ODQ2/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ebbbe5299> Hannah Minn
At this point, it feels like economists have been predicting an imminent recession for so long that theyâ€™re starting to sound like that guy who insisted on spending December 31, 1999,Â  in a remote cabin because of Y2K. Still, one big recession warning signal reared its head this week.

What happened? When Jerome Powell told lawmakers Tuesday that recent strong economic data meant interest rates would likely climb higher than previously expected, it sent the markets into a tizzy, pushing the US Treasury yield curve to its deepest inversion <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30775253.2964846/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbzE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc3NTI1My4yOTY0ODQ2/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C75815fe0> since 1981.

And that meansâ€¦the yield for 2-year Treasury bonds exceeded the yield for 10-year onesâ€”by a lot. Itâ€™s considered an inversion whenever the short-term yield eclipses the long-term yield. It signifies that investors expect interest rates to rise in the near term but that those hikes will ultimately damage the economy, forcing rates back down over time.

What does it have to do with a recession? A yield curve inversion has happened before every recession since the 1960s, so itâ€™s definitely a more reliable prognosticator than your friend who has â€œa systemâ€ for their March Madness bracket.

Yeah, butâ€¦predicting the future is hard. Right now investors are freaked out by the Fed, but Powell is still trying to stick the (soft) landingâ€”even if this makes it look less likely.â€”AR

Forget being rich in friendships, folks, itâ€™s time to 10x that salary and start a side hustle dropshipping iPhone cases. A new study <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30775253.2964846/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbzY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc3NTI1My4yOTY0ODQ2/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C46886d60> found that happiness rises with income levelâ€”even accelerating at levels beyond $100,000 per year up to $500,000 per year.

Millionaires and billionaires might be even happier: The studyâ€™s authors just didnâ€™t have conclusive data for salaries beyond that range (those folks are probably too happy to take surveys). This new information upends an oft-cited 2010 study that found happiness plateaued near a salary of $75,000, or ~$103k today, after inflation.

In the new study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, two prominent researchers (including Daniel Kahneman, the Nobel Prize winner who wrote that 2010 paper) surveyed 33,391 US adults between the ages of 18 and 65 with household incomes of at least $10,000. Participants logged their happiness level when prompted at random times throughout the day via an app.

A caveat: While more money does lead to more happiness for most people, itâ€™s not the only factor, and its emotional effect is small compared to other considerations, like time off from work. â€œAn approximately four-fold difference in income is about equal to the effect of a weekend,â€ the study said.â€”MK

TRAVEL

The DOJ is aiming to split up JetBlueâ€™s Spirit takeover <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30763746.2968171/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbDQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc2Mzc0Ni4yOTY4MTcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D6a9f0c2c> A combination Spirit and JetBlue plane <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30763746.2968171/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbDQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc2Mzc0Ni4yOTY4MTcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E6a9f0c2c> Photo Illustration: Dianna â€œMickâ€ McDougall, Source: Getty Images
The Biden administration is continuing its full-court press strategy against airline consolidation. Yesterday, the Justice Department sued <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30763746.2968171/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbDU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc2Mzc0Ni4yOTY4MTcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C87a30ade> to block JetBlueâ€™s planned $3.8 billion takeover of Spirit Airlines, claiming that theÂ  acquisition would raise fares for consumers and decrease options in an industry already known for only having pretzels or peanuts.

Spirit, with its no snacks, 28 inches of legroom, and no-recline seats, isnâ€™t exactly anyoneâ€™s top choice for travel, but it is the nationâ€™s largest ultra-low-cost airline. And, according to the DOJ, Spirit getting scooped up would eliminate about half of all ultra-low-cost seats in the industry, sending ticket prices (which are already skyrocketing) up even further.

For the Biden administrationâ€™s DOJ, with its hardline attitude against mergers it considers to be anti-competitive, thatâ€™s unacceptable.

Why would prices go up?

According to internal company documents that the DOJ cites in its complaint, when Spirit starts flying a given route, average fares fall by 17%. Meanwhile, JetBlue estimates that when Spirit stops flying a route, average fares shoot up by 30%.

JetBlue has claimed that by increasing its size with the purchase of Spirit, it could better compete with the â€œbig fourâ€ airlines: United, Delta, American, and Southwest. But according to the DOJ, JetBlue isnâ€™t the disruptive force it once was, and has instead evolved into an â€œally of the big four.â€

In response to the lawsuit, JetBlue CEO Robin Hayes argued that the merger was not like Pepsi buying Coke, and instead would make his company a â€œdistant fifth-largest airlineâ€â€”a Dr Pepper, you might say.

Zoom out: The last big merger in the airline industry happened in 2016 when Alaska Airlines acquired Virgin America. According to airlines.org, there have been 21 completed US airline mergers since 2001. That consolidation has made it hard for new competition to enter: Between 2007 and 2021, not a single new airline startup was formed in the country.â€”MK

HEALTH

Study finds a popular sugar substitute might be bad for your heart <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30763746.2968171/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbGg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc2Mzc0Ni4yOTY4MTcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D3a00bc30> Sugar substitute gravestone <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30763746.2968171/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbGg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc2Mzc0Ni4yOTY4MTcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E3a00bc30> Francis Scialabba
A recent study <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30763746.2968171/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbGk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc2Mzc0Ni4yOTY4MTcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C0dbbd7fe> published in Nature Medicine found that the sugar alternative erythritol is associated with an increased risk of heart issues and strokes.

Our bodies produce small amounts of the compound naturally, but itâ€™s also increasingly found in many processed foods, especially â€œsugar-freeâ€ products and even some toothpaste.

What did the study find?

Scientists explored the link between levels of different chemicals in the blood and the risk of heart disease.

Patients with more erythritol in their system had a higher chance of having a stroke, suffering a heart attack, or dying within three years.

It was also tied to an increased risk of blood clots in mice and human blood samples.

While erythritol is linked to health issues, it is not necessarily a cause. Itâ€™s also unclear how worried folks without medical conditions should be, as the study mostly followed a population that was already prone to heart disease (due to conditions like diabetes or high blood pressure).

Zoom out: The researchers are recommending further investigation so we can better understand whether erythritol ought to be proclaimed unsafe. In the meantime, one of the studyâ€™s authors, Dr. Stanley Hazen, is telling his patients to skip the sweetener and opt for a couple of drops of honey or a pinch of sugar instead.â€”SK

Stat: Americans whoâ€™ve had a bad experience with a product or service are increasingly airing their grievances <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30763746.2968171/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zbG0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc2Mzc0Ni4yOTY4MTcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ca5f3d79c> just like Frank Costanza. According to the National Customer Rage Survey, 9% of consumers who had a bone to pick with a company took â€œrevengeâ€ by shaming them in public (on social media or IRL). Thatâ€™s up from 3% in 2020, but significantly lower than the 17% average during the revenge-seeking golden age of 2003â€“2017.
