TRANSPORTATION

E-bike batteries are exploding and setting buildings on fire <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1U_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D5840dc0f> Two people on e-bikes in the street <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1U_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E5840dc0f> Spencer Platt/Getty Images
Everyone and their neighbor seemingly got an e-bike during the pandemic, but their surge in popularity has come with a nasty side effect: exploding batteries <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1Y_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd68fdc4b> that spark deadly fires. The problem is especially evident in New York City, where on Sunday an e-bike battery sparked <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1c_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb4acda81> an hourslong blaze at a Bronx grocery store that injured seven.

Itâ€™s the latest in a string of fires started by the lithium-ion batteries in electric bikes and scooters. Theyâ€™ve caused at least 30 fires, 40 injuries, and two deaths in NYC this year, as of Feb. 27, according to the New York Fire Department.

Last year, they ignited 216 firesâ€”double the amount of the year beforeâ€”resulting in 147 injuries and six deaths.

Lithium-ion batteries were the fourth leading cause of fire deaths in NYC last year, per the FDNY.

The number of blazes has been rising in tandem with the number of e-bikes sold: The US imported over 1 million last year, a gear shift up from 880,000 in 2021 and 450,000 in 2020, according to the Light Electric Vehicle Association.

Whatâ€™s so dangerous about an e-bike battery?

Itâ€™s about the batteries. Lithium-ion batteries are a Nobel-prize-winning invention that power everything from phones to computers to electric vehicles. These batteries are safe unless theyâ€™re faulty or damaged <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1g_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C8e1df9d4>, and e-bikes and e-scooters are subject to a lot of hard use hauling commuters and delivery workers up and over NYCâ€™s bridges.

The batteries are also expensive (about $300 each), so low-quality and secondhand alternatives, which are more likely to be defective, have flooded the market.

Itâ€™s unlikely an e-bike will spontaneously combust midride beneath your butt. Instead, they become a hazard while in storage or when theyâ€™ve been left unattended on a charger (where they overheat).

The fires they cause are nightmarish: Lithium-ion battery fires can engulf a room in about 15 seconds, per the UL Fire Safety Research Institute. In addition, the toxic gases they release make them especially difficult to put out.

Thereâ€™s a solution in the works

The New York City Council approved several bills last week that 1) add new safety and certification standards for micromobility vehicles 2) launch educational campaigns on safe usage and 3) restrict the use and sale of secondhand batteries.

Itâ€™s the cityâ€™s alternative to an outright ban, which London enacted for e-scooters in 2021 after it faced its own battery fire problem.â€”JW

WORLD

Tour de headlines Governor Gavin Newsom speaks at a press conference on Wednesday, Feb. 9, 2022 Aric Crabb/MediaNews Group/East Bay Times via Getty Images
California is â€œdoneâ€ with Walgreens. CA Gov. Gavin Newsom tweeted that the state will stop doing business <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1E_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ccf881c00> with Walgreens over the pharmacy chainâ€™s decision not to sell abortion pills in 20 GOP-led states. Walgreens and CVS have been threatened with legal action by Republican attorneys general if they distribute abortion medication in those states. But Newsom is not impressed, writing that Walgreensâ€™s move â€œcowers to the extremists and puts womenâ€™s lives at risk.â€

US to go full Gandalf with proposed airline merger. Thatâ€™s a â€œYou shall not pass!â€ reference, btw. The Department of Justice and Department of Transportation are expected to launch an attempt to block <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1M_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd543dfcc> a proposed $3.8 billion merger between JetBlue and Spirit as soon as today. The DOJ will sue on antitrust grounds, arguing that a tie-up would harm flyers by raising prices and decreasing options. And in a highly unusual move, the DOT is expected to try and block the transfer of Spiritâ€™s airline operating certificate.

Toblerone loses its Swissness. The brand is ditching <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ1I_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C6c0f7f00> the iconic Matterhorn mountain image and Swiss flag from its packaging because of the most European reason possible: Itâ€™s breaking Swiss government rules about what can be promoted as a Swiss product. The Swissness Act of 2017 put guardrails around how companies can use certain Swiss symbols in their marketing, but Toblerone will no longer meet the Swissness criteria as it shifts some production to Slovakia.



TOGETHER WITH MONOGRAM

A robot we kneed <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ2Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4JmxwPXRpdGxl/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce79e9b8a> Monogram <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ2Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4JmxwPWltYWdl/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd3255a1b>
With over 93k knee replacements yearly, knee reconstruction surgery is one of the most significant orthopedic issues. Which means doctors must have perfected the procedure by now, right?

Wrong. 20% of all patients experience chronic pain after surgery, and there are over 100k revision surgeries a year. Thatâ€™s why Monogramâ€™s attempting to change the status quo <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ2Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4JmxwPXRleHQx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C6c5bde77>.

Their 2-pronged approach has the potential to eventually rework conventional knee surgery completely, thanks to:

3D-printed joints custom made <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ2Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4JmxwPXRleHQy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7ae8c12e> for each patient

precision surgical robots that minimize invasive techniques and human error

Whatâ€™s this all mean? Two words: investment opportunity. You can invest in Monogram <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ2Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4JmxwPXRleHQz/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C02643b50> to get in on this game-changing new technology before their planned Nasdaq listing.



TRAVEL

Turbulent times for air travel <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ18_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D586ec7d7> Airplane affected by turbulence <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZ18_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E586ec7d7> Hannah Minn
We regret to inform you that there are shakes on the plane.

A series of extreme turbulence incidents in early 2023 has air travelers wondering why the seatbelt sign has been left on so much lately. Last week alone, turbulence was responsible for: at least seven injuries aboard a transatlantic Lufthansa red-eye <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zaDA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf33a20cb>, the aborted landing of a North Carolina-bound Southwest flight <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zaDE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C4d9a9d5e>, and a passenger death <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zaDI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce0d9ca5c> on a business jet traveling between New Hampshire and Virginia.

Are the skies becoming more treacherous?

Research shows that the chances of having a turbulent flight are increasing and that a changing climate might be the culprit.

Climate change makes atmospheric air currents more unstable and winds faster, causing rockier skies.

Itâ€™s also elevating the risk of clear-air turbulence, which appears out of the blue and gives pilots little time to order passengers to buckle up.

But in general, you should still be more concerned about the prospect of a canceled flight than a shaky one.

Extreme turbulence is still very rare and not usually dangerous. Only 146 people were seriously injured by severe turbulence between 2009 and 2021, per the Federal Aviation Administrationâ€”and most were not wearing their seatbelts. Airplanes are designed to withstand intense shaking, while pilots are trained to safely navigate intense windâ€¦even if your plane meatloaf sticks to the aircraft ceiling.â€”SK

A storm drain? Who cares. But a storm drain officially named Stormy Drainels? Thatâ€™s something to cherish.

Municipalities across the US know this, so theyâ€™re increasingly holding <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30749356.2968168/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zaDc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDc0OTM1Ni4yOTY4MTY4/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf3ef9d24> online naming contests to christen fixtures like snowplows, sewer grates, and garbage trucks in a bid to increase public awareness of the services available and the workers who perform them, the WSJ reports.

The Madison, Wisconsin, snowplow naming contest results came in late last month, resulting in five newly deputized plows: Saltimus Prime, Snowbi Wan Kenobi, Seymour Pavement, and Dolly Plowton.

Madison isnâ€™t the only city with named plows. Some highlights from around the US include:

Fuhgeddaplowdit (New Paltz, NY)

Plowy McPlowFace (St. Paul, MN)

Steve (North Hero, VT)

Other pieces of equipment around the country have also gotten the pun treatment. A storm drain in Minnesota is named Drain â€œThe Blockâ€ Johnson, a street sweeper in Virginia has been dubbed â€œMF BROOM,â€ and a garbage truck in Indiana now goes by â€œBin Diesel.â€

Whereâ€™d this come from? The idea of naming municipal equipment seems to have been spawned in Scotland, where a 2006 primary school contest to name gritters (snowplows) caught on in a big way. All 240 plows operated by Transport Scotland now have names.â€”MK

Markets: Stocks broke out of their slump last week, but investors are still facing black-diamond-level conditions in this jittery market. As usual, the Fed is playing the boogeyman: In recent comments, officials have begun to signal that they plan to raise rates higher and for longer to tame stubborn inflation.

Stock spotlight: Formula One shares reached a record high as the racing season began in Bahrain yesterday. Max Verstappen shares are also at a record high.

BUSINESS

More companies are selling a â€˜first-classâ€™ experience <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30739367.3376090/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zY1g_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDczOTM2Ny4zMzc2MDkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D376303af> How I met your mother GIF <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30739367.3376090/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zY1g_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDczOTM2Ny4zMzc2MDkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E376303af> How I Met Your Mother/CBS via Giphy
To begin this story, I want to jog your memory: Have you recently bought a higher-quality product even though it costs more? Hulu without ads? Fancy jeans? A Le Creuset instead of a regular olâ€™ Dutch oven?

Companies are hyperfocused on attracting that particular kind of customer right now. According to the NYT, theyâ€™re going all-in on â€œpremiumization <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30739367.3376090/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zY1k_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDczOTM2Ny4zMzc2MDkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf6437bb6>,â€ which is a strategy to entice customers to pay more for what is perceived as a better-quality product or service.

Premiumization isnâ€™t new. Starbucks famously did it with coffee in the 1990s, and airlines have been dangling a luxurious first-class experience for decades. Premiumization has been especially popular in the consumer goods space <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30739367.3376090/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zY1o_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDczOTM2Ny4zMzc2MDkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C16f98ac8>.

But whatâ€™s new is the breadth of companies that are trying to extract more $$$ from their wealthiest customers. Execs referenced the premiumization concept in close to 60 earnings calls and investor meetings in the past several weeks, per the New York Times. A few examples:

Krispy Kreme, which offered bargain deals last year, is now aiming to generate â€œexcitement around our premium specialty doughnuts.â€

Six Flags has raised prices â€œin order to elevate the guest experience.â€

Even WD-40 is souping up its cans with things like a â€œsmart strawâ€ to get consumers to pay more.

Why is this happening?

Companies facing slowdowns in other areas see growth opportunities in upselling their wealthiest customers, who are sitting on more than $1 trillion in excess savings since the pandemic.

And those customers seem willing to play along. â€œAll around the world, people are spending more <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30739367.3376090/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zYy0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDczOTM2Ny4zMzc2MDkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C155c6872> on better products,â€ Lâ€™OrÃ©alâ€™s CEO Nicolas Hieronimus recently said. â€œThe pandemic has generated this desire to pamper yourself.â€

Big picture: The urge to focus on premium products could result in fewer options for lower-income Americans, who spend a greater share of their income on essentials like housing and food, the NYT notes.

The auto market is already out of reach for many Americans. At the end of 2022, only 10 car models were priced below $25,000, compared to 36 at the end of 2017.

UN agrees to protect the seas. In a deal decades in the making, more than 190 countries established a framework <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30739367.3376090/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZDI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDczOTM2Ny4zMzc2MDkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cdce3d5d9> to protect marine life on the â€œhigh seasâ€â€”which are the 60% of the worldâ€™s oceans that lie outside of national boundaries. Currently, only 1.2% of those areas are protected, but the UN High Seas Treaty hopes to turn 30% of international waters into protected areas by 2030. Almost 10% of global marine species are at risk of extinction, per the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

Gov. Ron DeSantis, the champion of this conservative agenda, is expected to run for president in 2024.

Despite a cyclone of headlines and hype, ChatGPT remains almost as unpopular on campus as the overachiever who asks a question when the professor is about to end class.

In a survey of 520 US college students, a Morning Brew/Generation Lab poll <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30739367.3376090/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zZDY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDczOTM2Ny4zMzc2MDkw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cbc2c5055> found that 40% have never heard of the chatbot from OpenAI.

Of those who have heard of ChatGPT, 52% have never used it.

And the students who said they do fire up ChatGPTâ€¦donâ€™t use it all that much, as 55% of respondents who said theyâ€™ve used ChatGPT do so â€œalmost never.â€

Of course, ChatGPT was released just a few months agoâ€”so in a sense it is quite remarkable that 60% of college students have heard of it. Still, it hasnâ€™t made major inroads on college campuses yet, even while many instructors warn the new tech could create havoc in the classroom.

Uses for ChatGPT

Among the students who do use ChatGPTâ€¦what are they using it for?

For giggles: 71% of students whoâ€™ve used ChatGPT said they use it in part for entertainment or just for fun.

As Google: 32% of students whoâ€™ve used ChatGPT said they use it in part for quick answers to simple questions, and 31% to understand complex topics.

Forâ€¦cheating? 17% of students whoâ€™ve heard of ChatGPT said they have direct knowledge of friends having used ChatGPT to cheat.

Ooni <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30728929.102437/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zOEg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcyODkyOS4xMDI0MzcmbHA9bG9nbw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce8f135bc> 
Good morning. Cocaine Bear has only been in theaters for one week but a potential sequel has already emerged: Cocaine Hippo. It wouldnâ€™t be about a hippo on cocaine, but instead about the community of hippos thatâ€™s flourished in Colombia thanks to Pablo Escobar. In the late 1970s, the cocaine kingpin imported four hippos to his estate, and in the decades since those four have multiplied into a small village of 130.

Now, with hippos considered an invasive species in Colombia, authorities want to capture 70 and send them to sanctuaries abroad. Elizabeth Banksâ€”you have our number.

â€”Sam Klebanov, Matty Merritt, Max Knoblauch, Abby Rubenstein, Neal Freyman

BUSINESS

Amazon hits pause on 2nd headquarters <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30728929.102437/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zY24_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcyODkyOS4xMDI0Mzc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Da1967c56> Construction worker looking up at building <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30728929.102437/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zY24_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcyODkyOS4xMDI0Mzc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ea1967c56> The Washington Post/Getty Images
Amazonâ€™s HQ2 is starting to look more like HQ1.5. The e-commerce giant announced yesterday that itâ€™s halting the construction of its much-hyped second headquarters in Arlington, VA.

Construction status update

The first part of the project, Metropolitan Park, is on track for a ribbon cutting this summer.

Breaking ground on the swanky office park known as PenPlace, which would encompass three 22-story towers and a sleek helix-shaped building, has been put off indefinitely.

Met Park can accommodate 14,000 workers, which is more than enough for Amazonâ€™s 8,000 local employees. And headcount is unlikely to skyrocket any time soon: Amazon began laying off 18,000 employees in January (the steepest job cuts in its history).

Plans and promises

Amazon chose the DC area as the site of its HQ2 in 2018, after a cutthroat bidding battle among dozens of cities nationwide that resembled the municipal version of The Bachelor.

The company promised to bring 25,000 jobs to the region and turbocharge the local economy in exchange for $800 million in tax benefits and infrastructure improvements.

It says it does plan to build PenPlace and reach the workforce goal eventually. But for now, itâ€™s not short on office space: Its employees still spend a lot of time working from home, even after a recent companywide mandate to come into the office three days a week.

The company is also reducing its physical footprint elsewhere. It vacated an office tower in its hometown, Seattle, earlier this year.

Zoom out: Amazonâ€™s pause on its Northern Virginia expansion is part of a bigger trend. Big Tech companies like Meta and Twitter have cut down on their real estate footprint to save money. And itâ€™s just one of the many ominous signs for the commercial real estate market since people no longer go into the office every workday.â€”SK

Stat: Instant noodles can be dangerous for kids, and not just because one serving is packed with several monthsâ€™ worth of sodium. Researchers at the University of Chicago found that almost one-third of childhood burn injuries <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30728929.102437/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zY0Y_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcyODkyOS4xMDI0Mzc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cebc4a0b8> can be attributed to the slurpy snack. Between 2010 and 2020, 31% of kids who checked into the university hospitalâ€™s burn center with injuries said instant noodles were the cause. To reduce the risk, the researchers suggest having an adult take the noodle cup out of the microwave and then keep it from the kids until it cools down a bit.

Itâ€™s no secret that the government considers TikTok a national security threat. But in an interview with Bloomberg <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zN1o_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cee8295dd> yesterday, Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo suggested that the government is concerned about the dangers posed by other Chinese apps, too.

â€œIf what weâ€™re worried about is Chinese-backed companies being on tens of millions of American phones, including members of the military and privacy concerns, data concerns, misinformation concernsâ€”it doesnâ€™t just apply to TikTok,â€ she said.

Thing is, Chinese apps are the most popular apps in the US right now. The top three free apps on Appleâ€™s App Store yesterday were Temu, CapCut, and TikTok, while Google Playâ€™s were Temu, TikTok, and Street Fighter: Duelâ€”with Chinese fast-fashion company Shein chilling at No. 4.

Except for Street Fighter, all of these apps are based in China and have been downloaded onto American devices hundreds of millions of times.

CapCut is a video editor for TikTok owned by the same tech giant, ByteDance.

Temu is a shopping app that was already gaining traction in the US late last year but boarded a rocket ship to the most-downloaded spot after airing two spots for its â€œShop Like a Billionaireâ€ commercial during the Super Bowl.

For now, TikTok has the biggest target <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zNy0_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C9f185885> on its back:

Legislation to ban TikTok in the US was approved by an influential House committee this week, though it still has to face trials by fire with the full House and Senate.

Government agencies have 30 days from Feb. 27 to ensure TikTok is deleted from all federal devices and systems.

Experts canâ€™t agree on whether Chinese apps are a threat

An exec at the think tank founded by former Google CEO Eric Schmidt wrote last month <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zN18_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb49438b8> that all of these uber-popular Chinese apps, including the messenger WeChat and game apps from Tencent, â€œcould pose similar challenges [to TikTok], particularly with respect to data harvesting, data exploitation, andâ€”possiblyâ€”covert influence.â€

Higher mortgage rates combined with already astronomical home prices have led to the most unaffordable housing market on record, per Bloomberg.

Alex Murdaugh found guilty of murder. A jury convicted <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zOEM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2ad6124e> the disbarred South Carolina lawyer of murder in the shooting deaths of his wife and son in 2021. Progress on the gender pay gap has stalled. US women earned an average of 82% <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zODU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf9ec3950> of what men earned in 2022, according to a new Pew Research Center analysis. Thatâ€™s just a slight uptick from the 80% women earned relative to men 20 years before, in 2002. The study shows how the progress made on the gender pay gap in the late 20th century has petered out in 21st, despite women now having higher educational attainment than men. In 1982, women earned an average of 65% of what men earned.

A once-in-a-generation snowstorm has buried <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zODc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C340ac8b3> the West Coast.

But just in the last week, California has been hit with an obscene amount of fresh pow. On Wednesday, Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency for 13 counties, including San Bernardinoâ€”where some towns will likely be cut off from the rest of the state for weeks.

Californiaâ€™s Joshua Tree National Park closed on Wednesday because of inclement weather. And thereâ€™s no reopening date in sight for Yosemite National Park, which has been shut down since Saturday.

For ski resorts, itâ€™s too much of a good thing. Mountain High in Southern California averages 67 inches of snowfall every season. But its slopes received 93 inches (about eight feet) last week alone. Unfortunately, Mountain High and other SoCal resorts are still snowed in and are at the mercy of unplowed highways.

FOOD & BEV

Whiskey fungus pits locals against Jack Daniel's <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zOGM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D155a48c2> Jack Daniel's whiskey <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zOGM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E155a48c2> SOPA Images/Getty Images
Turns out there are more cons to living near a bourbon distillery than just the obvious (having a million gingham shirt bachelor-party guys stumble around your neighborhood every year).

An out-of-control, soot-like whiskey fungus is spreading in Tennessee and causing a rift <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30714817.2969871/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8zOGQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDcxNDgxNy4yOTY5ODcx/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C77560b1e> between residents and famed whiskey-maker Jack Danielâ€™s.

The fungus, named Baudoinia compniacensis after a distiller who first made note of it in the 1870s, feeds off of ethanol vapors released during the whiskey aging process. For months, residents of a rural Tennessee county where Jack Danielâ€™s has six barrelhouses (and plans to build up to 20) have complained that the fungus coats basically all outdoor surfaces, including trees, house siding, and patio furniture.

Studies have shown that the fungus isnâ€™t hazardous to humansâ€”and it dirties but doesnâ€™t damage propertyâ€”but residents are nonetheless peeved with Jack Danielâ€™s over its spread, filing a lawsuit thatâ€™s ultimately forced the company to stop construction on a new barrelhouse.

Residents are asking for Jack Danielâ€™s to fund an environmental study to see if the vapors or fungus harm humans, and install an air filtration system to slow their spread. The company has resisted installing filters and claims it could impact the whiskeyâ€™s flavor.â€”MK

GRAB BAG

Friday puzzle

Weâ€™ll give you five words and five definitions. Each word can be anagrammed into a two-word phrase that matches one of the definitions. Then, you have to assign each definition to its corresponding word.

Example: Given the word â€œcobalt,â€ you could rearrange it to â€œcat lobâ€ and match the definition â€œto hit a feline in a high arc.â€

Words

Chameleon, medium, physical, president, tungsten

Definitions

a boat constructed of thick mud-like soil

a cozy canvas shelter

a device for trapping tarantulas

a not-too-bright bird

a tidy house

  TOGETHER WITH

Huel <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWEs_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjYmbHA9bG9nbw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C53ce0314>  
Good morning. Itâ€™s the 28th and final day of February. Have you wondered why February is shorter than the other months? Turns out, we have ancient Roman superstitions to thank.

To make a long story short, Roman king Numa Pompilius tweaked the calendar to sync it with the lunar year, which included changing every month to 29 days (because even numbers were unlucky at that time). One month, though, needed to have an even number of days, and February was selected since it was when the Romans held rituals for the dead.

And so, February was dropped down to 28 days. And despite numerous changes to the calendar over thousands of years, itâ€™s (mostly) stuck.

â€”Max Knoblauch, Sam Klebanov, Jamie Wilde, Abby Rubenstein, Neal Freyman

DEBT

Understanding the SCOTUS student loan forgiveness arguments <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dc1551ca9> SCOTUS student debt <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ec1551ca9> Francis Scialabba
The fate of the Biden administrationâ€™s student loan forgiveness planâ€”and the monthly budget of tens of millions of Americansâ€”rests on oral arguments that the Supreme Court will hear <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc5beb551> today.

Given the courtâ€™s 6â€“3 conservative majority, many legal experts see a tough road ahead for the ~$430 billion debt relief program. The conservative SCOTUS has reined in Bidenâ€™s executive power multiple times already, from throwing out his administrationâ€™s eviction moratorium and large business vaccination-or-testing requirement, to significantly dampening the EPAâ€™s power to fight climate change.

So, whatâ€™s the court expected to hear today? Letâ€™s take a look.

Itâ€™s about harm

There are two legal challenges to debt cancellation:

One from six Republican-led states (Arkansas, Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, and South Carolina)

Another from two Texas borrowers backed by a conservative advocacy group

Before SCOTUS can issue any ruling on the Biden administrationâ€™s constitutional authority to cancel debt, it must first decide if these challengers have standing to sueâ€”i.e., if any of them are specifically harmed by debt cancellation.

So far, lower courts have found that they are. The GOP states have standing thanks to a semi-independent loan servicing company, MOHELA, created by the state of Missouri, a court ruled. Missouri has argued that since MOHELA would lose money if there were fewer loans to service, it would put less money into a state education fund, and the state would be sufficiently harmed. A different court ruled that the two Texas borrowers have standing, as neither fully qualified for forgiveness under the program.

The Biden administration is expected to lean heavily on this question, arguing that none of the plaintiffs have sufficient standing to challenge the loan cancellation program. Many experts see this tactic as the administrationâ€™s best chance to win since it would be easier than convincing the justices of its power to cancel debt.

Zoom out: The Biden administration has said that whatever the courtâ€™s decision is, the student loan payment pause thatâ€™s been in place for almost three years will end 60 days after the case is resolved (or at the end of August, whichever comes first). SCOTUS is expected to announce its ruling before the courtâ€™s term ends in late June.â€”MK

Tour de headlines Rupert Murdoch, CEO of News Corp. Axelle/Bauer-Griffin/FilmMagic
Murdoch admits Fox hosts â€œendorsedâ€ false election fraud claims. Rupert Murdoch stated under oath that Fox News hosts, including Sean Hannity and Jeanine Pirro, had â€œendorsedâ€ <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWVk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cddb73745> dubious claims that the 2020 election was stolen, according to a legal filing by Dominion Voting Systems. â€œI would have liked us to be stronger in denouncing it in hindsight,â€ the media mogul said during a deposition. Dominion has a $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit pending against Fox over the claims, but Fox maintains they were newsworthy.

The Supreme Court will decide a financial regulatorâ€™s fate. The justices agreed yesterday to consider a case <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C22284022> challenging how the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is funded. The financial watchdog, which was created in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, gets its cash directly from the Fed rather than from Congress, but the conservative 5th Circuit Court of Appeals found that scheme unconstitutional. The Biden administration says that calls into question every rule the agency has ever made and every enforcement action it has taken.

Move over, Mickey. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signed a bill yesterday granting him power over the special district <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C527edb35> where Disney World is located, which Disney has controlled since the 1960s. DeSantis went after the special district when Disney came out against a law he backed, known as the â€œDonâ€™t Say Gayâ€ bill by critics. â€œToday the corporate kingdom finally comes to an end,â€ the governor, who is expected to launch a presidential run soon, said at the signing ceremony.

TRADE

UK and EU shake on a Northern Ireland trade deal <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D0e924d85> UK PM Rishi Sunak and President of EC Ursula von der Leyennt shaking hands <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E0e924d85> Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
Diplomats are cracking a Guinness after making major progress on the peskiest Brexit issue: The United Kingdom and the European Union hammered out a deal <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWXo_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc9e82279> over Northern Ireland trade yesterday.

Why the deal is a big deal

The UKâ€“EU divorce generated the problem of handling the only land border between them, the one separating Northern Ireland (part of the UK) and the Republic of Ireland (a separate country thatâ€™s in the EU). Imposing typical customs controls wouldâ€™ve been risky: The open border between them is a legacy of the Good Friday Agreement that ended decades of political violence known as â€œthe Troubles.â€

As a workaround, the UK and EU signed the Northern Ireland Protocol in 2019, which preserved the frictionless border status quo. Instead, customs checks were introduced for goods moving from the island of Great Britain (which encompasses England, Scotland, and Wales) to Northern Ireland. The new agreement builds on this arrangement.

Whatâ€™s in the deal?

There will now be minimal customs controls for trade between Great Britain and Northern Ireland, while goods transiting into the Republic of Ireland will be checked normally.

The Protocol left some EU laws in place in Northern Ireland, but the new agreement pares that number down.

Looking aheadâ€¦The agreement isnâ€™t a done deal until it passes through the UK Parliament (where there is likely to be opposition from hardline Brexiters and Northern Irish parties) and parts of it get the go-ahead from the EUâ€™s 27 member states.â€”SK

Need a refresher on the difference between the UK, Great Britain, and England? TOGETHER WITH RAD DIVERSIFIED

RAD Diversified <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWEw_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjYmbHA9aW1hZ2U/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C55510a05>
Tough times call for smarter investments. REITs (aka real estate investment trusts) are ready to handle any economic era, as theyâ€™re unaffected by the stock market. And RAD Diversified <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWEw_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjYmbHA9dGV4dDE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C8197ae34> is one that stands out: They invest in real estate properties across the US, with a 35.35% return in 2021 and 122.2% increased stock value since October 2019. WORK

More Americans are choosing the part-time life <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWUU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dda8342e4> A hand with a clock <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWUU_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Eda8342e4> Hannah Minn
Over a million Americans joined the part-time workforce in December and Januaryâ€”and most of them chose the temporary grind over a full-time hustle, according to Labor Department data analyzed by the WSJ.

Key word: chose. As of last month, over 22 million part-timers were working fewer than 35 hours per week voluntarily, compared to just 4 million that wanted full-time hours and couldnâ€™t get them. That nearly six-to-one ratio is the highest itâ€™s been <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWUY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1c71d9e0> in two decades, per the WSJ.

Why the downshift?

Early in the pandemic, the number of Americans doing part-time work â€œfor economic reasons,â€ as the Labor Department classifies it, spiked as layoffs rocked the economy, peaking in April 2020. But after that, the vibe shifted: More people started choosing to work part-time â€œfor noneconomic reasons,â€ such as caregiving and personal health.

And there may be more 9-to-5ers waiting for the chance to clear their G Cals. â€œA lot of people want to work part-time, but the options arenâ€™t really there,â€ Ernie Park, who left his full-time tech job to take an hourly gig and start a family farm, told the WSJ. â€œFor companies that get on this, they can scoop up some really great talent.â€â€”JW

Key performance indicators Jeff Reitz, world record holder for most consecutive visit to Disneyland Jeff Gritchen/MediaNews Group/Orange County Register/Getty Images
Stat: This guy has been to Disneyland more than you. His name is Jeff Reitz, and he was recently deemed a world-record <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30675860.101966/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yWUo_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY3NTg2MC4xMDE5NjY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C788e9aa2> holder for making 2,995 consecutive visits to the theme park. Thatâ€™s one trip to Sleeping Beauty Castle per day for eight years, three months, and 13 days. We donâ€™t know whether he considers himself more of an Anna or an Elsa, but we do know that he started visiting as a way to stay active while unemployed in 2012 and kept returning daily until Covid shut down the park in 2020.

Answer
Answer: August was the most popular baby name of all the months. It was the 121st most popular name for males, according to the SSA.

For females, the most popular was June, coming in 175th place (more than 10 spots above Molly, interestingly).

HEALTH

New report reignites lab leak debate <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30665546.3404422/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yVmY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY2NTU0Ni4zNDA0NDIy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D8445050c> P4 laboratory at the Wuhan Institute of Virology in Wuhan in China's central Hubei province on April 17, 2020 <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30665546.3404422/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yVmY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY2NTU0Ni4zNDA0NDIy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E8445050c> Hector Retamal/AFP via Getty Images
Nearly three years after the Covid-19 pandemic shut down much of the world, we still donâ€™t know how it started.

But the Department of Energy is ready to submit its best guess. In a new report based on fresh intelligence, the agency has concluded <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30665546.3404422/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yVmc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY2NTU0Ni4zNDA0NDIy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7f399837> that Covid-19 most likely spread to humans as a result of a mistake at a Chinese laboratory (aka the â€œlab leakâ€ theory), the WSJ reports.

Important note: In making this determination, the Energy Dept. is about as self-assured as any Michael Cera characterâ€”it reportedly has â€œlow confidenceâ€ that this theory is correct.

Also, why would the Energy Dept. have information about a pandemicâ€™s origins? Little-known fact: The Energy Dept. oversees a network of 17 national laboratories, and some of those labs do advanced bioresearch. The agency frequently leverages this lab network to gather information, rather than relying on typical intelligence operations, according to the NYT.

But thereâ€™s still no consensus

In endorsing the lab leak theory, the Energy Dept. joins the FBI, which has concluded with â€œmoderate confidenceâ€ that Covid originated accidentally from a Chinese lab: the Wuhan Institute of Virology. The two agencies reportedly arrived at this conclusion via different methods.

However, four other US agencies and the National Intelligence Council have concluded that Covid originated through natural transmission from an infected animal. But they, too, have low confidence their conclusions are correct.

One piece of evidence thatâ€™s missing from the natural transmission theory? The animal that hypothetically did the infecting hasnâ€™t been identified. Given all this uncertainty, two other US agencies havenâ€™t reached a conclusion on Covidâ€™s beginnings yet.

So, if youâ€™re doing the math at home: Four US agencies believe it was natural transmission, two say lab leak, and two are undecided.

Zoom out: Scientists say itâ€™s important to make every effort to learn how Covid-19, a pandemic thatâ€™s caused nearly 7 million deaths globally, began, so we can better prevent the next one.

But with the Chinese government thwarting investigations by global authorities, there may only be so much information the US can gather. And it might never be able to confidently answer the question: How did Covid begin?

Dilbert dropped by major newspapers. Mediterranean migrant tragedy. The boat had set sail from Turkey and was carrying at least 150 people from countries including Afghanistan, Somalia, Pakistan, and Iran. In time. Thatâ€™s not a phrase you often hear associated with baseball, but youâ€™d better get used to it because this season, baseball has entered its Sonic the Hedgehog era.

Over concerns itâ€™s getting disrupted by faster-paced sports, MLB is disrupting itself by introducing new rules <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30665546.3404422/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yVnA_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY2NTU0Ni4zNDA0NDIy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3d72c436> this year to speed up the game and generate more offense. These rules includeâ€¦

A pitch clock so pitchers (and hitters) canâ€™t loaf around in between pitches.

The elimination of extreme defensive shifts to encourage more offense.

Bigger bases to boost the number of stolen bases.

Limiting the number of mound â€œdisengagements,â€ like pickoff throws.

Itâ€™ll take some getting used to. Strange scenarios in the first spring training games showed how players and teams will need to adjust to the new rules. On Friday, San Diego Padres star Manny Machado became the first MLB player to begin an at-bat down 0â€“1 in the count for stepping into the batterâ€™s box too late.

Big picture: For fans who love baseball but canâ€™t justify spending 3+ hours watching it, these could be welcome changes. That same Padresâ€“Mariners game on Friday took just 2:29Â to completeâ€”about 40 minutes shorter than last yearâ€™s regular-season average, per ESPN.

Â  SNAPSHOTS

Â  Photo of the week Low water levels in a Venice canal Alessandro Bremec/NurPhoto via Getty Images If youâ€™re thinking â€œThatâ€™s not what I remember Veniceâ€™s canals looking like,â€ youâ€™d be correct. Â  SCIENCE

Â  Dept. of Progress Jessie saying Breaking Bad/AMC via Giphy Here are some illuminating scientific discoveries from the week to help you live better and maybe even longer.

Self-cleaning is for more than just ovens. While thereâ€™s plenty of debate <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU1M_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C821d865e> over whether touchscreens in cars are safe or convenient, thereâ€™s no denying theyâ€™re covered in more fingerprints than a crime scene. But according to a recent patent filing, GM has solved <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU1Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C014dab58> that problem. The automaker has invented a self-cleaning screen to save your sleeve from having to do the work. Itâ€™s got a coating that will break down those smudgy prints after being activated by violet light from pixels inside the screen.

Thereâ€™s a right time to exercise for a longer life. Itâ€™s not news that exercise can help you live longer, but a new study of ~92,000 people in the UK suggests that if longevity <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU1U_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C87c672c5> is your goal, you might want to get your workout in after lunch. The study found that people who work out between 11am and 5pm are less likely to die prematurely than people who #riseandgrind. This upside of afternoon exercise was most pronounced for the elderly, men, people who were generally less active, and people with cardiovascular conditions.

A promising new drug to defeat superbugs. Researchers at UC Santa Barbara have developed a new type of antibiotic <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU1Y_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf03c3121> that cures mice of infections from bacteria deemed close to untreatable in humans. Even more importantly, the bacteria developed almost no resistance to the drug. If the drug turns out to work the same way for humans, then it could be a big step forward, since the WHO considers antimicrobial resistance a huge and growing threat to human health, food security, and even the economy.

Â  NEWS ANALYSIS

Â  How the WWE got its sticker price of $9B <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU0w_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D9eb46d9b> Vince McMahon getting carried by a wrestler <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU0w_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E9eb46d9b>Leon Halip/Stringer/Getty Images Thereâ€™s no consensus on whether pro wrestling is really a sport, but few doubt that major changes await the biggest supplier of the spectacle. The legendary wrestling promotion WWE is on the market, with fans holding their breath to see who the buyer will be.

Whoever snags it, itâ€™ll cost them a pretty penny: Owner and CEO Vince McMahon reportedly wants $9 billion, according to Bloomberg. The 77-year-old retired from the company amid a sex scandal last yearâ€”but recently returned to oversee preparations for the potential sale.

Not many companies have been a bigger part of American pop culture than WWE (and probably no others have had their CEO fake-assaulted <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU00_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C745028a6> and shaved bald by a future US president), so letâ€™s look at how it came to be such a juggernaut.

First, WWE took over TV

Vince McMahon purchased WWE from his father in 1982, and turned the regional promotion originally active in the Northeast into an international phenomenon by recruiting top talent from other companies and getting its matches on national television.

* The company launched its flagship pay-per-view live event, WrestleMania, in 1985, which would draw record-shattering crowds and secure its dominance in the industry.

* WWE (then called WWF) matches quickly became a prime-time TV staple. Millions tuned in weekly to watch flamboyantly costumed larger-than-life personalities play out colorful storylines, talk smack, and use their acrobatic prowess to feign beating the living hell out of each other.

The names of early superstars like Hulk Hogan and AndrÃ© the Giant will probably ring a bell, but the most important persona in WWE history is arguably McMahon himself. He was a regular presence <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU04_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce700eaac> at the ring, never shying away <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30652798.3409462/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yU08_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY1Mjc5OC4zNDA5NDYy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C4f5cb219> from stunts like tossing a colleague into a trash truck.

WWE further hit its stride in the â€™90s, ushering in an iconic period known as the â€œAttitude Era.â€ The company went all-in on mature content, in a battle for Monday night ratings with rival promotion WCW. Matches were laced with profanity, harsher violence, and sexual explicitness.

The Attitude Era ended when WWE bought out WCW. But its legacy lives onâ€”it propelled personalities like The Rock and Stone Cold Steve Austin to fame beyond pro wrestling circles.

Then WWE won over the internet

WWEâ€™s TV ratings declined following the Attitude Era. Some attribute it to an eventual move toward PG content, while others blame creative missteps and the aging of popular stars.

WWE nonetheless posted record revenue last year. Its live events continue to draw impressive crowds, and itâ€™s hugely popular on social media and streaming platforms.

* WWEâ€™s YouTube channel counts upward of 92 million subscribers (more than the NFL, NBA, and MLB combined), and it has 20 million followers on TikTok.

This massive following makes it extremely attractive to advertisers chasing after new markets and could drive up its sale price, according to the Associated Press.

Looking aheadâ€¦Endeavor Group Holdings, the owner of UFC, as well as Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Public Investment Fund, are among those rumored to be eyeing the company. WWEâ€™s stock price has gone up almost 50% in the past year, in part due to expectations of an impending sale.â€”SK

Â  DESTINATIONS

Â  Place to be: A darkness retreat A house at Sky Cave Retreats Sky Cave Retreats Itâ€™s a big world out there. In this section, weâ€™ll teleport you to an interesting locationâ€”and hopefully give you travel ideas in the process.

How does a darkness retreat work? Sky Cave Retreats, the facility where Rodgers blacked out, allows people to ponder lifeâ€™s big questions in partially underground rooms devoid of light, owner Scott Berman told ESPN. These rooms have a bed, a bathroom, a floor mat, andâ€¦thatâ€™s pretty much it. Itâ€™s just you and your thoughts, only interrupted by Berman delivering a dayâ€™s worth of meals to your door.

WORLD

The war in Ukraine, 1 year on <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30645048.2761552/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yUDM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY0NTA0OC4yNzYxNTUy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D9189289d> Collage of Zelensky, maps, text <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30645048.2761552/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yUDM_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY0NTA0OC4yNzYxNTUy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E9189289d> Photo Illustration: Dianna â€œMickâ€ McDougall, Source: Getty Images
Exactly one year ago today, Russian tanks rolled across Ukrainian borders, setting off the largest armed conflict since World War II.

Reverberations from the war have impacted people from Illinois to Islamabad, straining economies and reshaping political agendas worldwide. While combat continues in eastern Ukraine, letâ€™s look back on how the Russianâ€“Ukraine war has changed the world over the past year.

The scale of devastation

At least 7,199 Ukrainian civilians have died, more than 11,000 have been injured (both figures are the latest UN estimate and are likely a major undercount), and as many as a 100,000 of its soldiers have died or sustained injuries.

Russian military casualties are believed to be approaching 200,000, per US officials.

More than 8 million Ukrainian refugees (~20% of the country's prewar population) have fled for other European countries. Hundreds of thousands of Russians also left their country.

Economic losses

The war has cost Ukraine hundreds of billions of dollars in damaged infrastructure and caused its GDP to plummet 30% in 2022.

Russiaâ€™s output contracted by just over 2%, surprising many economists who believed a meltdown was imminent.

But economist Sergei Guriev cautions against using GDP to measure the performance of a wartime economy, since military expenditures can distort the big picture. He says Russiaâ€™s economy is worse off than it seems, and points to a significant decline in Russiaâ€™s consumer spending and a higher-than-expected increase in its government budget deficit.

Shifting global trade

Russians now have to shop abroad to snag a Big Mac or a pair of Leviâ€™s jeans. Over 1,000 multinationals <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30645048.2761552/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yUDQ_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDY0NTA0OC4yNzYxNTUy/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C161b4af4>, including Microsoft and Nike, said theyâ€™d limit their operations within Russiaâ€™s borders or leave altogether in the first months of the war, according to a group of Yale researchers led by management professor Jeffrey Sonnenfeld.

Sonnenfeld says that the corporate exodus from Russia is six times bigger than the one that ensued during the apartheid era in South Africa, which at the timeâ€”1988â€”was the largest in history.

But most damaging to the Russian economy has been the action of governments abroad. Due to its invasion of Ukraine, Russia is now the most sanctioned country in the world, with restrictions on its energy exports, strategic imports, and access to the global financial system.

And the EU, which at times relied on Russia for almost half of its natural gas imports, has cut those levels to less than 10%, according to Axios.

Zoom out: The biggest international conflict since World War II has spurred many countries to reconsider their approach to national defense. Notably, Germany and Japan appear to have abandoned their customary pacifism, promising to ramp up their military spending, and the US is prioritizing increasing its arms stockpiles.â€”SK

Stay tuned tomorrow when we'll dive into what the next year might hold for the war in Ukraine.

The rules are still in draft form for now, but if they get finalized, it would be a blow to Big Milkâ€”which has been crying over spilled alt-milk for years.

The dairy industry has long argued that plant-based milks dilute the meaning of the term â€œmilk,â€ and has instead called them â€œbeverages.â€ But the FDA said yesterday that consumers arenâ€™t confused by the term and that makers of soy, almond, oat, cashew, hemp, and whatever other milks cafes charge extra for should be able to label their cartons â€œmilkâ€...as long as they keep the plant source up front.

The new draft rules also suggest that alt-milk-makers add an extra label indicating when theyâ€™re less nutritious than cowâ€™s milk, which didnâ€™t go over well with plant-based food advocacy groups.

Dairy hasnâ€™t been dethroned yet: Despite the rising popularity of nondairy milk in the US (almond is No. 1, but oat is gaining on it), the cow-based kind still outsells it five times over. Sales of cowâ€™s milk totaled $12.3 billion for roughly the past year compared to $2.5 billion for nondairy alternatives, per NielsenIQ.â€”JW

The real story: The movie is loosely based on a 1985 incident in which a drug dealer dropped 75 pounds of cocaine from an airplane along the Georgiaâ€“Tennessee border. He tried to jump out after it, but his parachute failed and he plummeted to his death. A few months later, authorities found a ripped duffel bag and a dead bear that tested positive for cocaine.

The botched drug smuggling story became a local legend. And 38 years after the powder fell from the sky, we get to see the Elizabeth Banks-directed film that answers the vital question: â€œOK, what if the bear didnâ€™t die?â€

No bears were harmed. In fact there were no bears near the set. Instead, stuntman and motion capture artist Alan Henry played the bear during filming, wearing a bear head and walking on all fours with special attachments on his arms. Peter Jacksonâ€™s visual effects company, Weta FX, added the full CGI bear (which ate up most of the movie's $35 million budget) after filming.â€”MM

HEALTH

Diabetes patients need Ozempic, but dieters want it <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS3c_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Db33f5f66> Doctor writes a prescription <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS3c_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Eb33f5f66> LumiNola/Getty Images
Ozempic may be TikTokâ€™s new favorite weight loss drug, but it served a different demographic before dieting celebrities: Type 2 diabetes patients. Now, the drug is in short supply <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS3g_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C10c0933c>.

As more people inject the drug for weight loss, diabetes patients are pharmacy-hopping to find stores that have Ozempic in stock, lowering their dosages to make their supplies last longer, and attempting to switch medications. The company that makes it, Novo Nordisk, expects supply to be iffy through mid-March.

Meanwhile on TikTokâ€¦

#Ozempic, #ozempicweightloss, and #ozempicchallenge have a combined 785 million views on TikTok, where use of the drug is a viral trend <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS3k_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C426f2f8b>. This year, use of Ozempic has grown 69% and its higher dose alternative Wegovy, 75%, according Novo Nordisk.

Ozempic may be having its moment now, but itâ€™s not new:

The FDA approved Ozempic, generically known as semaglutide, for treating Type 2 diabetes in 2017.

It blew up when people noticed that one of its side effects was weight loss, and in 2021, the FDA approved semaglutide, under the brand name Wegovy, for that use.

The problem is that Wegovy can also be hard to find. But as TikTok would say, everybodyâ€™s so creative <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS3o_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C8c7afb74>, and itâ€™s a common practice for doctors to prescribe medications for something other than their FDA-approved use. So, doctors scribble up Ozempic prescriptions for weight loss.

Thereâ€™s another reason a doctor might prescribe Ozempic even if their patient isnâ€™t diabetic: While diabetes drugs are always covered by insurance companies, drugs for weight loss often are not. And a one-month supply of Wegovy costs upward of $1,300.

Backlash is building: The American Diabetes Association is telling doctors to give priority for Ozempic back to diabetes patients, and numerous celebrities have spoken out about its rampant off-label use and potential side effects.â€”JW

WORLD

Tour de headlines A man clearing snow from the winter storm CRAIG LASSIG/AFP via Getty Images
The weather outside is frightful. At least 75 million people were under winter weather alerts as of yesterday, and the National Weather Service has cautioned that a prolonged, coast-to-coast winter storm <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS0Q_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cddf4d079> will impact just about every region of the US today. It really does mean coast to coast: Parts of Los Angeles are under the areaâ€™s first-ever blizzard warning. The storm has already begun to wreak havoc on travel, with at least 1,400 flights canceled so far. Meanwhile, itâ€™s going to feel like summer in much of the mid-Atlantic, with temps in Washington, DC, expected to hit almost 80 degrees.

NFL follows golf into Netflix doc realm. Netflix and NFL Films partnered <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS0U_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd02fd400> to create a real â€œtoo soonâ€ watch for Eagles fans: a docuseries called Quarterback following QBs Patrick Mahomes, Kirk Cousins, and Marcus Mariota through the 2022 season. Should be interesting: One won the Super Bowl and the other was benched before being placed on injured reserve. The first collaboration between the streamer and the league, Quarterback is slated for a summer premiere. Just one season has been ordered so far.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and a nonprofit investment manager controlled by church leaders have agreed to pay $5 million in fines to settle the Securities and Exchange Commissionâ€™s claims they used shell companies to keep the size of their massive investment portfolio a secret <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30631792.103071/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yS0c_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYzMTc5Mi4xMDMwNzE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C57a15f78> for more than two decades.

What regulators claim: The SEC said Tuesday that from 1997 through 2019, the investment manager, Ensign Peak, did not file required paperwork laying out all of its holdings. Instead, the leaders of the faith, widely known as the Mormon church, used 13 shell companies to file smaller disclosures. The church feared â€œnegative consequencesâ€ from publicly sharing its investments, which by 2018 had grown to $32 billion, the SEC said.

What the church says: Like most entities that tangle with the SEC, the church has neither admitted nor denied the allegations. But it did release a statement that said: â€œWe affirm our commitment to comply with the law, regret mistakes made, and now consider this matter closed.â€

Looking aheadâ€¦we probably wonâ€™t hear too much more on the matter from the church, which has historically kept mum about financial matters, outside of encouraging members to tithe 10% of their income.â€”ARÂ

Good morning. Did you know that Presidents Day (today) doesnâ€™t actually fall on any presidentâ€™s birthday?

While originally celebrated on February 22, the day George Washington was born, the holiday was moved to the third Monday of February in 1971. Thatâ€™s because Congress passed the Uniform Monday Holiday Act, which moved some federal holidays to Monday so we could all enjoy more three-day weekends.

Seems like a win-win: We get a day off and GW gets the highly coveted â€œbirthday week.â€

â€”Neal Freyman

Markets: The US stock and bond markets are closed today for Presidents Day. But crypto trading takes no days off, and despite the fallout from FTXâ€™s collapse and a flurry of crackdowns by regulators, bitcoin has been on a nice run lately. Last Thursday, it topped $25,000 to hit an eight-month high.

SOCIAL MEDIA

Zuck takes a page out of the Musk playbook <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQTY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D353c749b> Mark Zuckerberg <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQTY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E353c749b> Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images
Mark Zuckerberg must have gotten fed up with Elon Musk hogging the social media headlines, because yesterday he announced a big update to his own online platforms.

The Meta CEO introduced a subscription service <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQTc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C98ea7a57> for Instagram and Facebook that will allow users to purchase blue badges that mark them as verified. Known as Meta Verified, the service will launch in Australia and New Zealand this week and hit other countries â€œsoon.â€

Similar to Twitter Blue, Meta Verified eschews the traditional concept of the blue checkmark as a gift bestowed to notable people like politicians and celebs. Now, itâ€™s open to anyone whoâ€™s willing to pay. But there are differences between Twitterâ€™s and Metaâ€™s plans:

Metaâ€™s is more expensive, costing $11.99 on the web and $14.99 on mobile. Twitterâ€™s costs $8 and $11, respectively.

Meta will also require Meta Verified users to confirm their identity using a government-issued ID, something Twitter doesnâ€™t require.

What your $15 gets you with Meta Verified: Youâ€™ll get higher â€œvisibility and reachâ€ on the platforms and increased access to customer support, among other perks.

Whatâ€™s the strategy here, Zuck?

There are a couple ways Meta Verified could help Zuck sleep better at night.

Zuck said the overarching goal of the service is â€œincreasing authenticity and security across our services.â€ Meta Verified could help tackle some of the fake account issues that have plagued the companyâ€™s platforms.

With its metaverse dreams a long way off and revenue on the decline, Meta needs to kickstart growth ASAP. Itâ€™s hoping revenue from subscriptions can offset some of the damage that Appleâ€™s privacy changes and economic uncertainty have dealt to its advertising business.

Zoom out: This is a big dealâ€”not only for Meta, but for your experience on social media. By promising increased reach in exchange for $$$, Zuck is cementing social mediaâ€™s evolution from a tool to keep up with your high school friends to a pay-to-play entertainment medium catering to professional content creators. As Bloombergâ€™s Sarah Frier noted <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQTg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C014b569e>, â€œGet your good friends a group chat if you havenâ€™t already.â€

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQTk_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C94e1b334>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQWE_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2f227c71>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQWI_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C896d9571>Â Â

Several of the most iconic characters in childrenâ€™s literature, including Augustus Gloop, the Oompa Loompas, and Mrs. Twit, are being described with more inclusive language after publishers made edits <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30602377.3046114/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yQWg_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDYwMjM3Ny4zMDQ2MTE0/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C4e433445> to some of author Roald Dahlâ€™s books.

Puffin, the prestigious childrenâ€™s publisher, and the Roald Dahl Story Company, which Netflix acquired in 2021, worked with sensitivity readers to review Dahlâ€™s texts and give them an update so his stories â€œcan continue to be enjoyed by all today.â€ The edits generally focus on removing potentially offensive language related to gender, race, weight, mental health, and violence, according to the Independent.Â 

Some of those changes:

Augustus Gloop from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is now â€œenormousâ€ and not â€œfat.â€

In a gender-neutral revision, the Oompa Loompas in that same book are now described as â€œsmall peopleâ€ rather than â€œsmall men.â€

In The Witches, where 59 changes were reportedly made by publishers, a line was added to a paragraph that explains why the witches are bald underneath their wigs: â€œThere are plenty of other reasons why women might wear wigs and there is certainly nothing wrong with that.â€

These changes sparked a firestorm. Critics unloaded on the edits, accusing them of being clumsy, erasing the authorâ€™s intended meaning, and representing political correctness run amok. Acclaimed writer Salman Rushdie tweeted, â€œRoald Dahl was no angel but this is absurd censorship.â€

Â  NEWS ANALYSIS

Â  Why bird flu has people worried about more than the price of eggs <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30588693.3463080/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yeDY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDU4ODY5My4zNDYzMDgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D8b93b7e9> Person in haz mat holding chicken <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30588693.3463080/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yeDY_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDU4ODY5My4zNDYzMDgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E8b93b7e9>Peter Garrard Beck/Getty Images Weâ€™ve all noticed that chicken eggs cost as much as the FabergÃ© kind latelyâ€”OK, not quite, but the price of eggs has increased over 70% in the past year. At least part of the blame for the spike lies with the avian flu, which has been spreading from wild birds to poultry worldwide.

In the US, over 58 million farm birds have died in the past year as a result of the outbreak (a death toll that includes whole flocks that had to be culled if even one bird got infected). But itâ€™s not just avian safety and omelette prices that have people concerned about the outbreak: There are also fears this bird flu could lead to the next human pandemic.

Whatâ€™s new with the bird flu?

The A(H5N1) virus <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30588693.3463080/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy8yeDc_bWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJmJmNpZD0zMDU4ODY5My4zNDYzMDgw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3564e839> has been infecting poultry in Asia and other regions of the world since 1996, but the current outbreak is different in scope and intensity. Not only is the virus sweeping through new places, affecting Europe and the US more extensively than ever before, itâ€™s also become endemic among some wild birds for the first time, per Reuters. More parts of the world are starting to see that itâ€™s no longer a seasonal phenomenon, making poultry vulnerable to infection year-round.

With A(H5N1)â€™s current iteration, the term â€œbird fluâ€ increasingly sounds like a misnomer: Scientists in the US have detected it in bears, foxes, raccoons, and other mammals. And a recent outbreak at a mink farm in Spain has shown that itâ€™s now sometimes able to spread among mammals without any birds present.

Flu viruses are particularly inclined to mutate, and if an animal becomes infected with both a human flu and a bird flu, the two different strains can exchange bits of DNA (kind of like the virus version of a sitcom crossover), making it more adept at infecting new hosts.

This developmentâ€”and humanityâ€™s recent struggle with another high-risk pathogenâ€”has many people wondering whether humans might be next.

So, how risky is it for humans?

Not very. Experts urge vigilance within the medical community, but you donâ€™t have to relocate to an off-the-grid bunker in rural Wyoming just yet.

* Instances of human infection are exceedingly rare: There have been less than 10 cases globally since December 2021, according to the CDC (though the mortality rate tends to be high).

* At the moment, humans mostly contract the virus from infected animals, and farm workers are taking precautions when dealing with birds and livestock.

And in other reassuring news, you donâ€™t need to worry about bird flu in your foodâ€”unless you enjoy eating raw eggs or poultry. Heating them to an internal temperature of 165ËšF kills bacteria and viruses, A(H5N1) included, per the CDC.

While scientists arenâ€™t immediately concerned about the bird flu setting off the next human pandemic, the situation is already making farming more unpredictable and threatens to render our fauna less diverse.

Looking ahead...A(H5N1) vaccines for birds do exist, but theyâ€™re traditionally unpopular due to import bans on vaccinated birds and their limited effectiveness against the ever-mutating virus. The recent outbreak has caused a change of heart in many governments that are testing jabs on birds.â€”SK
