WORK

Employers are trying to take back the power on RTO <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XaD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dc043b5f0> A large open floor plan office from a scene in Orson Welles's The Trial. <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XaD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ec043b5f0> The Trial/Studio Canal
The ongoing tug of war between remote employees (who are feeling more productive and less burnt out) and their employers (who are feeling bad about paying for an office) could experience a balance shift in 2023. Major companies, aware of fears about a potential recession, are issuing directives <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XaT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C85e847b2> to come into the office for more days, sometimes under the threat of termination.

Last week, Disney CEO Bob Iger told hybrid staff that, starting on March 1, they must return to the office four days a week. Two days later, Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz announced a similar three-day RTO requirement, expressing irritation at internal badge swipe data that revealed employees were not â€œmeeting their minimum promiseâ€ regarding hybrid work.

Employees at Vanguard, Paycom, and News Corp have also received recent orders to phase out remote work in the new year. A survey from Resume Builder found that 90% of companies will require a return to the office this year, signaling a shift away from the softly enforced hybrid policies that became popular during the pandemic.

A controversial resolution

That doesnâ€™t mean employees are excited to add commute time or â€œgetting asked about weekend plansâ€ back into their lives: According to a recent Gallup poll, 34% of remote-capable workers want to work from home permanently and just 3% want to work in the office full time. A Monster survey in September found that 40% of workers would quit if they had to come into the office even one day a week.

But thereâ€™s an issue with that: Remote work is getting hard to find. Between February and October 2022, remote job listings fell from 20% to 14% of all listings on LinkedIn. Now, even more employers seem empowered to demand <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XTT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C22719f95> in-office time.

Remote hope is not lost: On the flip side, Twitter CEO and vocal remote work critic Elon Musk recently ordered Seattle employees to WFH as a cost-cutting measure.â€”MK

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9Xaj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C82cd18cf>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9Xaz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce4aaf8ea>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XbD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc88bab99>Â Â  

TOGETHER WITH LIQUIDPISTON

Itâ€™s called the X-Engineâ„¢. And even though itâ€™s smaller than other engines, Little X delivers up to 10x the power-to-weight ratio <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9NUj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5NiZscD10ZXh0MQ/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce79b3206> of legacy engines and 30% more fuel efficiency.

But thatâ€™s just the start. When the EV market grows 380% by 2030, there will be a shortage of precious metals like lithium. Thatâ€™s where X-Engine comes in, enabling hybrid electric cars to use 80% smaller batteries.Â 

Itâ€™s no wonder X-Engineâ€™s creators at LiquidPiston <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9NUj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5NiZscD10ZXh0Mg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3cfe612e> have already secured $30m in contracts to do everything from shrinking generators to flying military drones 2x farther.

Despite dodging authorities since 1993, he has been convicted in absentia and given life sentences for his role in various crimes, including the murder of two anti-Mafia prosecutors; bombings in Florence, Milan, and Rome that killed 10; and the slaying of the young son of a Mafioso who turned stateâ€™s witness.

Ukrainian soccer club pledges $25 million for soldiers. Rinat Akhmetov, Ukraineâ€™s richest man and the owner of the Shakhtar Donetsk football club, announced the donation <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9Xbj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cce602086> yesterday after agreeing to trade star player Mykhaylo Mudryk to Chelsea FC in a ~$110 million deal. Elon Musk heads to court over Tesla tweet. So far, Musk is expected to testify this week, and his odds donâ€™t look great: The judge already determined that the tweet was false and reckless, but now a jury will weigh whether Musk knew it was false and whether it was material to investors.

TECH

Artists sue AI art generators <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XcD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Da1c3e8eb> A corgi eats an avocado in space <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XcD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ea1c3e8eb> Midjourney
Art made by AI has won prizes, been displayed in museums, and taken over Twitter profile pics, but not everyoneâ€™s happy with how it turns users into elven princesses.

Three artists are suing <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9XcT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd1904dd4> Midjourney, Stability AI, and DeviantArt for their use of an AI art-generating tool called Stable Diffusion. The artistsâ€”Sarah Andersen, Kelly McKernan, and Karla Ortizâ€”allege the tool violates millions of artistsâ€™ copyrights.

How AI art generators work: Stable Diffusion has been fed billions of images scraped from the web in order to train its AI on how to do things like identify an â€œavocado.â€ So when a user types â€œcorgi eats an avocado in spaceâ€ into an AI art generator that uses Stable Diffusion, it creates new works <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9Xcj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ca06ef6f9> based on the images itâ€™s analyzed.

But whether itâ€™s derivative or plagiarism is up for debate

The suit claims that Stable Diffusion cobbles together pieces of copyrighted images, but creators of AI art-generating tools argue that their use of existing pictures to train the AI to make new ones is covered by â€œfair useâ€ doctrineâ€”which allows using copyrighted materials for â€œtransformativeâ€ purposes.

Bottom line: This case could set an important precedent on training AI tools that could go way beyond the art world.â€”JW

Watch out, Zeus: Scientists havenâ€™t completely mastered lightning, but theyâ€™ve successfully used a laser to divert its direction. A study <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30267060.104296/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9Xdz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjY3MDYwLjEwNDI5Ng/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce57548a5> published yesterday described an experiment in which a laser was shot at a storm cloud from atop a Swiss mountain to successfully direct lightning toward the ground.

This marks the first time the method worked outside a lab, and thatâ€™s a big step forward for public safety.

Lightning causes billions of dollars in damage and claims over 4,000 lives a year.

It would be much worse had Benjamin Franklin not invented the lightning rod, which to this day remains the go-to for protection from lightning. But the man would have turned 317 today, so itâ€™s about time his invention was updatedâ€”especially since the Franklin rod is a godsend for your home, but itâ€™s insufficient for bigger places like airports or wind farms.

So, how did we one-up a founding father?

Scientists unleashed a rapid-fire barrage of laser pulses at thunderclouds, creating a path of charged particles that lightning was more likely to follow. Four lightning bolts were steered toward a rod mounted on top of a telecom tower that is a frequent target of lightning strikes.

Looking forward: Itâ€™ll be a while before youâ€™ll be able to catch regular laser-lightning shows in the night sky due to an eye-popping price tag: The system used in the experiment costs $2.17 billion.â€”SK

TECH

How to spot cheating in a ChatGPT world <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VWD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Dbb43dc44> A man looking at his hand to cheat on a test. It says <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VWD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ebb43dc44> 5secondfilms via Giphy
As more students realize that ChatGPT can write five-paragraph essays equally as good asâ€”if not significantly better thanâ€”what theyâ€™re capable of, teachers are scrambling for tools that can detect whether theyâ€™re grading the writing of a young human or a young robot.

Several cheating-detection tools have sprung up <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VWT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2d3c7817> in the few months since ChatGPT, a conversational language model from OpenAI, arrived on the scene. The most-talked about one is GPTZero <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VWj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cea1ab833>, which was developed by, of all peopleâ€¦a student.

Over winter break, 22-year-old Princeton student Edward Tian created an app that determines the likelihood that a piece of text was written by a human or by ChatGPT. While it probably didnâ€™t make him the most popular dude on campus, the app is getting more than 7 million views as of last week.

Apps like GPTZero are becoming increasingly sought after as older cheating detection tools become obsolete in the ChatGPT era.

Remember Turnitin?

Many of us whoâ€™ve been tasked with explaining the green light at the end of The Great Gatsby have had to submit those essays to Turnitin.com to make sure we didnâ€™t copy it from Wikipedia. That was effectiveâ€¦before ChatGPT. But what makes ChatGPT different is that it theoretically creates an original response of text every time you query it. Thatâ€™s not what Turnitin is designed for: It cross-checks your work against an existing database of writing.

Turnitin, of course, is on the case: It says itâ€™s currently testing a tool that can detect AI-generated text, and plans to open it up to the public later this year.

But as good as these apps get, ChatGPT and its fellow language models will also evolveâ€”and some education experts say teachers will have to also rely on the oldest tool in the book to mitigate cheating: their noggin. Teachers will need to understand the differences (which do exist) between AI and human writing. Theyâ€™ll also likely need to overhaul their teaching process <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VLT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C5273cf40> to minimize cheating opportunitiesâ€”for instance, by setting clear expectations with students about the role of ChatGPT in classrooms, or by tweaking their assignments to reward skills ChatGPT hasnâ€™t masteredâ€¦

Yet.

Dozens killed in Nepal plane crash. At least 68 people were killed when a Yeti Airlines flight crashed <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WMj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C759c9c31> while attempting to land in the resort town of Pokhara on Sunday. A total of 72 people on board the aircraft, a twin engine ATR 72, including 15 foreign nationals. Itâ€™s Nepalâ€™s worst plane disaster in 30 years, but plane crashes are not uncommon in this country of towering mountains, treacherous flying conditions, and weak safety standards: Since 1946, Nepal has experienced 42 fatal airplane crashes.

A Ukrainian residential building was destroyed. In the deadliest civilian attack on Ukraine in months, a Russian missile strike on a nine-story apartment block killed 30 people <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WMz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C24171329> in the city of Dnipro on Saturday. The Ukrainian military said the missile was a supersonic Kh-22Â  â€œaircraft carrier killerâ€ that it does not currently have the ability to intercept. As Russia ramps up its attacks after a two-week breather, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged Western allies to supply more weapons. Britain recently announced it would send over 14 of its primary battle tanks.

Polarizing MLK monument opens in Boston <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WNT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Db29258cd> The Embrace- a new monument to MLK and his wife in Boston <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WNT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Eb29258cd> Lane Turner/The Boston Globe via Getty Images
On Friday, Boston city officials unveiled <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WNj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd088ab19> the latest monument to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.â€”a $10 million bronze sculpture depicting the moment MLK embraced his wife, Coretta Scott King, after Dr. King learned he won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964. It is called The Embrace.

The completion of the 22-foot-tall statue was highly anticipated: Five years in the works, it is the largest monument to racial equity in the country, and itâ€™s located in the Boston Common, the oldest public park in the US.

Why Boston? That was where MLK met Coretta: He was a doctoral student at BU, while she was studying at the New England Conservatory of Music. Boston Common was also the final destination of a 20,000-person-strong voting rights march Dr. King led from Roxbury in 1955.

But The Embrace hasnâ€™t exactly been embraced <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WNz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C23e86aaa> from a critical POV. The design of the statue, which shows four arms intertwined, was bashed online for not depicting the couple in full and for potentially giving off inappropriate vibes. Corretta Scott Kingâ€™s cousin, Seneca Scott, wrote in the online journal Compact, â€œTen million dollars were wasted to create a masturbatory metal homage to my legendary family members.â€

The artistâ€™s vision: Brooklyn-based sculptor Hank Willis Thomas told the Boston Globe <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WOD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd5acce8e>, â€œThis work is really about the capacity for each of us to be enveloped in love.â€

<https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WOT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C487c3c22>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WYT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2B1ef4e27c>Â Â  <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30260530.3516230/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9WYj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjYwNTMwLjM1MTYyMzA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C8d257a1e>Â Â

TOGETHER WITH FACET WEALTH

New year, new financial outlook

Thatâ€™s our favorite thing about this time of year: all the fresh starts + new beginnings, like a *new* financial plan that gives you a better handle on your finances.

Â  SNAPSHOTS

Â  Photo of the week Anglers cast lines through holes on a frozen river during the annual ice fishing festival in Hwacheon Anthony Wallace/AFP via Getty Images Any idea what all these people are doing on the ice? If you guessed â€œfishing for trout,â€ you get a sticker.

The festival is located just 12 miles from the Demilitarized Zone that separates South Korea from its northern neighbor.

Â  SCIENCE

Â  Dept. of Progress Jason Sudeikis talking about the periodic table on SNL SNL/NBC via Giphy Here are some illuminating scientific discoveries from the week to help you live better and maybe even find new worlds.

Cancer prevention is working. Overall mortality from cancer <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9QWj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3ec60548> has plunged by a third since 1991, according to a new report by the American Cancer Society. The drop, which the organization estimates has resulted in 3.8 million cancer deaths avoided, reflects improvements to cancer screening and prevention. For instance, cervical cancer rates for women in their early twenties dropped 65% following the introduction of the HPV vaccine. But thereâ€™s still more work to do: Rates of prostate cancer, which is the second largest cause of cancer death for US men, have started climbing and cases are frequently being caught in later stages.

A whole new world. NASAâ€™s James Webb Space Telescope proved this week that it can do more than just take gorgeous photos: It discovered its first exoplanet <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9QLT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C08b3966f>, a rocky sphere about 41 light-years away from us thatâ€™s roughly the same size as Earth. But this oneâ€™s probably not a candidate to be our new digs if Elon Muskâ€™s plans for Mars donâ€™t pan outâ€”the planet, named LHS 475 b, orbits a red dwarf star a whole lot closer than we do the sun, making it at least 200 degrees hotter than Earth. Still, the newbie adds to the list of 5,000+ exoplanets NASA has found so far.

ğŸ«§ A startup is sucking carbon from the air. Switzerland-based Climeworks said it has achieved a world first by pulling carbon dioxide out of the air and sticking it underground <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9QXz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C8e50ca64>, where it will ultimately transform into rock. The feat has been confirmed by an independent auditor, meaning that hoovering gas out of the air, a long-held goal for several companies and a potentially important way to fight climate change, is now a real possibility.â€”AR

Â  ANALYSIS

Â  Why a bunch of VIPs will be at the same ski resort tomorrow <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9RYz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D262bfb06> Davos <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9RYz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E262bfb06>Getty Images What do German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and cellist Yo-Yo Ma have in common? Theyâ€™ll both speak at the World Economic Forumâ€™s (WEF) annual meeting in Davos this week, as economic and political elites from around the globe gather in the Swiss Alps to drink GlÃ¼hwein in a ski lodge brainstorm solutions to the worldâ€™s most pressing problems.

According to the WEF <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9RZD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C42260562>, these are: climate change, inflation, confrontation between countries, threats from technology, plus the prospect of these issues combining into a â€œpolycrisisâ€ (like wars over scarce natural resources brought about by climate change).

What happens in Davos every year is pretty straightforward: World leaders, billionaires, heads of international NGOs, celebrities, and Nobel laureates rub elbows behind closed doors. Meanwhile, journalists lurk around, hoping to catch them in a talkative mood.

But does the WEF really achieve anything besides organizing a glitzy get-together in Europeâ€™s highest town?

First, what is the WEF?

Itâ€™s a not-for-profit foundation thatâ€™s been around since 1971. It aims to bring together the worldâ€™s most influential people to â€œshape global, regional, and industry agendas.â€ Aside from the flagship Davos event, it runs regional summits and publishes thought leadership on economic and social issues.

The WEFâ€™s efforts center on stakeholder capitalism, the idea that corporations should not just be profit-maximizing machines but should also look out for customers, suppliers, and local communities.

Not everyone is a fan of the Alpine ski squad

It shouldnâ€™t come as a surprise that an organization in the business of setting up schmooze fests for the global elite has more than a few critics.

Davos skeptics note that the WEF is funded by basically every major organization under the sun. Its 2022 annual report says over half of the ~$413 million it brought in that year came from its partners, mostly corporations like NestlÃ© and government-run entities like the Agricultural Bank of China. Itâ€™s been accused of engaging in capitalist virtue signaling while making it easier for sponsors to lobby for their interests and advocate for business-friendly policies.

The â€œGreat Resetâ€ initiative, the foundationâ€™s global post-pandemic recovery plan, has been panned as a thinly veiled effort to tip the power balance in solving global issues away from governments and toward the private sector.

Why this all matters to those without a private jet

The WEF shapes the conversation (and policies) in areas like international food security and global vaccine distribution:

* Itâ€™s a prominent supplier of narratives to news organizations, with last yearâ€™s Davos meeting getting 48,000 media mentions (and itâ€™s already notched at least one this year).

* Its influence transcends legacy media: Popular journalist Johnny Harris was once called out <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9RZT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C972d107f> for partnering with the WEF to promote shareholder capitalism on his YouTube channel.

Big picture: Curiously enough, this yearâ€™s Davos attendees nearly showed up to a ski resort without the ability to ski, as an unusually warm winter has left European mountains with little snow. It did snow in Davos at the last minute, but whether the WEFâ€™s efforts can help blunt the impacts of climate change (or solve any other problems) remains to be seen. The WEFâ€™s ability to produce vague proclamations and viral Greta Thunberg moments <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30246160.3484633/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9RZj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjQ2MTYwLjM0ODQ2MzM/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf1ac448c>, however, is certainly beyond question.â€”SK

Â  DESTINATIONS

Â  Place to be: Melbourne, Australia Australia Open venue in Melbourne Graham Denholm/Getty Images Itâ€™s a big world out there. In this section, weâ€™ll teleport you to an interesting locationâ€”and hopefully give you travel ideas in the process.

While it may not be Australiaâ€™s largest city, Melbourne is the countryâ€™s hub for all things food, culture, arts, and sportsâ€”and starting tomorrow itâ€™ll be the center of the tennis universe for the next two weeks when it hosts the Australian Open.

As you watch tennis players rally in the warm sun (it is summer Down Under, after all), you should know that outside the courts, thereâ€™s a metropolis of 5+ million people with some unique characteristics, starting with the cityâ€™s design. Melbourneâ€™s central business district (CBD) is laid out in a grid, but tucked behind the major thoroughfares are â€œlanewaysâ€ that in the Victorian era serviced the businesses on the main roads. Itâ€™s on these narrow streets that you can find some of the cafes, boutiques, restaurants, and street art that Melbourne is known for.

Some other fun facts:

* Melbourne is sports-mad. Not only does it host the Australian Open, but also a Formula 1 race and other international events. Melbourne Cricket Ground (capacity: 100,000+) is one of the most famous sports venues in the world. And in 1956 Melbourne became the first city outside of Europe or North America to host the Olympics.

* Vegemite, that foul spread Australians like to eat with bread, is manufactured in Melbourne and the product turns 100 years old this year.

* In the 2010s, Melbourne was declared the most livable city in the world for seven straight years by the Economist Intelligence Unit. â€”NF

Good morning and Happy Saturday. Our fantastic design team was out at a summit yesterday, which left the inmates (us) to run the asylum (image selection for the newsletter).

When deciding which images to use for each story, Jamie jokingly floated the idea of using Simpsons GIFs for all of them. At first we laughed, but then thoughtâ€¦why the heck not? So, for no particular reason, we did.

Thank you most of all to Matt Groening for providing an infinite library of timeless scenes to choose from.

GOVERNMENT

Yellen sounds the alarm on debt ceiling <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30250159.3068198/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VaD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjUwMTU5LjMwNjgxOTg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ddcbb74d6> Homer Simpson saying the end is near <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30250159.3068198/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VaD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjUwMTU5LjMwNjgxOTg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Edcbb74d6> The Simpsons/20th Television via Giphy
The sky began to slowly descend on Washington as Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen kicked off the fight over the debt ceiling yesterday.

Yellen said that if lawmakers donâ€™t raise the cap on government borrowing, the Treasury will start taking â€œextraordinary measures,â€ like pausing contributions to federal workersâ€™ retirement funds, on Thursday.

So, what is all the fuss about? In order for the US to keep borrowing and paying its bills, lawmakers have to agree on a new debt ceiling. Currently the US is $78 billion away from maxing out the current $31.4 trillion limit (similar to your credit card sitch after the holiday season).

This is something Congress needs to do, but lawmakers have come to view the procedure as a bargaining chip. The negotiation is expected to be epic:

Ultraconservative Republicans only handed Rep. Kevin McCarthy the House speakership on the condition that a new borrowing limit gets coupled with deep cuts to government spending and a plan to balance the budget in the next decade. (According to the Washington Post, theyâ€™ve already prepared a plan for default.)

The White House insists that the new debt limit must be passed with no strings attached.

While the government can probably scrape by on the cash it has until early June, all the drama has people thinking about what defaulting for real would be like. Well, the reputation of the US as a borrower would start to resemble that of an unemployed uncle with a gambling addiction. Financial markets would likely enter a tailspin and the US economy would tank.

How do we avert the disaster?

Lawmakers have to reach a compromise. It could involve negotiations between top House Republicans and the White House, or the House entering a more protracted procedure that entails convincing moderate Republicans to vote with Democrats.

But if the traditional route doesnâ€™t work, policy nerds have some workarounds (that are not Yellen-approved). One is minting a trillion-dollar platinum coin to meet the Treasuryâ€™s financial obligations.

Bottom line: While an unprecedented default on US government debt remains a remote possibility, some parts of the bond market (which holds government debt) are already angsty and preparing for a long congressional fight.â€”SK

Open house

Mirrored, reflective house in Joshua Tree.The Invisible HouseTodayâ€™s listing <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30250159.3068198/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9VTz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjUwMTU5LjMwNjgxOTg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C19215a1b>, called the Invisible House, is very obviously the first piece of an alien Tetris game. One loooong room, but two toilets

Indoor pool

Bed with 2,500-pound glass base

How much for the shiny log?

The agency grounded all flights in the morning over a problem it believes was caused by a â€œdamaged database file,â€ renewing concerns that US travel infrastructure desperately needs an update.

This grounding is way bigger than when your parents realized the â€œcartoonsâ€ you rented from Blockbuster were hyperviolent anime: It may be the first time all flights have been ordered to stay on the tarmac since 9/11. Departures resumed at 9am ET, but as of yesterday evening, 10,000+ US flights were delayed and 1,300 were canceled as airlines struggled to sort out the morning mayhem <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30223741.3062455/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9FdT9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjIzNzQxLjMwNjI0NTU/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C9eb7c460>.

What exactly caused this mess?

The FAA system that went down was created over 75 years ago. It's called NOTAMs (formerly â€œNotice to Airmen,â€ now â€œNotice to Air Missionsâ€), and it alerts pilots to any hazards along their route and at their destinationâ€”such as flocks of birds and icy runways. It was rebooted <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30223741.3062455/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9Fdj9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjIzNzQxLjMwNjI0NTU/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd36a7e25> yesterday morning after some corrupted data was discovered, and it took longer than AOL dial-up to get back online.

The government system has been criticized for *surprise, surprise* not being very modern, and the UNâ€™s aviation body has been pushing to bring NOTAMs into the 21st century. A single briefing produced by the system can consist of up to 200 pages of alerts, and pilots have to review the whole document before takeoff.

Looking aheadâ€¦the FAA has preliminarily traced the issue back to a damaged file and said that it does not appear a cyber attack was involved, but, whatever occurred, the outage signals that the systemâ€™s outdatedness may run deeper than its HTML. â€œAmericaâ€™s transportation network desperately needs significant upgrades,â€ Geoff Freeman, the US Travel Association president, said. Markets: So far, stocks are generally making good on their New Yearâ€™s resolution to only go up <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY25iYy5jb20vMjAyMy8wMS8wOS9zdG9jay1tYXJrZXQtZnV0dXJlcy1vcGVuLXRvLWNsb3NlLW5ld3MuaHRtbA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd56b84b5>, but theyâ€™ll face several AP-level tests in the coming days, including the monthly inflation report release (Thursday) and the start of earnings season (Friday). Over in cryptoland, Coinbase investors applauded the companyâ€™s dramatic moves to cut costsâ€”the crypto exchange said it would lay off 20% of its workforce and drop â€œseveralâ€ projects.

WEATHER

20 trillion gallons of water is too muchâ€”and not enough <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.> Flooding in California. <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.> George Rose/Getty Images
A deadly barrage of storms has been dumping Olympic-sized pools of rain on California over the past few weeks. On Monday, millions across the state experienced an â€œatmospheric riverâ€ that dropped a monthâ€™s worth of rain in one day. And as the downpours continued yesterday, 90% of the stateâ€™s population (which equates to 10% of the entire US population) was under flood watch. Forecasters estimate more than 20 trillion gallons <Over%2020%20trillion%20gallons%20of%20water%20are%20expected%20to%20fall%20across%20California%20over%20the%20next%202%20weeks.%20> of water will have fallen on California by mid-January.

Surely all this water will cure the state of the devastating drought thatâ€™s parched it over the last few decades, right?

Not quite

In fact, most parts of California are simultaneously under drought and flood emergencies, a bizarre consequence of climate change that will likely stick aroundâ€”despite more rainstorms projected to hit the state throughout the rest of the month.

Experts say California would need a lot more rain to completely reverse the drought that has put the Southwest in its driest condition in 1,200 years. One scientist told <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cud2FzaGluZ3RvbnBvc3QuY29tL25hdGlvbi8yMDIzLzAxLzA1L2NhbGlmb3JuaWEtZHJvdWdodC1yYWluLXN0b3JtLz91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C18ef35f3> the WaPo that these storms are like getting a normal monthly paycheck after several months of not getting paid at allâ€”the influx is welcome, but your bank account will still be depleted.

Another problem: Right now, thereâ€™s too much water and nowhere to put it. While California has gargantuan reservoirs to store rainwater and snow melt, most of the state has received rainfall anywhere from 400% to 600% above average since the storms began a few weeks ago. And once reservoirs are full, the water just flows into the ocean.

For instance, Lake Cachuma in Santa Barbara County was hovering around 30% capacity in early December. After rising 34 feet yesterday, itâ€™s expected to start overflowing Friday or Saturday.

Plus, in cities like LA (which has received around three inches so far), rainwater canâ€™t be collected because itâ€™s been contaminated by road runoff.

The current state of the storms: Around 146,000 customers were left without power as of 7pm ET yesterday and the death toll has risen <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY25uLmNvbS8yMDIzLzAxLzEwL3dlYXRoZXIvY2FsaWZvcm5pYS1mbG9vZGluZy1hdG1vc3BoZXJpYy1yaXZlci10dWVzZGF5L2luZGV4Lmh0bWw_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C018290c4> to 17. Mudslides and flooding have forced residents of many areas, including the ritzy neighborhoods of Montecito, to evacuate.â€”MM

But French unions, which staged massive protests the last time this plan was floated, have already made plans to strike on Jan. 19 in opposition to the move, which they call unjustified. So, what is OpenAI? It was founded in 2015 as a mission-based AI research organization by a roster from Silicon Valleyâ€™s A-list, including Elon Musk. Its stated goal is to develop safe AI for the benefit of humanity.

But OpenAI has plenty of critics who have called it out for ethical concerns, a lack of transparency, and abandoning its mission for profits.

TECH POLICY

You can now fix your tractor (if you know how) <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9qb2huLWRlZXJlLXJpZ2h0LXRvLXJlcGFpcj91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3Jm1pZD03Y2QzZDdlZmNiMmI1ZDFhNmNiZTBiZjA5MzFmNGIyZg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Bd50e87fc> John Deere <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9qb2huLWRlZXJlLXJpZ2h0LXRvLXJlcGFpcj91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3Jm1pZD03Y2QzZDdlZmNiMmI1ZDFhNmNiZTBiZjA5MzFmNGIyZg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd50e87fc> Photo Illustration: Dianna â€œMickâ€ McDougall, Source: Getty Images
As tractors have evolved to include high-tech features like self-driving capabilities, GPS, obstacle detection, andâ€”soon, with any luckâ€”League of Legends compatibility, theyâ€™ve become increasingly difficult for farmers or third-party shops to repair. But on Sunday, John Deere committed <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cud3NqLmNvbS9hcnRpY2xlcy9kZWVyZS10by1hbGxvdy1mYXJtZXJzLXRvLXJlcGFpci10aGVpci1vd24tZXF1aXBtZW50LTExNjczMjI4NTgwP3V0bV9jb250ZW50PWJ1ZmZlcjE3MjdlJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09c29jaWFsJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9dHdpdHRlci5jb20mdXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPWJ1ZmZlcg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C72d00aa8> to making that easier.

Together with the American Farm Bureau Federation, the company signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) thatâ€™s aimed at providing farmers with greater access to tools, diagnostic codes, and manuals. Until now, the companyâ€™s high-tech tractors could only be repaired by authorized dealers due to software locks, which farmers claimed raised costs and caused delays (and even led to some farmers hacking <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZW1lcmdpbmd0ZWNoYnJldy5jb20vc3Rvcmllcy8yMDIyLzA5LzIwL2pvaG4tZGVlcmUtcy1kaWdpdGFsLWVtYnJhY2UtcHV0cy1hLXNwb3RsaWdodC1vbi1pdHMtY3liZXJzZWN1cml0eS1wcmFjdGljZXM_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPWV0YiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXcmbWlkPTdjZDNkN2VmY2IyYjVkMWE2Y2JlMGJmMDkzMWY0YjJm/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C4799e80c> their tractors).

While this represents a victory for the burgeoning right-to-repair movement, advocates are wary of the MOUâ€™s lack of enforcement measures and certain sections in the agreement, including one that gives John Deere (or the AFBF) the ability to withdraw from the deal if any federal or state right-to-repair legislation is enacted.

Zoom out: This isnâ€™t the first time a deal like this has been made in the private sector. In 2018, a similar agreement was reached between a lobbying group representing Deere and the California Farm Bureau, but many of the promises didnâ€™t come to pass.â€”MK

GRAB BAG

Key performance indicators <#> Skyline of Chicago Interim Archives/Getty Images
Stat: Chicagoans have a lot of time to contemplate what the Bears should do with the No. 1 NFL Draft pick. Thatâ€™s because Windy City drivers wasted an average of 155 hours sitting in traffic last year, making Chicago the worst US city <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cud2FzaGluZ3RvbnBvc3QuY29tL3RyYW5zcG9ydGF0aW9uLzIwMjMvMDEvMTAvdHJhZmZpYy1jb25nZXN0aW9uLWlucml4LWNvdmlkLz91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C3216fe67> for congestion, according to INRIXâ€™s global traffic scorecard. Traffic picked up in cities all over the world last year, to match (and in some cases exceed) pre-pandemic levels. London was found to be the most congested city globally.

Quote: â€œWe are not, and will not be, a â€˜climate policymaker.â€™â€

In a speech in Stockholm, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said itâ€™s not his job <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30212721.3059397/aHR0cHM6Ly9hcG5ld3MuY29tL2FydGljbGUvYnVzaW5lc3MtamVyb21lLXBvd2VsbC1zd2VkZW4tc3RvY2tob2xtLWNsaW1hdGUtYW5kLWVudmlyb25tZW50LWMzZTU4NzVmNGI2ZDdlZmEwNzljODcwZmRjNzc5ZDc0P3JlZj1iaXp0b2MuY29t/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cdae93fb6> to play climate cop for the global financial system. Powell has heard from critics in both directions that the Fed should play a larger (or smaller) role in promoting environmental sustainability in the financial world. Powell also emphasized the need for the Fed to maintain its independence, since political influence could disrupt necessaryâ€”but unpopularâ€”interest rate hikes to stamp out inflation.

Good morning. What can you expect from Super Bowl commercials this year? Less crypto, more Gronk. FanDuel announced yesterday that in an ad during the game, Rob Gronkowski will kick a 25-yard field goal live. If he makes it, anyone who placed a Super Bowl bet of $5 or more on FanDuel will split $10 million in free bets on the platform.

Something tells us this is going to be a very effective way to sign up new usersâ€¦

ENVIRONMENT

Ozone layerâ€™s been looking good lately <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30200055.3066282/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9zMz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjAwMDU1LjMwNjYyODI/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D192ac170> Ozone layer recovery illustration <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30200055.3066282/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9zMz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjAwMDU1LjMwNjYyODI/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E192ac170> Hannah Minn
A bit of good news for the Earthlings reading this: The ozoneâ€™s layer is set to be fully restored <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30200055.3066282/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9zND9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjAwMDU1LjMwNjYyODI/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C0728e10a> over most of the world within the next two decades, according to a new UN report.

Trends indicate a full ozone layer recovery by 2040 will take place across the planet, excluding the poles: Ozone bounce back (to 1980, precrisis levels) over the Arctic is expected by 2045, and over the Antarctic by 2066. So keep holding, South Pole property owners, good times are just over the horizon.

So, why does it matter?

Science class refresher:

The ozone layer is a thin part of the Earthâ€™s stratosphere, about nine to 18 miles above its surface. This layer shields Earth from harmful ultraviolet rays linked to cancers and crop damage. In 1985, scientists identified a hole in the ozone layer caused by chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), the ozone-depleting chemicals found in air conditioners, refrigerators, and deodorants.

The loss of the ozone layer was one of the most feared environmental issues through most of the 1980s and â€™90s, culminating in a poetic reference in Smash Mouthâ€™s 1999 banger â€œAll Star.â€ Perhaps due to the easily digestible urgency of the problem (a hole that was getting bigger), an international agreement to phase out CFCs known as the Montreal Protocol was reached quickly in 1987.

And, despite a few hiccupsâ€”including a 2018 discovery that factories in China were emitting large amounts of banned chemicalsâ€”the Montreal Protocol has proven successful. Yesterdayâ€™s report found that the primary ozone-depleting gasses in the stratosphere were on the decline from their peaks:

Chlorine decreased 11.5% from its peak in 1993.

Bromine decreased 14.5% from its peak in 1999.

In a bit of a full circle moment, the defunct Earth Radiation Budget Satellite, which helped confirm the ozone layerâ€™s decline in the â€™80s, fell back to Earth on Sunday night.â€”MK

TOGETHER WITH LANEAXIS

When companies need to ship freight, they call a trucking company, right? Wrong!Â 

They call a broker to hire a trucking company. These middlemen rake in $200b annually by charging up to 50% commissions, which drives up your product costs and shrinks truck driversâ€™ revenue.Â 

Enter LaneAxis <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30200055.3066282/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9zMD9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjAwMDU1LjMwNjYyODImbHA9dGV4dDE/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cde17503d>. Their patented software creates unprecedented efficiencies and lowers consumer costs via direct shipper-to-carrier connections, direct contracts, and direct payments.

The declaration will allow federal agencies to coordinate relief efforts as atmospheric rivers and cyclones keep pummeling the northern part of the state. As of yesterday, about 34 million Californians, or ~10% of the US population, were under a flood watch, according to CNN, and Montecito was ordered to evacuate.

Windsor watchers who have yet to overdose on British monarchy drama are queuing up at their nearest bookstore. Prince Harryâ€™s memoir, Spare, hits shelves <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30200055.3066282/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rcy5tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vYy9zYz9taWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmYmY2lkPTMwMjAwMDU1LjMwNjYyODI/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cd36a024f> today and bombshell pre-release leaks suggest that itâ€™s a juicy one (we already know more than we want to about royal circumcision).

Royalties for royalty

Celebrity narratives are big business: A four-book deal (allegedly) earned Harry and his wife Meghan up to $40 million. And though literary accolades are likely not on the horizon for Prince Harry (or his ghostwriter), Spare already clinched the No. 1 bestseller spot at both Amazon and Barnes & Noble.

Its publisher, Random House, says it printed 2.5 million copies for North America, betting at least that many readers will be willing to shell out $25 to get further details on how Harry lost his virginity in a field, behind a pub.

Zoom out: Harry and Meghan have not shied away from getting paid to publicly air grievances with family members turning themselves into a powerful media brand after walking away from royal duties. GOVERNMENT

In Congress, the fiercest battles are only beginning <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.> The US Capitol building <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.> Drew Angerer/Getty Images
Last weekâ€™s historic, bare-knuckle brawl to elect Rep. Kevin McCarthy as House speaker was a sign that in this 118th Congress, weâ€™ve ainâ€™t seen nothing yet. Concerns grew over the weekend that the chaos and brinkmanship that characterized the 15-round speaker vote could foreshadow nasty infighting <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.3054878/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cud2FzaGluZ3RvbnBvc3QuY29tL3VzLXBvbGljeS8yMDIzLzAxLzA3L2dvcC1idWRnZXQtZGVidC1saW1pdC1rZXZpbi1tY2NhcnRoeS8_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C78246370> around the biggest legislative issues of the year.

After all, electing a House speaker in just one ballot has been mostly a foregone conclusion since the Civil War. So if you can barely dice the onions, how are you supposed to make the entire chili?

The No. 1 issue: debt ceiling

The biggest challenge for Congress to tackle in 2023 is raising the debt ceiling <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.3054878/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wMS8wNy91cy9wb2xpdGljcy9zcGVha2VyLWVsZWN0aW9uLWRlYnQtbGltaXQtcmVwdWJsaWNhbnMuaHRtbD91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1d75b5cf>.

What is the debt ceiling? Itâ€™s a limit on what the US government can borrow to pay its bills. And since the government runs on budget deficits, it regularly needs to borrow more money to avoid a credit default, which would be a disastrous scenario. Should a potential default materialize due to congressional paralysis, it could crater global markets and plunge the US into a recession.

So, whatâ€™s the status? In 2021, Congress raised the debt ceiling by $2.5 trillionâ€”but that will only get us to August, when Goldman Sachs predicts that lawmakers will need to raise the roof again to avert a default.

Hereâ€™s where the McCarthy vote comes into play: The small faction of hardline Republicans who held up McCarthyâ€™s election as speaker could, in effect, hold the debt ceiling â€œhostageâ€ by getting their demandsâ€”specifically, spending cuts to domestic programs and the militaryâ€”into any debt limit bill. Given their outsized leverage in the Republican Partyâ€™s slim majority in the House, this group could bring debt ceiling negotiations perilously close to the expiration date, which is worrying economists over the downstream effects on markets.

Looking aheadâ€¦the concerns about gridlock may become real starting today, when the House will vote on a rules package that determines how the chamber will operate during its term. Some Republicans expressed hesitation <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.3054878/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cudGhlZ3VhcmRpYW4uY29tL3VzLW5ld3MvMjAyMy9qYW4vMDgva2V2aW4tbWNjYXJ0aHktaG91c2Utc3BlYWtlci1uZXh0LWZpZ2h0LXJ1bGVzLXBhY2thZ2U_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cad4ff5ce> this weekend about approving these rules due to the still unknown concessions McCarthy must have granted the hardline faction to secure his speaker seat.

TECH

Better call SaulBot 3000 <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.> Saul Goodman and Walter White on Breaking Bad <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.> Breaking Bad/AMC
Would Walter White have received better counsel from an AI than from Saul Goodman? We might get closer to the answer next month, when a robot will advise a defendant <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.> in US court for the first time in history, New Scientist reports.

The â€œrobotâ€ is actually an artificial intelligence algorithm created by the company DoNotPay. Itâ€™ll run on a smartphone located in the defendantâ€™s pocket and, through an earpiece, will advise them on what to say after hearing the arguments presented during the hearing.

DoNotPay is keeping the specifics of its â€œexperimentâ€ mostly under wraps, since what itâ€™s doing violates courtroom protocol, but we do know the hearing involves a speeding charge <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30190372.3054878/aHR0cHM6Ly9naXptb2RvLmNvbS9kb25vdHBheS1zcGVlZGluZy10aWNrZXQtY2hhdGdwdC0xODQ5OTYwMjcyP3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C135ff807>. Interestingly, no one in court other than the defendant will know that an AI lawyer is even involved (DoNotPay will use a hearing accessibility loophole to get the defendant to wear AirPods).

DoNotPay said itâ€™ll cover any fines or fees incurred by the defendant if its AI gets stage fright in court or if they otherwise lose the challenge.

Big picture: Recent breakthroughs in AI have some of us worried about robots taking our jobsâ€”are lawyers on the chopping block? Maybe not yet, but in a test from 2018, a machine-learning AI topped human attorneys when analyzing NDAs for risks.

ECONOMY

Why slowing wage growth has economists popping bottles <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.> Briefcase with green leaves growing out of it <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.> Hannah Minn
Most people donâ€™t toast to government data on a Friday night, but a report on the job market that dropped yesterday inspired cautious optimism: There might be a way out of our current inflation hellscape without bringing the economy to the brink of collapse after all.

The big numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics report:

The unemployment rate dropped <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYmxvb21iZXJnLmNvbS9uZXdzL2FydGljbGVzLzIwMjMtMDEtMDYvdXMtaGlyaW5nLXRvcHMtZm9yZWNhc3RzLWpvYmxlc3MtcmF0ZS1mYWxscy1hcy13YWdlLWdhaW5zLXNsb3c_c3JlZj1La1B6cFp2eg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C1e3d2005> to 3.5%, the lowest itâ€™s been in 50 years.

The US added 223,000 nonfarm jobs in December. Though job growth slowed from the previous month, the labor market is still going strong.

In 2022, 4.5 million total jobs were added, compared with 6.7 million in 2021.

But the number that really got people talking was the lower-than-expected month over month wage growth, which slowed to .3% in December and 4.6% annually.

While that might not sound like welcome news to anyone who doesnâ€™t live off a fortune inherited from their robber baron granddad, the folks at the Federal Reserve are most certainly pleased. Rapidly growing paychecks are seen as one of the key drivers of inflation, which the Fed has been trying to tame with aggressive interest rate hikes since early last year.

Economists have dubbed the jobs data a â€œGoldilocksâ€ situationâ€”not too hot, and not too cold. Since the labor shortage and the strident wage growth it drove seem to be abating, the hope is that inflation will continue to decline. At the same time, a strong labor market (fingers crossed) might just allow the economy to avoid a recession caused by the interest rate increases.

Zoom out: Experts expect slowing wage growth to signal to the Fed that itâ€™s time to chill with the aggressive rate hikes. And itâ€™s not just speculation: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said yesterday that heâ€™d lean toward just a 25 basis point increase (as opposed to 50 basis points) for the next interest rate hike if the labor market continues to cool.â€”SK

TOGETHER WITH THE MOTLEY FOOL

WORLD

Tour de headlines <#>
New Alzheimerâ€™s drug heads to the pharmacy. The FDA approved <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY25uLmNvbS8yMDIzLzAxLzA2L2hlYWx0aC9sZWNhbmVtYWItZmRhLWFwcHJvdmFsL2luZGV4Lmh0bWw_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2b3d9475> Leqembi, a drug that may slow down cognitive decline in early Alzheimerâ€™s patients. Key word: may. Clinical trials of the drug werenâ€™t as conclusive as some medical experts would like, but Leqembiâ€™s approval was fast-tracked since few treatments exist for the disease. The FDA has been criticized for granting the same accelerated approval to another unproven Alzheimerâ€™s drug, Aduhelm, in 2021.

ChatGPT expelled from schools. New York City public schools, the largest school district in the US, banned <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.> the AI text generator from school devices and networks this week, hoping to keep kids from cheating by getting ChatGPT to write that book report for them. Of course, students can still use it to fire off their term papers at home, but the move shows how worried educators are about the toolâ€™s potential. They may not need to be: A Princeton student recently built an app to help teachers detect cheating with the chatbot.

SPORTS

A rattled NFL returns to the field <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy8yMDIzLzAxLzA2L2EtcmF0dGxlZC1uZmwtcmV0dXJucy10by10aGUtZmllbGQ_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb5474202> Cooper Kupp #10 of the Los Angeles Rams takes to the field before a game against the San Francisco 49ers at SoFi Stadium <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy8yMDIzLzAxLzA2L2EtcmF0dGxlZC1uZmwtcmV0dXJucy10by10aGUtZmllbGQ_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Db5474202> Harry How/Getty Images
The final weekend of the NFLâ€™s regular season is typically among the most exciting dates on the sports calendar each year, featuring high-stakes games where teams jockey for playoff spots and higher seeds in the postseason.

And thatâ€™ll happen again today when Week 18 kicks off, albeit under the giant cloud of Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlinâ€™s cardiac arrest during a game Mondayâ€”a horrific injury that has shaken players, coaches, and fans of the game.

Hamlin update: He had his breathing tube removed <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZXNwbi5jb20vbmZsL3N0b3J5L18vaWQvMzUzOTE4MTIvYmlsbHMtZGFtYXItaGFtbGluLWJyZWF0aGluZy1vd24tdHViZS1yZW1vdmVkP3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7378db86> and has been talking and FaceTiming with family and his teammates. â€œI love you, boys,â€ he told his fellow Bills players yesterday.

Meanwhile, the NFL has announced a few tributes and changes in light of the incident:

Teams have been given a number of options to support Hamlin, including painting â€œ3â€ (his jersey number) in Bills colors on their 30-yard line.

After canceling the Billsâ€“Bengals game in which Hamlin collapsed, the NFL unveiled a complex set of scenarios for the playoffs, which include the AFC Championship Game potentially being played at a neutral site.

Big picture: While Hamlinâ€™s collapse has prompted reflection over the violence of the NFL, new viewership data <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuc3BvcnRpY28uY29tL2J1c2luZXNzL21lZGlhLzIwMjMvbmZsLWdhbWVzLWFjY291bnQtZm9yLTgyLW9mLTEwMC10b3AtdHYtYnJvYWRjYXN0cy0xMjM0NzAwMzgxLz91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C8baeacfc> from Sportico shows that pro football still maintains â€œhegemonic dominance over the domestic media market.â€ NFL games represented 82 of the top 100 TV programs in the US last year.â€”NF

SOCIAL MEDIA

A romance author faked her own death <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9pbmRpZS1yb21hbmNlLWF1dGhvci1mYWtpbmctaGVyLW93bi1kZWF0aD91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3Jm1pZD03Y2QzZDdlZmNiMmI1ZDFhNmNiZTBiZjA5MzFmNGIyZg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C578d45ae> Susan Meachen's book cover for "Love to Last a Lifetime" on background of faded roses. <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9pbmRpZS1yb21hbmNlLWF1dGhvci1mYWtpbmctaGVyLW93bi1kZWF0aD91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3Jm1pZD03Y2QzZDdlZmNiMmI1ZDFhNmNiZTBiZjA5MzFmNGIyZg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D578d45ae> Photo Illustration: Dianna â€œMickâ€ McDougall, Source: Amazon
In the biggest scandal to hit Facebook since we got banned for offering a bag of half-eaten tortilla chips in our neighborhood Buy Nothing group, indie romance author Susan Meachen posted <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30179621.3048557/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYnV6emZlZWRuZXdzLmNvbS9hcnRpY2xlL2tlbHNleXdlZWttYW4vc3VzYW4tbWVhY2hlbi1hdXRob3ItYWxsZWdlZC1kZWF0aC1ob2F4P3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C65d66de9> that sheâ€™s actually alive.

She faked her own death for over two years. Meachen is/was/??? known in the romance writing world for self-publishing over a dozen books and running a successful niche Facebook group. In 2020, a post supposedly written by her daughter claimed that she had died by suicide because of bullying from other authors.

Then, on Monday, Meachen posted in the same Facebook group that was used to announce her death that she was alive and ready to start writing again, ending her post with â€œLet the fun begin.â€

While her friends and fans were glad to find out she was alive, they were also horrified. Some asked where the money they crowdfunded for funeral costs went. After Meachenâ€™s supposed death, the community even edited her final novel for free and helped promote it in her honor.

What the twist? No oneâ€™s quite sure why Meachen did this. The only explanation she offered in her post was, â€œMy family did what they thought was best for me.â€â€”MM

The Ascent <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZm9vbC5jb20vbW1zL21hcmsvdGEtY2MtY2l0aXNpbXAvP3V0bV9zaXRlPXRoZWFzY2VudCZ1dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249dGEtY2MtY28tbWItY2l0aXNpbXAtMDEwNjIwMjMtNS1uYS1uYSZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPWNwYyZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1iJmxwPWxvZ28/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C6b8df858> 
Good morning. The US House of Representatives still does not have a speaker since a small faction of rebels in the Republican party keep blocking Rep. Kevin McCarthy from securing the 218 votes needed to clinch the position.

And after going 0â€“11 in votes so far, McCarthy is racking up a losing streak thatâ€™s verging on Process-era Philadelphia 76ers territory. In fact, the only times the House has needed more ballots to choose a speaker was before the Civil War.

Will today be the day for a breakthrough, or just another scene from Groundhog Day? Weâ€™ll find out when the House reconvenes at noon ET today.

ANTITRUST

FTC to noncompete agreements <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9mdGMtd2FudHMtdG8tZ2V0LXJpZC1vZi1ub25jb21wZXRlcz91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3Jm1pZD03Y2QzZDdlZmNiMmI1ZDFhNmNiZTBiZjA5MzFmNGIyZg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cb0b0ce89> Finish Him!! screen on Mortal Kombat <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9mdGMtd2FudHMtdG8tZ2V0LXJpZC1vZi1ub25jb21wZXRlcz91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3Jm1pZD03Y2QzZDdlZmNiMmI1ZDFhNmNiZTBiZjA5MzFmNGIyZg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Db0b0ce89> Midway Games via Giphy
While the House has spent the last week in Jackass Forever mode, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) got serious and proposed <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly90aGVoaWxsLmNvbS9idXNpbmVzcy1hLWxvYmJ5aW5nLzM4MDA0ODUtZnRjLXVudmVpbHMtcHJvcG9zYWwtdG8tYmFuLW5vbmNvbXBldGUtY2xhdXNlcy8_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2fb8ed25> a new rule yesterday that could impact everyone from Big Tech execs to unpaid social media interns. The potential rule would ban noncompete agreements, a common mechanism used by companies to keep employees from jumping ship and working for competitors.

Itâ€™s been a long time coming

In a 2021 executive order, President Biden asked the FTC (led by antitrust shark Lina Khan) to target noncompetes. And the proposal the agency came up with flexes more muscle than it has in the past: The plan would make all new and existing noncompetes illegal, as well as require companies to inform employees that any previous noncompete agreements are void.

Why are noncompetes a thing? Theyâ€™re pitched as a way to protect trade secrets so someone working at Dominoâ€™s doesnâ€™t leave and design a pizza tracker app for Pizza Hut (okay, not a bad idea). But as noncompetes have flooded industries across the board, the FTCâ€”and even the Treasury Department <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuYnVzaW5lc3NpbnNpZGVyLmNvbS9jb21wYW5pZXMtcGF5LXdvcmtlcnMtbGVzcy10aGFuLXdvcnRoLWJpZGVuLXdhbnRzLXRvLWNoYW5nZS0yMDIyLTM_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C7b584225>â€”say these clauses are essentially trapping workers in lower wages. Putting an end to the practice could boost wages by $300 billion every year, and release workers from career inertia, per the FTC.

Noncompetes are truly everywhere: In one high-profile case in 2016, Jimmy Johnâ€™s settled a lawsuit with the Illinois state attorney generalâ€™s office, saying it would not enforce its noncompete that barred workers from making subs (and sub-adjacents) within a three-mile radius of any JJ shops for two years. As if Jersey Mikeâ€™s would even need those dry sandwich secrets.

Looking aheadâ€¦the FTCâ€™s 3â€“1 vote in favor of the proposed rule is the first step of the agencyâ€™s rulemaking process. Next up is 60 days of public comment. But thereâ€™s no date set for a final vote, and the plan is sure to face challenges even if it does cross the finish line. The US Chamber of Commerceâ€”which represents a lot of big, powerful corporationsâ€”threatened legal action against such a change in 2021.â€”MM

WORLD

Damar Hamlin is awake. Doctors at the University of Cincinnati Medical Center said the Buffalo Bills safety had woken up <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9hcG5ld3MuY29tL2FydGljbGUvYnVmZmFsby1iaWxscy1kYW1hci1oYW1saW4tdXBkYXRlcy1jMDg2ZTQ3MmIxMGI0ZTc5Y2QyNDUwMmJjYmYyZTA5Yj91dG1fc291cmNlPWhvbWVwYWdlJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09VG9wTmV3cyZ1dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249cG9zaXRpb25fMDI/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cf1190b4a> on Wednesday night, two days after he had gone into cardiac arrest during an NFL game and was sedated. Hamlin has been able to communicate via writing, and his first question was whether the Bills won their game against the Cincinnati Bengals. The doctors responded: â€œThe answer is yes, Damar, you won the game of life.â€ That Billsâ€“Bengals game has been canceled by the league, but NFL teams are still preparing to play in an anything-but-normal Week 18 this upcoming weekend.

Pineapple Express slams California with wind and rain. A weather event known as a Pineapple Express storm has caused thousands of power outages and at least two deaths in California, which has been under a state of emergency since Wednesday. The storm brings <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnByLm9yZy8yMDIzLzAxLzA1LzExNDcxMDI5NjgvY2FsaWZvcm5pYS1zdG9ybS13ZWF0aGVyLXBpbmVhcHBsZS1leHByZXNzLWF0bW9zcGhlcmljLXJpdmVyP3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C2e657d59> with it 100+ mph winds and buckets of rainfall, which has led to flash flooding and landslides in parts of the state. Parts of Northern California were evacuated or placed under weather advisory, and forecasters have warned that more storm systems are expected to hit the area next week.

Drama at the southern border ahead of Bidenâ€™s visit. The president is planning to visit the USâ€“Mexico border for the first time in his tenure on Sunday, and before his trip he announced tighter restrictions <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9hcG5ld3MuY29tL2FydGljbGUvcG9saXRpY3MtbWV4aWNvLWltbWlncmF0aW9uLWFmMDY0M2E0ZmI4ZjQ1Mzg4ZmUyNDdlNDRjOWIyYzVlP3V0bV9zb3VyY2U9aG9tZXBhZ2UmdXRtX21lZGl1bT1Ub3BOZXdzJnV0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1wb3NpdGlvbl8wNA/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cc650513e> on migrants who try to come into the US without authorization, telling them to apply for asylum in their home countries instead. Meanwhile, Mexico arrested the son of drug lord â€œEl Chapo,â€ who is himself allegedly one of the top traffickers of the deadly opioid fentanyl.

RETAIL

Bed Bath & Beyond says itâ€™s reached its limit <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9iZWQtYmF0aC1iZXlvbmQtcG90ZW50aWFsLWJhbmtydXB0Y3k_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D3658471a> Bed Bath & Beyond bankruptcy <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy9iZWQtYmF0aC1iZXlvbmQtcG90ZW50aWFsLWJhbmtydXB0Y3k_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2E3658471a> Photo Illustration: Dianna â€œMickâ€ McDougall, Source: Getty Images
Big January-in-the-Northeast vibes out of Bed Bath & Beyond yesterday, as the company announced <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnl0aW1lcy5jb20vMjAyMy8wMS8wNS9idXNpbmVzcy9iZWQtYmF0aC1iZXlvbmQtYmFua3J1cHRjeS5odG1sP3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Ce6c88968> in a public filing that it has â€œsubstantial doubtâ€ about its ability to continue and could potentially file for bankruptcy.

BBBY expects to report a 33% sales decline compared to Q3 last year (which included Black Friday). The company anticipates losses to reach $385.8 millionâ€”a 40% spike from last yearâ€”and warned that it may not have cash for suppliers and lease agreements in the coming months. In response, shares fell to their lowest level in ~30 years, marking a 96% decline from the stockâ€™s recent peak during its period in the memestock limelight (more on that in a bit).

What happened? Maybe shoppers are just less impressed by towels these days. But more likely the retailer also committed a self-own by replacing big brands with private labels amid supply chain snarls and at a time when pandemic-era shoppers wanted to shell out for a Kitchen-Aid. Sales fell flat due to supply chain issues and underinvestment in the BBBY website.

There was also the issue of meme stock investor Ryan Cohen, who announced a ~10% stake in the company in March, which prompted retail investors to also pile in. In August, however, Cohen exited <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2RhaWx5L3N0b3JpZXMvYmVkLWJhdGgtYW5kLWJleW9uZC1tZW1lLXN0b2NrLXJlYm9vdD91dG1fY2FtcGFpZ249bWImdXRtX21lZGl1bT1uZXdzbGV0dGVyJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9bW9ybmluZ19icmV3Jm1pZD03Y2QzZDdlZmNiMmI1ZDFhNmNiZTBiZjA5MzFmNGIyZg/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C57dbc378> his position and shares plummeted 45%.â€”MK

FOOD & BEV

Everyoneâ€™s becoming a non-alcoholic <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy8yMDIzLzAxLzA1L25vbmFsY29ob2xpYy1iZWVyLXdpbmUtYW5kLXNwaXJpdHM_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C77a5cba3> 0% ABV labeled beer taps <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJldy5jb20vZGFpbHkvc3Rvcmllcy8yMDIzLzAxLzA1L25vbmFsY29ob2xpYy1iZWVyLXdpbmUtYW5kLXNwaXJpdHM_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2NkM2Q3ZWZjYjJiNWQxYTZjYmUwYmYwOTMxZjRiMmY/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2D77a5cba3> Francis Scialabba
Nonalcoholic beer, wine, and spirits are grabbing headlines because itâ€™s Dry Januaryâ€”the month when people stop drinking <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubnByLm9yZy9zZWN0aW9ucy9tb25leS8yMDIzLzAxLzAzLzExNDQ2MjE2NDEvbm9uYWxjb2hvbGljLWJlZXItd2luZS1zcGlyaXRzLWRyeS1qYW51YXJ5P3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2Cef080b18> and the worst time to go on a family vacation. But it turns out that drinking 0% ABV lagers has turned into a year-round phenomenon for health-conscious customers.

Retail sales of nonalcoholic beverages grew more than 20% last year, and 120% over three years, per Nielsen.

IWSR Drinks Market Analysis estimates <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZm94YnVzaW5lc3MuY29tL2xpZmVzdHlsZS9iZXlvbmQtZHJ5LWphbnVhcnktcmlzZS1ub24tYWxjb2hvbGljLWRyaW5rcy1hZHVsdC1iZXZlcmFnZS1tYXJrZXQ_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2B33d66f62> the sector will expand more than 25% in the US by 2027.

Beer giants Ab Inbev and Heineken have launched <https://link.morningbrew.com/click/30167710.3067832/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY25iYy5jb20vMjAyMi8xMi8zMC9ub24tYWxjb2hvbGljLWJlZXItc2V0LXRvLWNvbnRpbnVlLXRvLWdyb3ctaW4tMjAyMy5odG1sP3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/62b63bd3ff8136015c0bece2C6a21cab6> Oâ€™Douls competitors, and so have nonalcoholic breweries like Athletic Brewing Co.â€”which recently raised $50 million from Keurig Dr. Pepper. Alcohol-free wine and spirits represent much smaller pieces of the categoryâ€™s sales pie, but new brands pedaling adaptogens, nootropics, and whatever else Erewhon marks up have been launched by celebs including Bella Hadid and Katy Perry.

Meanwhile, sales of alcoholic beer and wine have declined year over year, and alcoholic spirit sales grew less than 1% annually.

Thatâ€™s not to say people are teetotaling. Actually, over eight in 10 people who buy nonalcoholic drinks also buy alcoholic drinks. Plus, the nonalcoholic drinks sector, despite its recent growth, is a shot glass to Big Alcoholâ€™s das boot, with the former representing a tiny 0.47% of the broader buzzed industry.â€”JW

Friday puzzle

This is an unusual paragraph. Iâ€™m curious as to just how quickly you can find out what is so unusual about it. It looks so ordinary and plain that you would think nothing was wrong with it. In fact, nothing is wrong with it! It is highly unusual though. Study it and think about it. You still may not find anything odd. But if you work at it a bit, you might find out. Try to do so without any coaching.
